(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID WESTIN, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: We want to welcome Catherine Bessant, she's Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch Chief Operations and Technology Officer. This is important. Miss Bessant has just been named the most powerful women in banking by the American banker and that's the second year in a row. So, I want to ask about threepeats (ph), Cathy, but thanks for being here. It's good to have you.

CATHERINE BESSANT, BANK OF AMERICAMERRILL LYNCH CTO: We're always going upward, David. Thank you.

WESTIN: So we've a lot of things to talk about Bank of America, about women in the workplace. But let's start with this Bloomberg story this morning, about this hardware hack as it were that really infiltrated some U.S. companies according to Bloomberg reporting.

I know that cybersecurity is right at the top of your list of priorities as Brian Moynihan's. What was your initial reaction when you read this? First of all, how do you know Bank of America doesn't have this problem?

BESSANT: Well, let's start with cybersecurity has to be at the top of every corporation's list. It's a ubiquitous risk and it's potentially systemic. So it's real. When I saw the news this morning my first reaction was, well, third party and fourth party risk is in fact I think the greatest source of risk to any supply chain for any company has. It's not just the companies that work with, but the companies they work with.

So, understanding the risk of the lineage of the hardware and software that actually goes to market, understanding where people are working with what vendors. People tell us all the time we're tough to do business with. I've actually become very proud of that on behalf of our customers and clients. I actually don't think it should be easy to put technology into the marketplace.

One thing I don't think has gotten enough conversation this morning, though, is we're talking about the chip and its detection. There are other mechanisms for prevention of risk that comes with that. We look at how data moves in our company. So, if somebody is a resident in our own hardware, could they actually get anything that was important to us? If the data moves, would we know?

And so, all of the emerging excellence in cybersecurity is really multiple layers of defense coupled with great tech investment which you know we do a lot of it and great talent. So, it's a multilayer defense strategy.

WESTIN: So has a hardware hack possibility been in your radar screen? Because we just haven't been covering stories like this. It's always been software, it's always been data access, it hasn't been actually something physically implanted in your machine.

BESSANT: I think that's really important part of the discussion. What this story reminds people or tells people for the first time his hardware risk is real. I think the risk is always been there but real manifestations of it that go beyond the hype or the fear that gets generated, those manifestations are very important. And this will spark a new dialogue.

ALIX STEEL, BLOOMBERG ANCHOR: So how you look at it in terms of protection? Because I was on a panel where I talked to three CFOs, three totally different companies, utilities, big tech and trucking. And then they're like, we literally can't spend all of our money on cybersecurity. We could but we can't. So you have to pick and choose what sponsor most vulnerable. How do you determine that?

BESSANT: Well, what's good thing and challenge is our company gives us unlimited budget in terms of tech investment and people investment.

STEEL: I see.

BESSANT: I always say the most important thing in cyber defense is caliber of talent, the team you actually put on the wall to prevent intrusion, to detect it, and then if or when that detected mitigated brilliantly. So, a lot of the success, in fact, I would -- to be all of this success we've had in this space in protecting our customers and teams to the talent we've got.

WESTIN: What's the role of government in this and particularly your relations with government? When you hear that the FBI has been investigating this particular chip for some time, certainly it wasn't made publicly known, it may have been communicated to individual companies, but from your experience, you have a great relationship? Do they call you up? Do they say, boy, we think we have a problem here or vice versa? Do you share information with them?

BESSANT: it's a two direction and multilateral sharing. I would say the most important role the government has is to cause and mandate that sharing to occur. There is no competitive advantage to secrets in this space especially regarding risks and sharing is the key to prevention and detection.

People ask about regulation. I'm not sure regulation is the answer. I do know that government has a huge role to play in how we share data with each other.

STEEL: Throughout the last hour and half we've been talking in different ways of sort of the next cold war say in technology for example. In your experience and expertise, how vulnerable are U.S. companies versus other companies in the world versus other countries in the world?

BESSANT: Well, I think any company, regardless of where it's (INAUDIBLE) their headquarter that has a global presence and sources globally is more at risks than a company that's insulare (ph) and stays at home. So, I would say the risk of amped up for global firms in a lot of ways that scale that causes of global firm to be in existence is important to defense. Defense does take money and people and it takes really sustain investment over time. We've had a dedicated information security team centralized team with enforcement authority in the company since 2008.

WESTIN: How is Bank of AmericaMerrill Lynch position particularly when it comes to trade problems, international problems? Because you have very substantial domestic U.S. deposit taking base that you offer now. You have international operations to be sure. I know you had a China operation I think you actually shut it down at some point. Are you more or less exposed? And in fact we do end up substantial, can I say, globalization?

BESSANT: Well our customers, no matter what jurisdiction or regulations or country by country regulation exist, our customers are global. And so we'll do whatever it takes in terms of innovation or business model to make sure we can serve their needs.

STEEL: Well, let's turn into your fabulous award you won. It's aw way to talk about gender diversity because it's not just sort of the buzzword, ESG (ph) thing, right? I mean look at California they're now requiring women on board. What do you think about that? Like that kind of requirement like Norway has which apparently hasn't really well for diversity.

BESSANT: Well, I'm not sure requirements are the answer. I don't think prescriptions about where talent should be used or how talent should be applied. And as a woman, I would never ever want to think (INAUDIBLE) to the strong women I know want to think they got the job because of a law or a mandate.

What I do think is this, 50% of the people in the workforce are women. 50% of the people to join our company are women. As long as you get to higher levels of management, 50% of our people are women. When 50% of our CEO's aren't women we have a measure of progress we have got to make.

WESTIN: We have to make but how do we make it? I mean you have this experience in the boardroom, in the C-suite. I mean how do we get there? Because we talked about it a lot. We don't seem to be getting there.

BESSANT: I'm very fortunately because its front and center in the conversations at the firm, 40% of our board is diverse, 40% women, 40% of our management team is women, 40% of our top 1000. So, I'm lucky and that it's an active conversation

I will say this, I don't think that the talk and action and dedicated smart people that have been working on gender diversity for decades, I don't think we're seeing the progress that all of that thought should produce. I've been thinking a lot about what should I be working on over the next year. I'm starting to have emerging theories about our women in power alley jobs. Jobs that take them to CEO roles. I don't know I know the answer to the next five years. I know that what we've been doing in the past hasn't been getting us where we want to go.

STEEL: All right. Just one other question like what's the problem? Because now it's like CEOs are talking about it. There's a mandate in California. Like it's on there. It's up there. Shareholders want it. What's the biggest holdup that you see?

BESSANT: Well, I actually don't know the answer to that.

STEEL: Fair point.

BESSANT: I wish I knew. If I knew, more than one of my direct reports would be to a woman. I do know this. Three years ago, three of my direct reports where women, two hired way by other firms. We aren't doing ourselves as corporate industry and industry being, you know, helping create new pipelines of talent where approaching each others talent, for a lot of -- in some cases really good reasons. When I do think the focus -- our focus as a firm is ensuring that the pipeline is strong enough to produce the kind of results that take -- that get us to that 40% of our senior workforce being women.

Tech disciplines if you don't mind by saying that.

STEEL: Yes.

BESSANT: Tech disciplines are really hard, right? We can say 50% of the entering workforce in general is women in U.S. colleges and universities this year. About 17% of the STEM, the engineering technology math graduates, 17% of them will be women. So, from the start in the tech disciplines we under index. And again, fortunate to work for a firm how's all over this.

STEEL: So, to brought now here and it's great to get you here to get your focus on to the next year. As you look at 2018, what's the biggest risk? What will keep you up most at night?

BESSANT: Well, the cyber reports to me, I focused every single day on cyber. And if the board was asking me, I would say third-party risks in cyber. So you've given us a great platform to talk about that today. I also think the pace of change, regardless of whether its cyber or technology in general, one thing I spent a lot of time thinking about is has the pace of change exceed in enterprise's ability to keep up with it. So, and I believe there are lots of solutions to that. That will be a huge focus for the firm as we move in to next year in my spaces.

STEEL: Cathy, so great to catch up with you. Thank you so much. Catherine Bessant of Bank of America, Chief Operations and Technology Officer. Great, great to see you.

(BREAK)

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5PGS-FC71-DXVP-V4R2-00000-00Cathy O’Neil: What kind of information economy will support healthy democracy?2017-09-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisPRINT SPECIFICCathy O’Neil: What kind of information economy will support healthy democracy?Staff Writer

The internet, led by the tech giants Amazon, Facebook and Google, has been great at connecting us with products. It has been less good, however, at connecting us as a polity. It's time we started imagining what an internet optimized for the citizen would look like.

I'm a plus-sized woman, and when I was pregnant with my first son in 1999, finding maternity clothes was a pain. The maternity shops didn't have my size, and the plus-size shops didn't sell maternity clothes. By the time I was pregnant with my third son in 2008, the internet offered all I needed — very cheaply and with quick delivery.

We've made a trade. In exchange for commercial surveillance and data collection, we have the world's best at-home mall. And just as my friends and I used to socialize at the mall when we were teenagers, nowadays we socialize online in commercial spaces like Facebook and Twitter. The stores around us, informed by our digital profiles, magically transform to meet our needs and desires. We have the tailored internet experience.

This happy story has exceptions. Predatory industries use the same profiling technology to locate folks desperately in need of money or vulnerable to gambling pitches and sell them things they shouldn't buy. But in large part, we're in consumer nirvana.

The dark side of this revolution is that data collected for one use can be repurposed for another. Our marketing silos are information silos, too. Thanks to our tailored experiences, we barely share a common reality with people who disagree with us. They see different products, different political news, even different facts.

It crept up on us slowly, while we were playing with our new toys. But now the internet giants have enormous power. Facebook and Google together collect 77 percent of U.S. digital ad revenues. They account for a growing portion of political ads and offer us news environments that they control and edit. They capture so many hours of our attention every day, it's hard to see how we wouldn't be influenced.

This influence isn't benign. Just last month, the New America Foundation shut down its Open Markets initiative after a big donor — Eric Schmidt, executive chairman of Google parent Alphabet Inc. — reportedly objected to its position on European antitrust regulation. The tech giants are spending increasing amounts on lobbying, lest we think of their market power and access to data as anything other than inevitable.

Consider the implications for society. The way Google presents search results can influence voter opinions and possibly help radicalize vulnerable people (remember Dylann Roof?). Facebook's experiments with its "I voted" button suggest that it could shift election outcomes. Imagine the possibilities if Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg ran for president (not an unthinkable scenario). He would be completely within his rights to direct his engineers to skew the Facebook newsfeed toward positive coverage of his campaign.

We caught a glimpse of what that might look like in the last presidential campaign. Donald Trump's team, for example, reportedly planted Facebook posts as part of an operation to suppress the African-American vote. And now we know that fake accounts, likely operated out of Russia, spent about $100,000 on Facebook ads ahead of the 2016 election — ads that might have reached tens of millions of people. Yet researchers can't get a more precise sense of what happened, because Facebook hasn't released the data needed to do so.

Facebook gives us a lot. It's a place to connect with friends and family. It's also the most efficient propaganda machine ever built by man. How can we decouple those two things and promote one while limiting the other? More generally, if we decide that we've made a bad trade with big tech, what can we do about it?

The authority of the inscrutable makes it hard for any individual to take on the tech giants — nobody who isn't a data scientist specializing in machine learning can even understand the algorithms. That leaves government, which has so far focused on antitrust matters related to consumers, not to the state of our democracy. And the classic antitrust approach of splitting up companies to increase competition probably wouldn't do the trick: Who can compete against Google without the data, the engineering teams, the infrastructure and the code?

We'll have to try something else. It might involve setting a legal standard for transparency, so that people will know how their data is being sold, for how much and to whom. Or it might require finding ways to limit the use of targeted advertising, so there would be less incentive to collect quite so much data about us.

Maybe what we need is a sort of internet-age analog to the ideal of public broadcasting — a new and parallel internet optimized for the citizen rather than for the consumer. Picture a space that isn't polluted with ads, that allows people to search for, say, information about health from sources that have nothing to sell them. We would go there to learn, listen and engage, and go back to the commercial internet only when we wanted to buy something. It might start locally, at the city or neighborhood level, curated and informed by local standards and customs. The people who created content could be compensated by their communities.

There's probably no single or perfect solution, but we have to start somewhere. Extrapolate 50 years into the future, when the big data of today will look puny and the algorithms inaccurate and modest. What kind of information economy will support a healthy democracy?

This isn't a technological challenge. It's a political imperative. We can't give away our democracy to a tiny group of profit-seeking corporations in return for a better shopping experience. At a minimum, we should demand that Facebook and Google make public all the data on their political ads, including who bought them and how they were targeted.

At least then we would have a better idea of what we're up against.

urn:contentItem:5VK2-9VD1-JDPT-T3VX-00000-00Cato Institute Holds Discussion on Technology Issues2019-03-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCato Institute Holds Discussion on Technology Issues

Cato Institute Holds Discussion On Technology Issues

March 01, 2019 09:15 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

CATO INSTITUTE PROJECT ON EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES DIRECTOR MATTHEW FEENEY

INTERNATIONAL CENTER FOR LAW AND ECONOMICS RESEARCH FELLOW ALEC STAPP

GEORGETOWN UNIVERSITY LAW CENTER STAFF ATTORNEY LINDSEY BARRETT

CATO INSTITUTE SENIOR FELLOW JULIAN SANCHEZ

DIRECTOR OF CIVIL LIBERTIES AT TECH FREEDOM ASHKHEN KAZARYAN

[*]FEENEY: Millions of people all across the world use social media sites and in doing so provide private actors with a gargantuan collection of intimate details. The Cambridge Analytica scandal highlighted how such information can be used, prompting calls for legislation and regulation. We also have concerns about big tech that go beyond social media. Google and Amazon also collect vast amounts of revealing information.

One of my favorite quotes about social media is a quote from now former Google Executive Chairman Eric Schmidt, who in 2010 said, "With your permission you give us more information about you, about your friends. We don't need you to type it all. We know where you are. We know where you've been. We more or less, know what you're thinking about." But are the risks associated with all of this data sharing and collection overblown? If not, what steps can lawmakers and private companies take to mitigate them?

So our first panel will--the first panel and flash talk will discuss these and other questions. The second panel will consider whether big tech companies are too big. The Trump Administration and some Democratic lawmakers are interested in investigating alleged big tech antitrust violations. While there is by partisan concerned about monopoly, there are also worried that such anti-trust enforcement would be inappropriate and could stifle innovation.

Alas, flash talk and panel will tackle online speech, their efforts to further regulate online ads, which raise a host of free speech concerns, allegations of anti-conservative bias in the largest social media sites have prompted discussions about content moderation, and the role of companies such as Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube in our liberal democracy. Should these companies use the First Amendment as their guide? What are the risks associated with government intervention in online speech?

So the guests on the stage today, of course, not the only ones with views on these questions, and I urge all of you to take part in today's conversations by using the #CATOtechnology. I want to remind everyone this event is being live-streamed and recorded. No food or drink is allowed in this auditorium. If you have to enter during a presentation please use the second entrance down the hall so as to minimize disturbances. And with that, I want to turn over to my colleague Julian Sanchez, who will get started on the first panel, which is Big Brother in Big Tech.

SANCHEZ: Thanks for that introduction, Matthew. I am, indeed, Julian Sanchez. I'm a Senior Fellow here at the CATO Institute, focused on issues of privacy and digital civil liberties, among others. To my left is Ashkhen Kazaryan, who is the Director of Civil Liberties at Tech Freedom. To her left, Alec Stapp, who is a freshly minted fellow at the International Center on Law and Economics. And his left, yet again, your far right, Lindsey Barrett, who is a staff attorney and Teaching Fellow at the Georgetown University Law Center's Institute for Public Representation Communications and Technology Clinic. I will forego the extensive recitation of our panelists impressive curriculum vitae, since in this wonderful connected world you are able to Google details--extensive personal information about all these people.

(LAUGHTER)

So I--I want to begin by picking up where Matthew left off. It seems like a more or less weekly occurrence that we read some news story about how online platforms or in some cases, device makers, are using or providing access to individuals private data in ways that provoke unpopular backlash. And yet at the same time, we find user behavior not exacting, you know, a toll, apparently, on those companies as people continue to give up large amounts of personal information, perhaps in part because they are not fully aware of how their information is being collected and used. And perhaps, in part, because it's simply difficult to understand what companies are doing with that data, buried as it often is behind impenetrable legalese in terms of service.

We've seen growing calls, including from, in many cases, legislators who are normally fairly averse to regulatory interventions. I think, perhaps, as we've all become used to this ritual of story backlash, companies saying, "Well, we take your privacy very seriously. We'll do better in the future." And just the--the pattern follows the--the old Smith's lyric, you know, "They'll never, never do it again." Of course, they won't, not until the next time.

So, you know, as these calls for, it's often called baseline privacy regulation grow, we want to explore, one, the extent to which there is a problem that might justify regulatory intervention, what proposals to try and more robustly protect user privacy or advanced, and what some of the wrinkles and potential trade-offs involved in those proposals are.

So I want to start by just throwing to the panel a question of how do we think about this problem? We know people like me, who are privacy advocates, tend to have a--a fairly high personal value they place on their--on their private information, but people's behavior in terms of, you know, what they're willing to give to sites in exchange for free service doesn't appear to track, you know, the--the answers, they often give pollsters about how much they care.

So one question to--set up here is, what are the--what are the--the harms that we should be worried about in terms of the collection of personal data? And how should we interpret the fact that despite the sort of drumbeat of scandals, it doesn't appear to be altering user behavior? Is there a problem that needs solving?

BARRETT: So I think, and you touched on this point before, when we take behavior as the only kind of indication of what people want and, you know, how--how we should understand the need for privacy legislation, I think we're going to go pretty far astride. Because, of course, you know, we're dealing with so many privacy policy of each day, you know, there's no way, even were we able to sort through the, what is it, eight or nine privacy policies that the average person encounters each day, you know, they're impossible to read, the company can't necessary or, you know, whoever the entity is doing the privacy policy, they can't always disclose the risks because they don't know themselves. And then oh, by the way, people are bad at evaluating risks. So when we talk about kind of the link between behavior and what people want in privacy, I think we--we really have to understand the role that resignation plays, and just the fact that we're all swamped in an ecosystem that we can't really do much--we can't really do much to act on whatever preferences we have.

SANCHEZ: Right.

STAPP: I think that's an important thing to always be aware of the privacy paradox. And I agree that we have to look at both revealed preferences and--and user behavior and stated preferences on these surveys. But I think some surveys you don't get to hear a lot about the National Telecommunications and Information Administration within the Commerce Department. They survey these things on an ongoing basis. And the major concerns related to privacy and security risks have been decreasing slightly, but it's not increasing. It's relatively flat. People avoiding online activity due to security concerns also decreasing at a slight rate.

And then ITIF surveyed people and said, "In this trade off context of if you get benefits for giving your data away would you be willing to give, you know, a piece of sensitive data away? Would you be willing to share biometric data, medical data, or location data, in exchange for say, better targeted medical--medical services, or just better services in general, or discounts?" And 60 percent of people said they'd be willing to share at least one piece of sensitive information. So I think when you recognize that you get benefits in exchange for this information you see the survey numbers change a lot. And then, of course, in revealed preference behavior we have things like DuckDuckGo if you want to use a private search engine that protects your privacy more than Google does and you also have browsers to do the same and frame Oh, sorry,

BARRETT: And frame-- Oh, sorry, Ashkhen.

KAZARYAN: Oh, that's okay. You can--

BARRETT: --Oh, no, I was just going to say the framing of these questions is important, too. Because if you say, "Well, hey, wouldn't you like this nice, lovely benefit if you give away your health information?" then most people will say, yes. But then you evaluate, okay, you know, what are--what are the kind of the amorphous hopes of what we can do with medical information versus how we know it can be misused? That framing is somewhat different.

STAPP: Yeah, and I think we definitely want to discuss the proper framing here. And I think that gets closer to the reality on the ground because when you do give away your data you do get free services in return. So it's--it's pretty concrete in the present, as well, as--as you see in practice.

KAZARYAN: And let me just jump in and not disagree with either or you but say that, first of all, when we look at these surveys it's a good thing that agencies do them because they're the closest to real life situations, and seeing where there's harm and where there's no harm and how consumers are being affected. But at the same time, these surveys, they're on a macro level, they don't really give us any sufficient data to go off on.

For example, even me personally, when, if you ask me, I'm the person who emails every website that I want to delete my account from, and buffer them until they do that. But at the same time, I will sign up for any app you want me to if I need WiFi in an airport.

(LAUGHTER)

It's, you know, depending on a day, depending on the situation, each consumer has their own needs. And what we should focus on is the real harms that are done to the consumer. And that's why the system that we have, like the Notice and Consent System that exists, that was created in the '70s, obviously, it's not efficient enough for the internet in the 21st century. And right now, 2019 is the Super Bowl for privacy lawyers. And we should all really, you know, gather our teams and focus and ask these hard questions to figure out what to do next.

SANCHEZ: Right. And so I think, you know, a lot you have gotten to the heart of--of common critique of the-the Notice and Consent model that governs most dimensions of privacy protection, that is the idea that the way your privacy is protected is that sites will offer you some degree of specificity about what their practices are, in terms of service, you know, that's the thing that everyone pretends to read before they click, "Sure, let me use the thing." You know, after skimming through but not actually reading any of the 10 pages of dense legalese. And this is this sort of consumer evaluation and consent provides privacy protection. And I'm, you know, inclined to say we all recognize that is for better or worse, not very meaningful, right. And most people are not particularly meaningfully informed, you know, as--as Lindsey alluded to, a fair amount of research suggesting that it's not even, literally, physically possible for most people to actually read the privacy policies for all the sites that they use. That it would take, you know, essentially a month of their year to, if they were to actually just once a year read--read all of those documents.

And so I wonder if, you know, how does--how does it sort of problematize the idea of consent when we sort of admit that practically speaking, the people who are agreeing to this stuff aren't reading it and don't understand what--what they're giving up? I think it's a little bit too quick to jump from that to a particularly regulatory solution as--as a solution but, you know, is sort of the heart of the way we approach this now, based on an unrealistic conception of what a normal user can--can sort of accommodate, has bandwidth for?

BARRETT: Absolutely, and I think with that acknowledgment that it's--it's simply not possible to sift through the thousands of times a day that someone asks us, "Oh, okay, are you okay, with x, y, z," in order to do something like, "Hey, I have a work email at this end of the airport. We have to understand in that context, okay, what is the what is the baseline of collection practices or use practices that just shouldn't be okay? You know, in--in other consumer protection context, we don't ask people to evaluate, "Oh, okay, you know, some people are okay with a certain amount of lead in their paint. And some people are asking with a certain amount of toxins in their coffee." We say, "All right. You know what? We know that in these decision-making contacts, this is bad for people and people are not able to evaluate or the--or the," you know, I--I don't know what kind of benefits or could be to lead in--in paint. But I--I want to say it was used for a while, and I probably should have researched this--

STAPP: Delicious.

BARRETT: Yeah, well, there.

SANCHEZ: It tasted sweet, right? Yeah.

BARRETT: Yeah. But all of the various, you know, chemicals that, you know, we decided after a while, "No, no, maybe it makes paint thinner, or, you know, dry more quickly, but, you know, toddlers probably shouldn't eat it," you know, that--that is similar to this context, in that people are not in a position to evaluate, "Oh, what is the possibility that by using--by using a cell phone, someone is selling my location data to a bounty hunter?"

KAZARYAN: Sorry, I was just going to say, the problem that we might encounter and fall into is what if we assume there will be harm but there's no real harm that we've seen? Let's say, you move to a new city, and based on whatever activity you had online, certain platforms start giving you ads for housing and for furniture and for jobs. Is there a real harm? Some people find it creepy. And I actually wanted to address that concept of creepiness because I'm afraid that it drives the debate often these days, especially amongst people who are not privacy lawyers or policy experts. And yes, it is creepy, but it's also helpful. I think we keep forgetting how helpful--helpful it is and how our understanding of creepy changes with time.

If anyone remembers Caller ID debate when it used to be scary and people didn't like it and thought it was violation of their privacy. And nowadays, I know that if I see my mother's name on my phone I'm going to pick it up in the middle of this panel because she was going to assume I'm dead if I don't do so. I'm very grateful to the Caller ID law, you know, Caller ID technology for doing that. Even though it might be a little creepy.

STAPP: And to follow-up on Ashkhen's about harm, I think it's important remember, I'm going to kind of quibble with the framing of the question that Julian laid out here, is that, yes, we don't have federal comprehensive baseline privacy regulation United States, but we do have sector and age-based privacy regulation that holds organizations and companies to a higher standard for those types of data. I think this matches pretty well with when you see people describe relative sensitivities of different types of data. So people are most concerned about their medical data, their financial data, their educational data, being leaked out. Well, we have things like HIPAA, FERPA, and GLBA, to address those concerns. And we are also concerned about children's data because they don't have as much of a--a rational sense of using these services as adults, we assume, then we have CAPA for that as well. I think it's a bit mistaken to say that we don't--that this is like the U.S. is like the Wild West of privacy. We do have sector an age-based privacy policies that I think match potential harms that we see.

BARRETT: Well, at the same time, so for instance, housing ads, we want to consider kind of the incentives that the current actors in the ecosystem have in terms of how they might collect information and use it. So it--it can be great to get kind of location based ads or--or whatever it is, but also, Facebook is being sued for allowing advertisers to target people on the basis of, I think, it was aged disability, and--and whether they're Spanish speaking, for housing ads against the--against the Fair Housing Act. So we both want to understand what's possible, what's valuable, and kind of what companies are rationally incentivized to do when they know that nobody's going to come knock--knock on their door and make them not do it.

KAZARYAN: But we already have a system that will react to that, right. They're being investigated. Probably an agency or two are going to go after them. There's going to be probably a civil lawsuit also going after this. So any anytime there is any practice that is unfair or deceitful, there will be a reaction to it.

BARRETT: One can only hope. But so, Julian mentioned that I'm--I'm at Georgetown, IPR and we work a lot on children privacy, actually.
