Cato Institute Holds Webinar On The New Coronavirus And Legal Issues

June 05, 2020 11:00 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

FTC COMMISSIONER CHRISTINE WILSON

CATO INSTITUTE PROJECT ON EMERGING TECHNOLOGIES DIRECTOR MATTHEW FEENEY

CATO INSTITUTE CENTER FOR CONSTITUTIONAL STUDIES DIRECTOR ILYA SHAPIRO

[*]SHAPIRO: Good morning. My name is Ilya Shapiro. I'm the director of the Robert A. Levy Center for Constitutional Studies at the Cato Institute and this is the third inner series on coronavirus and the Constitution. Three months into the pandemic, things are opening back up and fits and starts with legal challenges about lingering shutdowns that may no longer be justified as well as other shutdowns that were always on dubious legal grounds.

We're still talking about the state's police power to govern for Public Health and Safety. And this is a power that's not unlimited like any power but governors and mayor's do have broad discretion assuming they have a good enough justification for putting in their restrictions and regulations.

Three months ago, these officials were acting on the best epidemiological data. The idea is that we were all potentially fists swingers. You know, my freedom ends at the point of your nose. Well, if asymptomatic people could transmit a deadly virus, then shelter and place orders and the like could be justified.

Some state actors have gone beyond their state constitutional limits. A few weeks ago, the Supreme Court of Wisconsin found that that state's health authorities violated the separation of powers, went against Wisconsin administrative law. There's also been lower court rulings in Oregon, Ohio, and Illinois about different aspects of those states shut down orders in whole or in part.

I think that's gratifying that we still have checks and balances that we--the--the--there's no pandemic exception to the Constitution as the Supreme Court of Texas put in a concurrence a few weeks ago. And this all goes to Jacobson versus Massachusetts of famous Supreme--our now famous Supreme Court case from 1905 allowing mandatory vaccination. Although, Jacobson still recognized that there are limits, let me quote from that.

If health regulations went beyond the necessity of the case and under the guise of exerting a police power violated the rights secured by the Constitution, the court would be bound to hold such laws invalid. And so, even beyond kind of broad-based challenges to lockdown orders, some specific measures have gone too far. Restrictions on drive-in churches when drive-in liquor stores across the street are open. Tennis courts, roping off store aisles that have so-called non-essential goods rather than simply restricting the number of people per square foot of a store, that sort of thing.

A woman in Dallas who was jailed for opening her hair salon that was ultimately reversed. An Ohio Court ruled stopping the closure of gyms because it wasn't the proper authorities, they weren't exercising that kind of power. The Attorney General last month sent a letter saying that the federal government would be enforcing people's civil rights and it's done so in several occasions particularly with regard to religious liberty. And the Supreme Court speaking of religious liberty just last week issued a five-to-four decision not stopping a California--a restriction on in-person church gatherings although that might need to be re-evaluated now that California has permitted the demonstrations and protests.

And so if churches are similarly situated to those kind of secular gatherings, maybe the law looks different. Even if the orders all go away tomorrow though, people won't feel safe right away. although, public opinion is changing rapidly on all of that and shows that private action is just as or more important than public law. Now that we flatten the curve preventing hospitals from being overwhelmed, indeed health care workers have been laid off, people want to resume their lives and recoup as much as they can.

Conventional wisdom is that we could get things moving quicker if we have broader testing programs and more ambitious contact tracing. But can the government any level force you to get tested before you go to certain places or participate in certain activities? Can it make you wear a mask whenever you go outside? Can businesses require temperature testing at the door? Can the government work with technology companies and force you to download apps to track your phone and make sure you're following distancing guidelines? Whether digital or analog, what kinds of powers can contact tracers have, and how does all this relate to the Fourth Amendment?

For all of these issues, I'm going to turn to my colleague Matthew Feeney, the director of Cato's Project and Emergency Technologies and federal FTC commissioner, Christine Wilson who had a very interesting May 13th op-ed in the Wall Street Journal, coronavirus demands a privacy law. Turn it over to Matthew first. Matthew seems to be muted.

FEENEY: I'm here now. Sorry about that, yes.

SHAPIRO: There we go.

FEENEY: There we go. So thank you--thank you really and I'd like to start by pointing out that I come at this through technology and civil liberties perspective. I treat this issue as one that--that implicates obviously the Fourth Amendment which protects us from unreasonable searches and seizures as well as new and emerging technologies. And we're in a situation now where it looks to many people as if increased surveillance would actually be very useful. We're in a situation now where there's a ongoing pandemic and you can reliably tell a lot about the spread of the pandemic depending on where people have been arguably.

And the issue is that many people have talked about emerging technologies in the context of contact tracing which is to find out more about where people have been and people they've spoken to. And that many of the viewers will be familiar with the Fourth Amendment which protects us from unreasonable searches and seizures. And since 1967, the expectation of privacy tests has really been the lodestar of this amendment. And when we're thinking about (INAUDIBLE) rotations as well as some of the emerging technologies we've seen recently, there are--there are two cases I'd like to discuss because I think they're relevant to the conversation that Ilya outlined.

The first is U.S. v Jones which concerns the use of a GPS tracker on a Jeep. Here, the law enforcement officials put a GPS tracker on--on a Jeep belonging to Antoine Jones who they suspected of being a drug dealer. This was done without a valid warrant. And there, the court took a bit of a dodge by saying well, this physical attachment onto the car actually implicated a trespass onto the vehicle and therefore it's unconstitutional.

It's a notable case because there is a five-justice so-called shadow majority where you had justices, the--the traditional liberals as well as Alito arguing basically, well, it can't just be this. We have to think about reasonable quotations and tracking. The other is a case that came out a few years ago. This is cop into the United States. There's--many viewers will be familiar I hope that the phone is playing a constant game of Marco Polo with nearby cell towers.

This case involved the government access to information gathered about Timothy Carpenters' whereabouts in order to secure a conviction for armed robbery. And what's interesting here is that the Court did hold that the warrantless collection of these kind of records for about a week did violate the Fourth Amendment but it's a very, very narrow holding with the Chief Justice noting that the opinion didn't touch other surveillance technologies. And this brings us to the ongoing conversation about the kind of technologies we're concerned about. You've seen some people from Apple and Google talking about Bluetooth technology so that if you download a certain app, your phone will notify you if you've been within physical proximity of someone who's tested positive for COVID-19.

The issue here is that because Carpenter's a narrow decision, we haven't had any ruling on this technology per se. What I will say is when it comes to government mandating of the downloading of apps onto phones, you potentially do implicate Jones here because it is potentially arguably a trespass onto your property. This and other issues were discussed by present professor Rozenshtein from the University of Minnesota law school who had a great article about not just how this is a potentially a trespass but also raising the issue of the special needs doctrine that under the Fourth Amendment, there is a special needs exception. Usually, this is discussed in the context of drunk driving stops or searching, student-athletes.

But we do know that for example, justice Cavanaugh does believe for example that the bulk NSA metadata collection was justified under special needs. And it's possible that you could have a pandemic special need. Ilya didn't mentioned that the so far isn't a pandemic exception to the Constitution but that's the kind of question I think Wolf will have to consider if it becomes mandatory if there's government mandates for certain technologies to be installed or owned. And with that, I'm happy to turn it over to Christine.

SHAPIRO: Before Christine starts, I should remind the viewers that you can ask us questions whether on the website or through Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube using the hashtag Cato Scotus. Christine. You're muted now, Christine.

WILSON: There you go. And we were warned not to make the mistake.

SHAPIRO: Technical hosts should have reminded every buddy that were--the technical who should have reminded everybody to mute themselves and then unmute. That caused more problems than it fixed.

WILSON: So, thank you Ilya for inviting me to participate in the program, and thank you Matthew for laying such a great foundation for my discussion. I come at this as a perspective of a lawyer who practices consumer privacy data security law. The Federal Trade Commission has--does have responsibility for consumer privacy and data security enforcement in the United States.

Using its general authority, we do not yet have a comprehensive privacy law--of federal privacy law in this country. We do have some sector-specific privacy legislation including health data, financial data, children's data. But lots of gaps are emerging as technologies evolve and we also have a multiplying set of state and international regimes which is creating a patchwork of laws. And so on a bipartisan basis, for many years, the FTC has called for federal privacy legislation that would create predictability and certainty for businesses but would also provide consumers with transparency about how their data are collected, used, monetized, and shared and the transparency would help create digital trust.

People may be unwilling to adopt new technologies if they're not sure what's happening with their data and in any event, people can make more informed choices about what products and services to use if they understand the implications for their data. Now, the coronavirus as it began to spread around the world drove a new aspect of these discussions and I believe underscored the need for a federal privacy law.

As efforts to engage in contact tracing and containment of the virus began to multiply, we saw mandatory apps deployed around the world. We also saw mechanisms formerly used for prisoners applied to those exposed with COVID-19. So for example risk trackers--mandatory risk trackers and--and this, of course, raises concerns particularly because we're talking about sensitive health data, sensitive location data. And privacy principles have a lot to say about these issues including use limitations for data that is collected.

If you're collecting it for purposes of containing the virus, it shouldn't be used for any other purpose. Data minimization only collect the data that you actually need to implement the contact tracing and containment of the virus. But this issue is also important for Fourth Amendment reasons and this is one of the things that I wanted to emphasize in my op-ed. Matthew described the reasonable expectation of privacy test.

And when you understand the implications of that test, you begin to realize that the commercial data--that the data that's collected on the commercial side actually is intricately related to government action. It is, you know, the reasonable expectation of privacy test really complicates the relationship between government action and commercial data collection. And so, we're talking about heightened concerns here and in fact, we have heard that recent initiatives to track protesters maybe using contact tracing information which brings yet another wrinkle to this story.

Last weekend, Minnesota's public safety commissioner used to praise contact tracing to describe law enforcement efforts in connection with the murder of--with the protests that we're taking place in--in connection with the murder of George Floyd. And the statement it seems to have triggered widespread social media claims that contract tracing apps are being used by law enforcement agencies to track protesters for nonpublic health purposes. And some of the social media discussions referenced the technology that Apple and Google have worked on that--that Matthew described for us.

Interestingly, Travis LeBlanc who was a Democrat on the privacy and civil liberties oversight board here in the United States sent a letter to acting secretary Chad Wolf on Monday to the Department of Homeland Security. He said, the pandemic is not a Hall Pass to disregard the privacy and civil liberties of the traveling public and I concur heartily in--in what Travis said. So the point of my op-ed even before the protests over the murder of George Floyd raised new issues was to say we need federal privacy legislation that can help apply some of the principles, the very familiar principles that we talk about in the privacy arena to the collection of health data, location data and--and with these established legal boundaries, companies would be better equipped to determine when the government is asking them to cross the line for the public good and whether they should require a subpoena or inform customers before turning over the data.

SHAPIRO: Great. Thank you for that Christine. Matt, do you have anything in response to that or did--did Christine's remarks trigger anything that you wanted to add?

FEENEY: Only the very briefly that I think the commissioners comments really do highlight that the Supreme Court set the--the floor, not the ceiling. That although we might be upset with a lot of Supreme Court precedent when it comes to things like the (INAUDIBLE) of privacy test or the third-party doctrine and a host of other issues, nonetheless that doesn't prevent the legislature from improving upon that standards which is obviously what Christine is calling for.

SHAPIRO: Yeah, I didn't know the--

WILSON: Oh, I'm sorry. Oh, yeah, I was just going to say there's a great book called (INAUDIBLE) data that traces the line of Supreme Court cases that culminates with Jones and carpenter and makes the point in the last chapter that technology continues to outpace what the courts can handle and that it really is up to Congress to step in and address this issue. And so I completely agree with Matthew that the Supreme Court is setting the floor but we can do better.

SHAPIRO: The court also never wants to get ahead of technology whether we're dealing with the Fourth Amendment or privacy area or antitrust or any--any legal areas where technology can disrupt as it were legal doctrine. And so in this area, what's interesting about the confluence of the Jones and carpenter cases is that this is, you know, Fourth Amendment privacy protections often bring the left and the right together against the middle or rather they, you know, the principle versus the pragmatic if you will on the court. And so in these cases, you see justices Sotomayor and Gorsuch perhaps forging the next doctrine. You know, the reasonable expectation of privacy that doctrine 50 years old in an analog world that in turn updated previous doctrine from the early days of the telephone maybe now in the digital age whether you're focusing on peoples--strong protections for their personal effects which can be all contained effectively on your phone.

Think about, you know, your financial health records family photos, so much is on that one little device more than the police could get from, you know, two hours of ransacking your home perhaps. You know, those kind of principles the meaning of those things along with Justice Sotomayor's concerned for interpreting people's privacy and in a modern age where police have different tools and--and what have you.

And it could, you know, people have been expecting even as the court takes very small steps in the Fourth Amendment arena to update doctrine. People have been expecting kind of a super session of the reasonable expectation test but maybe this emergency-type unusual pandemic related situation will provide a case contact tracing or otherwise where--where that will happen.

FEENEY: We have a question that maybe we should address at the outset, kind of the most obvious ones. Matthew, why don't you, this is comes in from a Singlard Broussard (PH) who asks CAN states require their citizens to download a contact tracing app. My understanding of the--the law is that no, it would, of course, they could have a certain circumstances, I suppose. You can imagine a situation where there's--again, this gives us back to--to--to special needs where there's actually potentially a carve-out. But as things stand especially in this context, I don't see that being legally feasible.

Something that we should keep in mind is something like the following which is you don't have a reasonable expectation of privacy and illegal contraband or illegal behavior necessarily so this gets us back to technologies or techniques like drug-sniffing, dogs. So I suppose it's hard to imagine how this would work. But if there was a technology that only notified the police when you broke some kind of lockdown order, then potentially you'd be in safe legal grounds but at the moment, I don't see that being feasible.

SHAPIRO: And I'll remind people that you can ask your questions either on the Cato website if you're viewing it there or on Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube with the hashtag Cato SCOTUS. Christine, as you're looking at and proposing a federal privacy law, how do you delineate what's there for--for whether the FTC or another federal agency to do versus leaving things to the States?

WILSON: So with that, is--it's a great question that--that actually proved to be one of the two sticking points in--in getting federal privacy legislation across the finish line. The first sticking point has been preemption and should there be preemption including of California's new law CCPA which sets a very high bar for privacy? And I think that preemption is important because the internet doesn't stop at state boundaries let alone national boundaries.

I believe that the Federal Trade Commission should be given authority to enforce federal privacy legislation and that the state AG's should also have authority to enforce that legislation as force multipliers for the Federal Trade Commission. But--but I think that state laws that set different levels of protection for consumers will--will just maintain this patchwork of--of laws that is going to lead to consumer confusion about what their rights are and what kinds of data are allowed to be collected in any different--in any given state. And then also chill innovation and investment in new technology by companies who are--who are facing a essentially a patchwork of laws and need to tailor their efforts to a lowest common denominator.

SHAPIRO: Just to be clear for the non-lawyers watching, preemption means that sometimes the federal government can through the Supremacy Clause in the Constitution can trump state law that's to the contrary, the preamble--can preamp that law in that--in the legalese. But of course, you always have to look at whether the federal government has the requisite powers. In this case, it would be to regulate interstate commerce with data traveling all over the place as well as these--these civil liberties concerns.

But you--you could have a cooperative federalism in a sense or rather state and federal regulations that both have to be satisfied when dealing with this sensitive data. Matthew, did you have something to add there?

FEENEY: No, I would only--actually, something did just occur to me. So that you have seen that there have been states that have passed their own privacy--privacy laws in California being perhaps the most notable. And I think the experiences that should make us cautious about what's involved in federal privacy legislation because I--part of what I worry about is not only privacy but also speech and making sure there is an innovative entrepreneurial market for tech. And I do worry that if we're not careful that Congress could end up passing some kind of federal privacy law that actually is anti-competitive that only powerful marketing (INAUDIBLE) can comply.

WILSON: Yes. So Ilya, if I could take a moment. That--that's actually--that's the experience that the EU saw with its privacy legislation GDPR. And they saw an increase in the market shares of some of the largest incumbents for advertising like Google and Facebook and they saw a venture capital investing in smaller companies dry up because of this--essentially this entrenchment of incumbents and the chilling of competition.

Given so much emphasis on privacy, the costs of compliance were incredibly high and a lot of smaller companies either couldn't afford those costs or chose not to bear those costs, you also saw lots of US companies withdrawing from the EU market because of the cost of compliance. And so I completely agree with Matthew that we do need to take competition into account. We don't want a privacy law that chills innovation and stifles competition. At the same time, a privacy law could help boost trust in new technologies.

Right now, consumers realize they have no transparency with respect to what data is being collected and how it's being shared and deployed. In fact, Matthew was talking about mandatory use of apps in response to a question about that. In fact, if it were voluntary, the Washington Post conducted a poll and found that basically, more than half of Americans would be unwilling to download those apps because they don't trust that the tech companies are going to keep their identities private if they end up testing positive for COVID-19.

And so that lack of digital trust leads to a lack of use of emerging technologies and, you know, and that can lead to chilled innovation, decreased incentives to invest in innovation. But during the time of the pandemic, actually, the lack of confidence in tech companies and contact tracing could prove fatal. So there are--there are very serious consequences of getting it right but also of not doing anything.

SHAPIRO: Yeah, sure. Like with any regulation you have to guard against the--the--the big established incumbent player is always having more money to spend on compliance officers and lawyers that--that can crowd out there--their would-be entrepreneurial competitors. Matthew, I know that we've been talking in the last week's offline about whether digital contact tracing is even effective. I mean if--if you're in a fairly dense urban environment and you get a ping that you're somewhere close to or have been somewhere close to someone who is infected, how useful is that and conversely, would it give, you know, a danger that they're by, the authorities would just lock down, you know, a thousand people that are in a relatively small geographic area just because everyone's so close together without really giving any parsimony to the--to the contact tracing?

FEENEY: That is--that is a real concern. I think--I hope that lawmakers and law enforcement officials are taking lessons from the current pandemic. I think it's fair to say that you can make a strong argument that this kind of contact tracing is highly effective at the beginning of the outbreak where you have a handful of cases. However, where we are now, I think there are serious questions about how effective it would be.

So, for example, as Ilya pointed out, the--the Bluetooth technology or that kind of technology that's been discussed in this context notifies you if you've been close to another telephone which presumably is on a person who is tested positive. Now, if you're in a--in a dentist's apartment building or looking out on the street and a bus pulls up next to you and the person inside the bus has that's a positive and you're outside the bus and you--you are negative, it's--it does not exactly the kind of dangerous exposure that I think a lot of people who are designing these technologies are--are worried about or--or health professionals are worried about.

Other factors that you're going to put a lot of people into lockdown in many, many environments if that kind of tracing is what's used. And some could make the argument, of course, that look, maybe it's better to be overly cautious, oh, we should lock down an entire apartment and buildings or maybe whole towns and cities because, in this kind of environment, everyone's going to be notified they've been in close contact. And now, that's been a question for local officials about how much of the economy they're willing to sacrifice for that kind of degree of--of health and public safety.

But I think it's very important is and I'm glad Ilya highlighted this, it's very important that as well as the constitutional issues and the legal issues, we should also have a discussion about the technology and whether it would even be effective at this point.

SHAPIRO: Here's a related question from Aaron Kremen (PH). Is an additional app even needed? All phones are tracked now, I would assume that information is de-identified to some degree. But we know through the accuracy of online advertising that you don't actually have to actually know who I am in order to know who I am.

This gets to a doctrine that we haven't discussed which--which piggy backs off reasonable expectation which is the so-called third-party doctrine. This idea being that you don't have a reasonable expectation of privacy and information you "volunteer" to third parties such as your telephone company or your internet service provider. And Congress has improved upon this floor and--but nonetheless, it still remains the case that you don't have the degree of privacy and a lot of information you give to internet companies that you would of--of--pieces of property you have in your home for example.

So the question is correct that there is a lot of information out there already about where phones are located. But that was the kind of data that was at issue in carpenter, for example. And then, I think if the court was to consider other kind of tracking technologies, they would likely come to a similar conclusion in carpenter which is well, for this particular kind of tracing as used by governments, that's important.

You know, the fourth member protects against government action. As far as the government's concerned, actually this would probably run awry of the Fourth Amendment's protections against unreasonable searches and seizures. But when it comes to whether Google could just volunteer all this information to the FBI or to the Department of Justice or to Health and Human Services, that's more in Christine's wheelhouse I suppose. But I would say that at least from a law enforcement perspective in the wake of Carpenter, you hope that they'd be somewhat hesitant to try and engage in that sort of snooping.

SHAPIRO: Christine, do you have anything on that?

WILSON: So I would say that goes to the digital trust issue. We have seen Apple respond vehemently when the government tries to collect information from it with respect to potential crimes that have been committed. And it is--it is an ongoing question that companies are grappling with, when and under what circumstances do they need to turn information over to the government and--and--and we saw in carpenter one answer to one narrow question. We've also seen with respect to contact tracing and with respect to other technologies deployed, these questions are arising and I think federal privacy legislation could have provided some guardrails here.

But, for example, we saw a Facebook turning over information about where people were at various times so that the--the efficacy of quarantine and stay at home orders could be traced and supposedly all of that information was de-identified. We see Facebook deploying surveys across the country to--to collect information about symptoms and giving that information to researchers. And--and so Facebook has said well people consented to sharing this information because, you know, we have a privacy policy and people are supposed to read it and they're supposed to consent before they can use our services.

And the fact is no one gave consent have their information used for purposes of contact tracing in a pandemic. No one had a pandemic in mind when they opened a Facebook account and gave consent. And I'm using Facebook as an example and maybe even as sort of a proxy for many other tech companies. But these are the kinds of questions that--that we do need to grapple with. When information is collected by a Facebook or a Google or any other tech company for a certain limited purpose of providing a service, is it then okay for them to use the data for a completely different and unanticipated purpose?

And so federal privacy legislation would presumably provide some guidance about purpose limitations. And--and so there are--there are lots of questions that are emerging, and frankly we have more questions than answers. And it's one of the reasons I put in the op-ed. It would have been really great to have federal privacy legislation in place to at least provide some guardrails to help us grapple with some of these issues during the pandemic, and now during nationwide protests and a national unrest.

SHAPIRO: Here's a related question from--

FEENEY: If you don't mind--go ahead, yeah.

SHAPIRO: Oh, sure. Go ahead.

FEENEY: I was just going to say that Christine's last comment reminded me of the case Jones which we've discussed before where Justice Sotomayor and her concurrence actually put her finger on exactly this concern about what kind of good sense there is when it comes to these technologies and she asked "I would ask whether people reasonably expect that their movements will be recorded and aggregated in a manner that enables the government to ascertain more or less at will that political and religious believe, sexual habits and so on.

And I think this exact question that we're trying to grapple at the moment raises those issues which is well, because you click on the terms and agreement when you sign up for a Facebook account or Gmail, does that really mean that you're consenting to all the kinds of behaviors that are going on behind the scenes? So what Facebook and Google are doing with that data? And that's--that's a difficult question for I think lawmakers to grapple with because on the one hand, these--these companies have to be careful with their Terms of Service, but on the other hand no one's ever got to read through the dozens and dozens of pages necessary so squaring that holes going to be difficult.

SHAPIRO: There's a related question from Singlard Broussard (PH) again good--good second question. Apple and Google defined some privacy standards that the app developers have to comply with to be able to use their technology. Do you--I think this is probably more directed to Christine. Do you see this as a restriction of the government's sovereignty or I suppose an attack on, I don't know, FTC jurisdiction or something or rather as a welcome initiative to protect privacy? And how would your proposed federal law--I'm adding this part--how would your proposed federal law affect this question?

WILSON: Great question. So the Federal Trade Commission over the course of many years has set out general principles with respect to consumer privacy. One of those is accountability for--for companies. And--and in lieu of federal privacy legislation that puts limits on the kinds of information that can be collected or the kinds of uses to which information can be put, the Federal Trade Commission has urged companies to abide by many of these principles. So data minimization.

Only collect the information that you need for the purpose that you're using it for so that among other things if you're hacked, that information is it is more limited in scope and can perhaps do less harm if it's exposed. de-identification, if you don't need to have identities associated with data, don't keep that data in--in that way.

And so, a lot of those principles that the FTC has put forward and frankly that a lot of good privacy-focused organizations around the world have put forward are--are being adopted by companies in--in--in the vacuum that's been created by the absence of comprehensive federal privacy legislation. And so the point is if Apple and Google are imposing minimum standards on the apps that are in their app stores, I would like to take a little bit of credit for the FTC, for the fact that, they are doing that that the Federal Trade Commission has long urged companies to bear more of the responsibility to not rely solely on consent when we know consumers can't possibly read all of the disclosure that--that they received their--their friend studies done that calculate the hundreds of thousands of hours it would take for a consumer to read every privacy policy for every website and every surveys that the visitor uses and it's a massive number of hours, hundreds of thousands of hours that it would take us.

Until we know consumers aren't reading it and part of a--part of the consequence of that is to say businesses need to be more accountable for risk assessment, risk management, having privacy policies in place, having vendor management principles in place so that if you give information to a third party like a researcher or a data broker, you are also asking them to be accountable for what they're doing with that data. And so maybe--maybe a bit of a long answer but--but I view those guidelines that get imposed as it's very welcome in--in the marketplace.

SHAPIRO: I have a couple of questions from anonymous about HIPAA, the Health Insurance Privacy Act. I don't know if Matthew you've come across that in your research on contact tracing policy. One says my neighbor has COVID. I feel they--I guess the government, the local government or someone should have informed me. But are they protected by the Constitution to keep that info private? Well, it's not the Constitution it's HIPPA. And so we have how does HIPAA factor into the contact tracing or privacy discussion? I mean, the Health and Human Services is charged with enforcing it but how do--do--do other agencies also get involved?

FEENEY: Yeah, I'm afraid I don't have as comprehensive an answer as the questioner might ask. I've spoken offline with a health policy director, Michael Cannon (PH) about HIPAA in other context and I know we did, or at least we're planning to do an event on a book called Big Brother in the operating room or in the hospital to get the exact title. But it's certainly true that look, that there's a lot of sensitive information about some people's health that is also about that but I don't want to claim to be a HIPAA expert. And so I'd rather encourage anyone with questions about HIPAA particular to follow the work of Michael Cannon and his colleagues because it's something that he's solely keeping an eye on.

SHAPIRO: Yeah, I--I--I'm a simple constitutional lawyer so don't know much about HIPAA.

WILSON: Okay. So I can--I can talk a little bit about HIPAA, Ilya. So HIPAA protector information--HIPAA protects information in the hands of medical providers; your--your doctor's office, your hospital. But it does not collect health information. It's collected by say a Fitbit that you wear on your wrist or by health apps that you use on your phone. And frankly, that's one of the gaps because of emerging technologies that I mentioned for--for yet another rationale for federal privacy legislation. And so there is a lot of information, a lot of health information that is collected now by devices and--and is not covered by the protections that HIPPA offers because that data is collected and stored outside of providers offices and hospitals and so on.

And so, if--the question is a good one but I think it also reminds us, there are exceptions for--for various reasons both under HIPAA and under, for example, children's privacy laws where for safety reasons, information may need to be disclosed. And so the CDC, the Centers for Disease Control has long had the right to get information about people who test positive for various diseases like tuberculosis. And--and so in certain circumstances, we cannot expect privacy about, you know, illnesses that we have or diseases that we're carrying because it is necessary to protect society.

And so COVID positive names were reported to the CDC under various state laws and I think even a federal law. And so that is--it's something that we expect in this kind of circumstance and maybe it fits into the special needs exception that you mentioned at the top of the hour, Ilya. And so--so again, there are tensions, there competing interest in privacy and the need for protecting the welfare of society. But--but HIPPA is--a HIPAA is an example of a place where we're seeing gaps emerge.

SHAPIRO: I had no idea that we had knowledge about HIPAA on this program. Fantastic. We have a question now from Facebook, Guinevere Liberty Nell (PH). I don't know if Liberty is her actual middle name or (INAUDIBLE) but either way terrific. And she asks could anyone private or public be held responsible for not enforcing social distancing or other rules if people get COVID-19 by way of recklessness whether by lawsuit or other means or are the only dangers being too harsh on liberties?

I'll take a first stab at that by way of directing this question more to my colleague Walter Olson who was on our first coronavirus in the Constitution series and he's been writing about potential problems with being sued if you do sue and if you don't if restaurant or another business takes measures or doesn't take measures. The liability issues are pretty tricky and that's why there's been a lot of debate in Congress, some question about whether Congress can change the rules for-for tort suits after all, for--for the country, whether it can preempts state law, there's that word again or whether this needs to be on a state-by-state basis.

But yeah, I mean this is that does open up if--if you went to a store and a week later, you have COVID, what do you have to prove? Can you sue that store in the first place? Even if the story ultimately wins, that's a lot of legal fees. What kind of precautions the store have to take and if it takes those precautions and you, the customer, or an employee still get sick, what does that mean?

These are all very good questions but it's--it's, you know--with not many answers right now, it's--we're kind of planning on--on an open playing field but--but as I said, Walter Olsen has written about this. Matthew or Christine, do you have anything on that?

FEENEY: I would only add that it strikes me as just very, very difficult to be able to show for sure that you definitely got ill from a particular person or a particular store. I mean, one of the difficult things about this virus is that you can have it for a while before exhibiting symptoms and you can catch it from people who aren't exhibiting symptoms. So that--that strikes me is a potential difficult barrier. But--but I, of course, defer to my colleague Walter Olson on anything to do with tort and liability.

SHAPIRO: All right, we have a question from Steve Dewey (PH) in Arlington Virginia right next door to where I am in--in Falls ChurchVirginia. He asks what kind of differences exists in state emergency decree-laws that is the some states have no emergency decree laws, some have laws for certain time periods, and have some state governors imposed emergency decrees that are both illegal and unconstitutional. I'll take that one.

Yeah, this is an issue of state law and I don't claim to have expertise over any States law really but each state has a different constitution, and states also, of course, have police power. That is the--the--the public officials in those states exercised certain powers that might not even be listed in the Constitution unlike what is in the Federal Constitution which is a finite list of all the powers that the federal government has.

Now, those state constitutions and related federal state statutes will have limitations or regulations about how those powers can be exercised, for how long, when the legislature has to get involved if you're exercising emergency powers. Of course, we're in an unusual type of emergency when you tick--think about the typical emergency weather a hurricane or a tornado, a natural disaster, whether a mass shooting. These things are short term by definition. They end in hours or days and so there's not much more of a question of these broader powers lasting indefinitely.

Well, we're now as I said in two the third month and there have been disputes including litigated in state courts about legislatures trying to override or end or sunset certain powers and courts ruling that certain powers indeed have sunset because there hasn't been legislative ratification, others continue. And that's a very I think healthy debate to be had.

Congress has passed obviously the PPP and other federal legislation. Certain states have done as well. So it's not that legislators can't meet at all. It's not like they've been bombed and they literally do not exist. So state constitution and state laws do impose certain kinds of restrictions. Of course, certain places, even if the legislature acts, the governor might veto that kind of restriction. So you do have attention.

In some cases, something that could be characterized as a state constitutional crisis but that's a very good question in these times. A question for commissioner Wilson. Can you give more details or examples of what companies employed contract contact tracing to track protesters in Minnesota or if indeed they did so? This is an urban myth based on this exaggerated statement by a police commissioner.

WILSON: (OFF-MIC) details other than what has been reported publicly. The--the gentleman in Minnesota used the word contact tracing and then I think tried to clarify what he said. But there are other examples reported or rumored on social media to be occurring. I don't know which specific contact tracing apps were deployed. But I think this is--this example highlights at least two or three issues. First of all, digital trust and it's one of the reasons that in the Washington Post survey that I mentioned, people are very worried about downloading these apps. Among other things there's just a lack of trust in--in big tech in whether our privacy will be protected.

Second of all, it shows that purpose limitations are important. We--we want limitations put on the uses to which data can be put once it's been collected from us. And so, if I download a contact tracing app for purposes of, you know, the altruistic purpose of protecting society, I don't want to be a spreader of coronavirus unwittingly, and so sure, I will let a company know that I have tested positive and--and--and for altruistic purposes, others can be notified if they come in contact with me. But I certainly don't want my information including my location information to be used for a variety of other purposes.

And third, I think it just highlights this connection between information that's collected for commercial purposes and information that ultimately gets used by the government. There is this inextricable link now because of the reasonable expectation of privacy test. And so, we're talking not only about Fourth Amendment but we're also talking about First Amendment. Right to free speech, right to assemble, free exercise of religion. Lots of civil liberties issues have popped up because of coronavirus and because of the national protests that we're seeing and--and the uses to which our data are put.

SHAPIRO: We have a couple of related questions about actions by private businesses or companies. can shops and restaurants require temperature checks or documentation of negative tests or contact information for later tracing? That is you make a restaurant reservation, you give all your information that's stored in a log query whether the government then looks at that log at some point or not. Do workplaces have the right to require this from employees? And relatedly, what about immunity certificates to board and fly airplanes?

What I'll just say about all of this is that if it's a rule put in by that private business, restaurant, shop, airline, well, they can put in pretty much whatever rules they want and you can decide then whether you want to go into that store or restaurant or fly that--that airline. It gets a little different if--if it's a government--becomes a government rule or regulation. But again it's--it's subject to that police power over which the--the challenges that we've discussed about, you know, for the last couple of months about restricting gatherings and closing businesses and shelter in place, and all the rest.

So if there's some justification for that kind of government regulation, then it could be allowed. Now, in terms of keeping people's information and having the government check that later, that runs into some problems with for example Supreme Court decision in a case called Patel versus city of Los Angeles where the Court struck down just the requirement that innkeepers, motel owners keep all these records that can be looked at by the police whenever they like without a warrant or--or anything else.

Here, the justification would presumably be stronger for contact tracing, maybe as long as the information is--is deleted or destroyed within two weeks, the incubation period of COVID or something like that perhaps a regulation like that could be drawn if there are other privacy protections. Matthew or Christine, anything on that?

FEENEY: I would only add that it seems like it wouldn't necessarily be--be required to gather this kind of information for most kind of customers. So the majority of people who are still going to restaurants are going to make the reservation online. Even if they do show up, there's a very good chance of using credit or debit card in order to pay. They'll be leaving digital footprints everywhere.

So it's not clear to me that if a state would really, really intent on tracking down people who were say at a restaurant in a certain time period that they would need some kind of special authorization or a new order or something like that. It seems to me that there's plenty of data already out there and mechanisms by which they could gather it. Now absent some kind of special new law that just allows them to get at wholesale or a special need. There might be some hurdles that would frustrate law enforcement but I don't think we should forget that there's already many ways for people to gather that kind of information.

SHAPIRO: Okay. Another question from--go ahead.

WILSON: I was just going to say from an FTC perspective there are principles again that would guide shopkeepers activities here. So for example, data minimization the identification where possible that sort of thing. And also, I would commend to the person who asked that question a very interesting, read again, Travis LeBlanc's letter to Acting Secretary Chad wolf. Travis sits on the privacy and civil liberties board and he was addressing the airline's proposed collection of health information from passengers. And--and he pointed out that that information could be both over-inclusive and under-inclusive.

There are many reasons that someone could be running a fever including just being in a state of education or being pregnant as opposed to having coronavirus. And then under-inclusive because we know many people with COVID-19 can be asymptomatic. And so he asked a host of questions about how the program would be implemented and about how the data would be used in a variety of implications. And so, I would commend the folks interested in this issue, I would commend that letter to you because he does--he does grapple with a lot of these issues.

SHAPIRO: We have two related questions from Facebook. Cynthia Figueroa asks it seems that never downloading the software is the only answer to avoid the contact tracing which would impact the use of the phone. Is the only answer to get a flip phone and then what if the federal government bans flip phones if they're being used to avoid tracking. A more technical a related question to that from Guinevere Liberty Nell.

The UK contact tracing app was supposed to be open source and was on GitHub but the updates to it have not been. New versions were added to the Apple App Store, etc. How does this affect the legality if the same thing happens in the United States?

FEENEY: I'm happy to take a stab at that. I would say that Google and Apple are private companies and if they mandate that some kind of contact tracing app is a necessary part of an update, it seems to me that there aren't that many difficult legal questions that--I'm not saying there are none necessarily but that'd be much easier.

Now, the government coming in and saying look to Google and Apple, you must impose or must have this app installed on your next update, that--that's a very, very different kind of question. It would seem to me that, Ilya would know more than me. But I don't think the government would do very well if they tried to ban an entire kind of phone for this purpose. Now, it's certainly true that look, if you are a Apple, Google user, and you're not happy with these--with these apps and you have privacy concerns, there are limited options if these companies decide to make the app download mandatory and sometimes maybe one way to do that.

But certainly, if it's a private company and they've decided this is in the best interest of their users, it strikes me as less legally troubling than the government coming in and mandating that private companies install certain technology.

WILSON: With respect to the privacy consequences of those apps that we've already seen one instance in which a contact tracing app inadvertently disclosed information to third parties after guaranteeing that the information would not be disclosed to third parties. And so there's a lot of opportunity for mistakes here. In terms of FTC enforcement, right now, a lot of our privacy enforcement in this area is based on our ability to get a deceptive active practices. And so, if an app promises in its privacy policy that information will be maintained in a certain way, it will be held secure, it will not be shared with third parties except under specifically identify--identifiable circumstances.

And then the information is shared in ways that controvert those promises. The FTC can go after the company for deceptive claims. We also have authority over unfair practices, although that's much more amorphous. And so, I would say that right now the FTC's authority with respect to enforcing any--any privacy issues for apps is--is--is too narrow and again federal privacy legislation could help us. But--but right now I can--I can guarantee that if you download an app and it promises, it will only use your information in a certain way and it violates that promise. That's an area where the FTC can get involved for a deceptive act.

SHAPIRO: We only have a couple of minutes left here's one question that probably goes to Christine again. Given that she displayed knowledge about HIPAA, maybe she knows something about this. This might be ERISA anyway. Jay Haynes from Twitter asks, early in the pandemic, my employer purported to require all employees to inform them if the employee or anyone in their family were diagnosed with coronavirus. That seems to be a step too far. Do you know, anything about that Christine?

WILSON: HIPAA yes, ERISA no. sorry.

SHAPIRO: Good. Well, I can only surmise that normally disclosing health, this might be a HIPAA thing. Anyway, employment laws of various kinds, disclosing employees health information to each other is probably normally a no-no but might be allowed to prevent the spread of conta--contagion or requiring employees to stay home, those kinds of rules, I'm sure that would be backed up. But again, I'm not an expert on ERISA or whatever the more specific law in this area might be.

Here's an interesting question. Again, going back to what Matthew was saying about the policy of contact testing, whether you do it digitally or the old-fashioned way. the problem with testing aside from false positives is that someone testing positive isn't necessarily contagious and someone testing negative isn't immune from contagion. Doesn't this make contact tracing meaningless?

FEENEY: I think it certainly calls into question how feasible is going to be to--to stop the spread and be part of the worry throughout all of this is that we're going to take a sledgehammer to a nail and that many people who shouldn't be are told to stay at home and to lock themselves down and the impact that could have on --on the economy in the long run. And potentially even people's health is something that we should all keep in mind.

But unfortunately, look that this as viruses is a tricky one. The asymptomatic is the--the length of time (INAUDIBLE) all different kinds of difficult issues and this gets back to what I was saying earlier which is as well as the legal issues we should also make sure to keep in mind the feasibility issues and the utility issues.

SHAPIRO: Okay. And with that, I'm afraid we'll have to close. Thanks very much to everyone for attending. We're sorry weren't--we weren't able to get to all the questions, there were quite a number. If you'd like to follow up with any of us, our--our twitter handles at least or on the event page and you can contact me or any of my Cato colleagues through our website as well. The video recording of the event will be available on the web page later today. And with that, thank you everyone, and have a good weekend.

urn:contentItem:5V6D-9181-JCBW-N25Y-00000-00Caution is watchword on Wall Street;James Dean looks ahead to the earnings season and what investors and the markets can expect2019-01-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 41Caution is watchword on Wall StreetJames Dean looks ahead to the earnings season and what investors and the markets can expectJames Dean

Wall Street was in a state of euphoria as summer turned to autumn last year. Even with President Trump embroiled in a trade war with China, the S&P 500 index, the best measure of the health of corporate America, hit an all-time high.

"Back in September, the sun was shining, the birds were chirping and if you listened hard enough you could hear the ice cream truck in the background," Tobias Levkovich, chief US equity strategist at Citigroup, said. "We had an idyllic scene: synchronised global recovery."

Then relations between America and China soured further, growth in Europe and emerging markets slowed, manufacturers showed signs of decline and the US Federal Reserve kept raising interest rates without signalling that an end was in sight. "Euphoria in September had turned to panic by late December and now we have a lot of storm clouds on the horizon," Mr Levkovich said. "We're going through an earnings reset at the moment and that can be painful. Some investors are worried about an earnings recession, where earnings go down even without an economic recession." This sets the tone for the coming earnings season in the United States, which gets going this week with fourth-quarter reports from JP Morgan, Goldman Sachs, Blackrock and other finance heavyweights. Research published last week by Morgan Stanley suggested that in mid-December investors were the most cautiously positioned in US finance stocks in five years.

Fourth-quarter profit numbers will be important, but Mr Levkovich is most interested in companies' guidance for the first quarter of 2019. "Given the uncertainties, I expect companies to be more conservative because it pays for them to play it that way," he said. "They're going to use that cringeworthy 'cautiously optimistic' tone. They might hide a couple of percentage points of growth in their pockets. They can blame it on China, the shutdown - anything."

The consensus among analysts is that fourth-quarter profits at S&P 500 companies rose by 10.7 per cent on average compared with the same period in 2017, weaker than the 15.9 per cent growth predicted at the start of October. It is also a marked slowdown from an average 25 per cent profit growth in the first three quarters of 2018, figures from Zacks Investment Research show.

As fourth-quarter profit growth forecasts have declined, so, too, have full-year 2019 forecasts: growth this year is expected to be 6.7 per cent on average among S&P 500 companies, down from a forecast of 9.7 per cent at the end of October.

Apple alarmed technology investors (and pretty much everybody else) as the year began with its first sales warning in 16 years. Earnings estimates for tech have been hit especially hard. As well as broader concerns for the market, Big Tech is suffering from the threat of greater regulation. The ten technology companies in the NYSE Fang+ index, which include Apple, Facebook, Google, Amazon and Netflix, together have lost about $812 billion in market capitalisation since the start of October last year. Only Tesla and Twitter have grown in value.

December's sell-off forced analysts to cut their forecasts for where the S&P 500 will end this year. Even so, most continue to believe that it will end the year higher than where it started. BMO Capital Markets sees the index hitting 3,000, a gain of nearly 20 per cent.

The American consumer remains strong, which is good news for the US economy, given that two thirds of it relies on consumption. Retail sales are in good shape in store and online, there are considerably more jobs than unemployed people (as has been the case since March last year), wages are rising and petrol prices are falling.

Outside manufacturing, the wider economy seems to be doing well, with December's jobs report, the most keenly watched of all economic indicators, coming in well ahead of expectations. Federal Reserve officials, not least Jerome Powell, the central bank's chairman, have made soothing noises of late about being "patient" with raising interest rates.

These are some of the factors behind Wall Street's recent rally, which pulled the index out of correction territory, defined as a drop of 10 per cent from its last peak. Not long after Christmas, the index was within touching distance of a bear market, down 20 per cent from its last peak. Maybe the sun will be shining and the birds chirping again by the time spring comes around.

Tim Cook, the Apple boss, issued an unexpected warning

urn:contentItem:5SGF-BTP1-JDJN-61K5-00000-00Cautious approach to innovation benefits HK2018-06-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCautious approach to innovation benefits HKPeter Liang

Critics say the city is 'falling behind' but a measured advance has spared us the fallout from such excesses as bicycle sharing and P2P lending, Peter Liang argues

Many people have lamented the failure of Hong Kong to catch up with the technology trends on the Chinese mainland and elsewhere.

Critics correctly point out that sharing economy, which touched the lives of countless millions of people in other economies, has yet to find a home in Hong Kong. That's not necessarily a bad thing. Hong Kong, at least, was spared the headache some other major cities — including Shanghai, Wuhan and Guangzhou — had in trying to find "graveyards" large enough to contain hundreds of thousands of bicycles discarded after the bicycle-sharing boom-bust.

Not too long ago, many financial gurus scolded the government for its reluctance to promote the so-called "P2P" (peer to peer) lending platforms in Hong Kong. They have kept their complaints largely to themselves since the collapse of the P2P market on the mainland, resulting in considerable losses to "lenders" using the now-defunct platforms.

It is a debacle Hong Kong can ill afford because of the predictable damage it can cause to its reputation as an international financial center. A former financial official once said he and his colleagues were vindicated for erring on the side of caution.

Indeed, the Hong Kong government and Hong Kong Monetary Authority have often been criticized for their overly conservative approach to financial innovation. This emphasis on the regulatory framework and institutional integrity is exactly Hong Kong's strength in fulfilling its expected role in the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area and other initiatives.

To be sure, Hong Kong enjoys other advantages, including excellent infrastructure, an efficient civil service and free access to information. But the greatest value it can bring to the table is expertise and experience to ensure orderly development which will not create new and bigger problems.

In the United States, for instance, big tech companies such as Apple, Amazon and Facebook can usually have their own way. Their monopolistic power and disruptive impact on various industries is largely seen as beneficial, or at least tolerated, because they are seen to have brought greater convenience and lower prices to many millions of consumers.

But when it comes to financial business, these technology behemoths will have to forge partnerships with established banks in offering their "innovative" services. That's because they don't see the benefit of going it alone, considering the high cost and complexity in complying with banking regulations.

Take electronic payment for example. Customers using that service usually have to put some money first into accounts with the service provider, who is, in effect, a deposit-taking company that is not regulated or supervised like those regular deposit-taking companies, mostly banks, by the regulator.

As such, customers of these electronic payment service providers are exposed to the risk that their money may not be managed with the level of prudence required of banks and regulated deposit-taking companies. It can be argued that such a risk is minimal when the service providers are the industry leaders sitting on big piles of cash. But it is important to note also that even some large banks required government bailouts to stay afloat after the outbreak of the credit crisis in 2008.

It can be expected that finance will be a major area of innovation in coming years. Fintech has the potential of letting the Chinese mainland quickly catch up with developed economies in the advancing financial services and markets.

The technological infrastructure and business know-how for fintech development are readily available. The hard part is drafting a regulatory framework and establishing enforcement capability to ensure things don't spin out of control, requiring corrective measures that are usually cumbersome, retroactive and counterproductive.

Hong Kong has vast experience in regulating complex financial systems and capital markets which withstood the onslaught of the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and, again, in the global credit crunch in 2008. The strength and resilience of its financial institutions in those testing times are testimony to the integrity of its regulatory environment.

That will be the key contribution Hong Kong can make to the mainland's drive for innovation in financial development.

The author is a current-affairs commentator.
