urn:contentItem:5940-JP81-DXH2-63PC-00000-00CAVUTO for August 12, 20132013-08-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCAVUTO8:00 PM ESTJennifer Stefano, Lenwood Brooks, Imogen Lloyd Webber, Ron Paul, Foster Friess, Gretchen Hamel, Chris Stirewalt, Gary B. Smith, Monica Mehta, Anahita Sedaghatfar, Zane TankelNEWSDomestic081201cb.223CAVUTO for August 12, 2013Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: Teed off, game on. Mainstream Republicans, watch out. Welcome, everybody. I am Neil Cavuto, and here is the good thing, that came out of this IRS scandal. It brought the Tea Party back to life, good bye Uncle Sam, Tea Parties across their country loaded for bear. And proving especially taxing the mainstream Republicans who all but hoped they had gone away, news flash they have not. And they are angry, not only at Democrats who dismissed them, but a Republican Party they say all but ignores them.

The same Republican Party, (inaudible) for a largely Tea Party recruits, help make John Boehner a speaker, now not letting him speak, and they say not letting him govern. So, this midterm contest, they are at it again, not only are anti-business Democrats in their sites, but businesses, usually Republicans even more in their sites, get ready. This time around, this is going to get very ugly. And this ticked off Tea partier says, better late than ever, with me now, Jennifer Stefano. Now, Jennifer you long argued that your problem was with the party that should have thanked you, guys, for putting them in the power in the House, but then sort of left them at the door?

JENNIFER STEFANO, TEA PARTY ACTIVIST: Right. Never before have I seen a group take their natural allies and turn them into their enemies. The fact is the message that the Tea Party delivered in 2010, where the idea that the government should listen to you, you have people in Washington that are for a limited government, for smaller, and empowering the individuals, that message sold, when they muddled (ph) us, ignored us all through 2012, you saw what happened, Neil. And the fact is, I don't care what you call me, call me a Tea partier, call me whatever you want, but it is the message, the principles and ideals that we're trying to deliver. And you know who is coming over to our side, Neil? It's moderate Democrats who are now furious with the Democratic Party for lying to them about Obamacare, that are now starting to work with us. To say, you know what? I don't like that none of these people did it, and the Republicans, they refuse to fight, so who can we trust? We can only trust ourselves, and I think you're going to see that personal momentum well up of individual coming out to fight. No matter what you call us. Tea Party, moderate Democrat, whatever.

CAVUTO: All right, mainstream Republicans call you dividers, as you know, and they point to Ronald Reagan and saying he'd rather get 80 percent of a loaf in a deal than no loaf at all, and he was famous for trying to move the ball forward to then Speaker Tip O'Neill. And trying to get some sort of a deal because stubbornness on other side doesn't necessarily -- things get done. What do you think of that?

STEFANO: Well, I think it depends on what 30 percent you are not doing, if you are selling out the President Obama's ideas on Obamacare or big government on extending regulation on shutting down coal and bankrupting people, bankrupting industry, then -- no, that is a 30 percent, I don't care what are those 70 percent you're with us on. These are things that cannot stand, you have to look at it from the perspective. The most people look at what is personal to them, right? What impacts me as a head of a working family or otherwise? And the Republicans are not in many areas standing up to fight that battle. Boehner should take those Tea Party freshman and do -- basically what Rand Paul does, what you see Ted Cruz is doing. Those words, those messages, they are resonating it. That ...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But they are not -- they're not resonating with the -- they are not resonating with the speaker, Jen. To that point, then, do you think John Boehner should be speaker?

STEFANO: Someone who cannot lead his people. And by the way, it is just not enough to manage inside Washington D.C. You have got to go out and speak to the people, and the fact of the matter is, the House has often not been able to properly address or to talk about why what they are doing matters to average people, and not to getting anything done. They could have put this president on offense 500 times, and by refusing to allow the group of people, like the Tea Party, the original Tea Party freshmen to really rise up and have a voice, like you are seeing in the Senate. I think you're really creating a situation where we're going to be set up to lose again. We cannot continue to fall back, because Barack Obama is denting policy that most Americans don't agree with, but we don't have a confident voice on the right in leadership or in a large position arguing that point. I think -- again, I point to the United States Senate, if you want to see, the future of the Republican Party, and, of course, to the grassroots, and it would be great, Neil, if we really focused on women, women are earning 60 percent of college degrees, they are continuing to be in industries that make the highest income.

CAVUTO: Sure.

STEFANO: I think the Republican Party has to (inaudible) and recruit women, to run profits, I think this is a very important point, and I hate gender politics, but man, I am never going to be sidelined by this women issue crap. Like I was back in 2012. That never will happen.

CAVUTO: By the way, Jen, speak your mind, I never know where you are coming from. But finally, to that point about reaching out the women. Is it by design or just coincidentally that I'm noticing in these latest Tea Party push, not much to talk about social issues, a lot of talk about, to your point, economic issues.

STEFANO: Sure, well, first of all, I think you can stand -- I mean I am pro-life and you can certainly talk about it, just talk about it like you are not insane and like you are a human being. And talk about it

CAVUTO: What does that mean? What does that mean?

STEFANO: Well, I think it means when you have guys like Todd Akins saying illegitimate rape, you just sound outrageous, the rape -- that's an outrageous thing to say. I think as a woman, most -- I have friends that are pro-choice, I have friends that have all done all sorts of things, but I can talk to them, and they can talk to me, and it is not a hysterical blood bath. I think Republicans have to learn how to be -- more outreaching. On the other hand, I think the economic issues are the more important ones, because number one, it's what most Republicans and most Americans, can you night around. As long as you explained them, why it matters to their lives as working families, and I think if you talk about spending and debt in these big aggregated term, we lose people, because the Democrats talk about people first, and Republicans and those of us on the right tend to talk percentages, and pie charts, we need to change that.

CAVUTO: Very well put.

STEFANO: We have to change the way we talk, and I'm telling you: get the women in there, more women to run for offers on the Republican ticket. And you will see success, I hate to say it, but Debbie Wasserman-Schultz was right. When women run, women win. And I'm no -- those pinko commie feminist Birkenstock wearers, I can't stand them. But I'm telling you ...

CAVUTO: They do win. More often than not, they do win.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Jen, it's always good having you.

STEFANO: They win.

CAVUTO: Thank you very much.

STEFANO: Thank you, Neil Cavuto.

CAVUTO: All right, so Foster Friess who feels Jen's fury. But urges caution the Tea Party is in general, not go too -- too far. Foster, we call the very rich guy, supported that largely giving up for political debt meet guy, Rick Santorum. Remember him? Until Rick gave Mitt more than a race than anyone thought. So, what is Foster up to now? And who is he putting his money on dough. He joins us, Foster, what do you make, first of all, what Jennifer just said.

FOSTER FRIESS, FRIESS ASSOCIATES FOUNDER: I think Jennifer is extremely wise in terms of Democrats talk to the heart and the emotions, we talk to the intellect and the brain. And when we talk about health care reform, if you talk about bloc granting medicated estates, or you talk about changing some of the tax code or, selling cross state lines, that is wonkish kind of a head talk, and so we have to talk about how do we help young people reduce their premiums, how do we make sure we create a safety net that allows people not to go into a spiral financially? So, she's right on there. However, I do believe we have a huge, huge opportunity of coming together with the establishment, Republicans, the Tea Party Republicans and the people formally on the left, and she said a lot of Democrats are upset, here we have James Hoffa, a head of a union siding with -- let's do something about Obamacare. The head of the IRS unions. As I like my health care just the way it is. And Neil, I have to tell you a little story that kind of ties in about the young kid runs his car in the ditch, buries it up to the half-(inaudible) in mud, and he calls a farmer over and puts a big horse on it. Pulls (inaudible), nothing happens, pulls Tom, nothing happens, pull Bill, nothing happens. And the farmer says, pull Homer, pulls him out just sleek as it could be. The young kid says, how come you have to call your horse four names before doing it? Well, you see son, Homer's blind. If he saw there's only he wouldn't give a damn.

(LAUGHTER)

FRIESS: So I think that's why -- that's where we are.

CAVUTO: But, you know, a lot of people criticize Republicans to a horse, but usually the other end of the horse.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: And they say that, say because Republicans have a habit of nabbing the feet from what look like the jaws of victory, and they say that because they end up going far afield from what makes their message alluring, and that is the economic message. That you believe into the -- alluded to at the time Rick Santorum was running. But then you get caught up in either social issues or as Jennifer Stefano said the crazies who then all of a sudden become the face of the party, and it's not an accurate face, do you agree with that?

FRIESS: Well, I agree that the left likes to pick out the worst spokesman.

CAVUTO: Absolutely.

FRIESS: And that is why it makes me nervous that you picked me. Because maybe they want to see me on TV.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Well, how would you combat that? I mean you are a savvy businessman, you are a good value investor, that's, obviously, you got your money and also you know something about seeing diamonds in the rough, right now things are rough for Republicans, how do they improve their image with all people? That their party reaches out back to those Ronald Reagan days? To all Americans.

FRIESS: It is so simple, Neil. It is so simple. All you have to do is take one rifle shot, for example, rather than talk about defunding Obamacare, delaying, postponing, all that we have to do is let's ask President Obama to treat the little guy as fairly as he treats the big corporation, so he gave the corporations a relief from their mandate, although the Republican have to do is now insist he does the same thing for the little guy, and keep it on that issue. And I don't think it makes sense to defund Obamacare, I think instead, what we want to do is reschedule the implementation of the mandates, so that the young -- the little guy can have a better chance to look what is in store for him, and the young people still favor Obamacare, and they are the ones that going to be hurt the most.

CAVUTO: So, you would be against, Foster this effort of Ted Cruz and other to defund it, that it would a waste of time?

FRIESS: Well, I think their intentions are good. And any of other people who want to repeal, and that's good. So, we -- everybody knows we have to get rid of it, that's the given. The trick is, what is the best way of doing it, and I suggest the best way of doing it, is just have a rifle shot, and just say, let's treat the employee, equal to how we're treating employer, give him a one year hiatus, don't spend all this money on ...

(CROSSTALK)

FRIESS: $50 million is going to be spend on advertising, which is going to go to advertising firms headed by Obama's donors. So, I think if we just asked for that one stall, not a stall, but a rescheduling, I think we can all come together. Establishment ...

CAVUTO: Got you.

FRIESS: Tea Party, Democrats we're all in this together. And that's what's exciting about what I see happening.

CAVUTO: Well, who are you pushing for -- I'm sorry to rush you there. Who are you pushing in 2016?

FRIESS: Well, I've told folks I'm still think Santorum is wisest of the group.

CAVUTO: Oh, really? So, he runs again, he's got your backing.

FRIESS: Well, he was -- he was talking in Iowa the other day about -- we talked about the job creators, why we talked about the job holders. I became wealthy not because of my acumen, but 70 people that are around me, and if it were not for them I would not be sitting in this chair, so I think the main thing we have to be sensitive to that hotel clerk that checks us in at 2:00 A.M. in the morning, the skycap that gets us on that plane at 5:00 in the morning, they get up at four. Those are people who make our country work. And I think Republicans care about them, and that is why they want to get rid of this Obamacare, which is going to be destructive to these people. So, I think, we just don't need to change our taxes, we just need to take our message, and Santorum's message, it's the beautiful one. Let's look out for the job holder.

CAVUTO: Foster Friess, it's always a pleasure. Thank you.

CAVUTO: Thanks, Neil.

CAVUTO: Meanwhile, talk about perfect timing, as libertarians are about to take off, the Ron Paul channel turns on.

CAVUTO: OK, then quick, what is the difference between Glenn Beck and Ron Paul? What if I told you nothing? At least on the Internet. Because one is already a big star there, and the other is about to become one. Because the Ron Paul channel is online and like (inaudible) is firing a lot of folks up. Paul says, 200,000 potential subscribers have expressed interest in paying upwards of $9.95 a month, for a channel, the former presidential candidate says, we'll give it folks straight every day. He is here to tell me also about a feature that promotes itself urging you first turn your TV off.

All right, Congressman, that is where you lose me -- particularly. Not a good, not a good strategy going forward. But nevertheless, because I admire you greatly. I'll let you come for this one last appearance, but I'm joking, but what's the -- what's the idea behind us?

FMR. REP. RON PAUL (R-TX): Well, the whole idea for me to have the ability to continue to do what I've been doing for 35 years, and that's talk about issues that you've helped me talk about many times over the years. And to bring it to the attention of as many people as possible. And there are some frustrations, you know, with regular TV, I don't have a job on regular TV. I don't want to live in New York, or Washington or L.A., but I can do this from my hometown -- I can talk to people, but it takes a big step, it takes a lot of help, it's much more complicated than I ever dream, and so it's really worked very well for me, although we're at beginning stages, as a matter of fact, just within the hours, I released that the burger M. is now available. So, it is you -- you have timed it very well. And although we go after TV, I will always turn to Cavuto when I want to hear the real (inaudible)

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: You -- I have to tell you, young man. You dare go after us, and then it's worked. But having said that, I'm curious, would this be then more like a libertarian channel congressman. How would you describe it?

PAUL: Well, it's going to not promote the ideas I disagree with. And most people have a pretty good sense of what I believe in. SEDAGHATFAR: I mean if you are an employee on the phone how will you be inspired to do well when your employer really does not care.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I just keep thinking, but Mr. Spacely! Anyway, it's too late for that, thanks for watching.

urn:contentItem:596B-5JD1-DXH2-61D4-00000-00CAVUTO for August 23, 20132013-08-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCAVUTO8:00 PM ESTTJ Rodgers, Adam Lashinsky, Regis Philbin, Keith Fitz-Gerald, Gary B. SmithNEWSDomestic082301cb.223CAVUTO for August 23, 2013Neil Cavuto, Lizzy MacDonald, Dennis Kucinich

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: A House speaker taking a pass on defunding Obamacare. A police force to monitor companies and whether they are complying with Obamacare. Navigating to push and coax Americans into Obamacare. And NSA now capable of retreating 75 percent of all Internet traffic. And IRS still -- still going after tax exempt groups. A Justice Department still intimidating Americans, now suing Texas over its voter I.D. law. A president bypassing Congress to push a cell phone tax to pay for Internet in all schools. A Senate majority leader determined to up the spending, period. And scores of cities and states equally determined to dramatically up the minimum wage. All this week. All this week. And it's got me feeling well, very weak. So much big government firing on so many fronts that it amazes me Republicans have all but raised the white flag. The speakers taking a pass by proposing a punt. We will get into that later.

The reality right now. The air of big government -- well it is back with a vengeance. And doesn't give a damn how much you complain.

Welcome, everybody, I am Neil Cavuto. And that's pretty much where we stand. We don't stand a chance. Because now we have a Congress that doesn't only take a pass on spending, but a president who's bypassing them altogether when it comes to taxing. The fallout for you is startling. The fallout for your boss, numbing. A big on here with me right now, and he's worried like never before -- about government encroachment. He warned us it would get out of control, and now officially is. A tech guy, a fed-up (ph) guy.

Going along with me tonight, because his temper is kind of short tonight. With me now, Cypress semiconductor CEO, T.J. Rodgers. T.J., always good having you. But man, I mean you were kind of like a high-tech Nostradamus, you saw a lot of this coming. But it's here, and what's a little scary, T.J., is it's accelerating. It is not slowing, it's actually accelerating. What do you make of all of this?

T.J. RODGERS, CYPRESS SEMICONDUCTORS FOUNDER & CEO: Well, I see the, you know, the government trying to take over bigger and bigger part of the economy. That litany you just gave -- it sounds like we need, you know, radio "Free Europe" -- written out and called radio "Free America." You know, the thing I'm worried about right now is jobs, the unemployment is still high. It is persistent. We have been doing the standard low interest rates and pump the economy thing, the depressing method -- for years now, it hasn't worked. And now we're talking about taxing the rich to pay their, quote, fair share, unquote. The thinking I did about it was that if we actually did raise taxes on the rich, right now the top five percent pay 58 percent of all taxes, I think that's already confiscatory, but leave that alone. If we take more money. The question is will that money create more jobs, and to me that's the big lie. I looked at what it cost small business to create a job, I have a small business in Wisconsin, it costs me $18,000 per job to create 65 jobs. The average in America for small businesses is $30,000 a job. It costs the government a million dollars a job in these stimulus programs to create a job. So, if you tax a million dollars out of the private economy, you lose, you know, 50 jobs, some number like that, and you create one job. And they keep saying, let's tax the rich guys in order to create jobs. And they don't count the fact that when they take money from the wealthy, that money comes out of investment, which is done by better, by better experts that are in the government. And the jobs lost on the private economy overwhelmed by a factor the jobs gained by the government.

CAVUTO: And what job gains, would you see, as you know, better than they, have been part-time. In fact, that is the trend. An unprecedented sort of a development in American history here. The health care law has a lot to do with that, that's not exclusively the reason. But obviously, big bosses like yourself are leery, and they are hedging their bets. How long do they hedge?

RODGERS: As long as it takes. You know, right now people say, companies are sitting on profit. And, of course, we are. You know, when you hire somebody, in effect it's like for CEOs, it's like having a kid. You're going to pour concrete, you're going to hire people, you're going to give them a stock option, five years duration. You're going to make plans for the future, you're going to create a product that will take you a couple of years to make. And if you don't feel the economy is going to be stable, level playing field for the next -- just a steady playing field for the next few years, you just don't do it. You sit back and wait. And you know, the litany you just read off, an idea a day out of Washington, all of which could change the viability of the business, means you just sit and wait until we get a president who will just run a stable country.

CAVUTO: What do you think of what Speaker Boehner is doing in the meantime? His critics say he is taking a pass, others are more pragmatic and say, they're just trying to keep the ball moving. But another temporary extension to sort of get us over the next hump, like so many others we have seen before. And that rattles some in corporate America, as we never get to the core of our problems, we just keep kicking the proverbial can down the road. What are your thoughts?

RODGERS: Oh, I have mixed feelings on that. Anytime you leave money with private individuals by not taxing them, you're better off. So, we have sequestering of funds, we're not spending as much. Guess what? I didn't notice the thing, you know, nothing I care about changed with this sequestering. So, in one way, I like the government getting smaller and maybe it will learn how to get smaller, maybe people understand it doesn't need to be as big as ...

CAVUTO: But do you think he is leading the effort on that regard or he is losing an opportunity to spearhead these issues?

RODGERS: He's losing an opportunity to spearhead -- I'm not sure, right now, if Americans are willing to listen. You know, we're in the summer. People just don't want to hear more squabbling ...

CAVUTO: Yeah.

RODGERS: (inaudible) Even for ... Two presidencies, we've been listening to partisan bickering. People are getting kind of tired of it. We need to solve the problem. I think if we had a balance budget amendment and like cities and states they have today. If you don't have, you can't spend it, you can't print money, you can't borrow money. That would be -- that would be a big step forward. That would be a fundamental root cause solution to the problem.

CAVUTO: But it will do anything to gate (ph) what was planned to be a number of rallies over the next week, T.J., with folks demanding a doubling on a minimum wage, helped and propelled by unions, I'm sure, eager for new members. What do you think of that?

RODGERS: Well, I've always felt it was hypocritical. Either ignorant or hypocritical, on the minimum wage. I mean we all like to feel that if somebody's willing to work, that they're going to be taken care of, and the minimum wage -- they're going to be -- you know, they are at least going to be able to live right, but the fact is, what really happens in the real economy, like it or not, the minute you raise the wage to a higher level, the people below that are going to be unemployed. You're going to take people out of employment and put them on welfare, and they're going to be worse off. And then you're going to brag, that I'm -- I'm the great altruist, they're taking of the people, I've raised their wage. But the fact is, you put a bunch of people out of work. I've always felt that it's hypocritical -- at best ignorant economically, ignorant move to make, but it's -- I've been listening to the argument, talking to myself about it for 40 years, and not going to change.

CAVUTO: Now, Wall Street, it's gyration, notwithstanding (inaudible) and then NASDAQ shot down and the rest. It has been kind of doing OK, with all the bumps still, what the Dow is still up about 13 to 14 percent. NASDAQ doing nicely. D you think it's missing something or is it just now grasping?

RODGERS: No, I think there is a reason the business is doing OK. One of the things you learn in business, is if you focus on something and do it right, you win. And then once you win, you get convinced that if you do more and more and more, that you'll win out on bigger scale.

You know, I think when business decided to hunker down, take the people a have (ph), and run the company right, that was -- that made some strategies better. Point one. Point two, our dollar is not worth what it used to be. You know, where the New Mexico? It's a good place to manufacturing. Or manufacturing companies could become more competitive. So smaller -- not smaller, but more conservative companies hunkering down. And -- and devalue dollar, are making for a reasonable climate. No growth, lousy unemployment but a reasonable climate for business right now.

CAVUTO: T.J., you're great. All we talk. You want to take a peek of young man and maybe consider running for office, but I guess you've had before. But T.J, thank you very, very much.

RODGERS: You're welcome.

CAVUTO: All right, will here is how scary this big government thing really is getting. A prominent liberal is saying stop. Why Dennis at the NFA is a menace? And not only it needs the and besets (ph). It needs to no longer exist.

Then look the ESPN. Fox is a secret weapon. Rodgers, Fox Sports one. Looking to be number one. (ph) And the love king -- that's the tycoon there.

CAVUTO: Well, Dennis Kucinich has had enough of big government. Well, not really, but when it comes to the NSA, actually, yeah, really. Because the former Democratic congressman and presidential candidate has heard more than enough about the agency's surveillance abuses and reprimands to say nothing of its constant overreach. So, he wants to reach for the stop button. And not only cut the agency's funding. How about cut the agency altogether? Dennis, congressman, do I have that right?

FMR. REP. DENNIS KUCINICH (D-OH): You do. And if you look at the Declaration of Independence, it said very clearly that when a government becomes disrespectful of the aims of a democracy or of our country, that we have the right to alter or abolish it. The NSA has clearly violated the Constitution, violated the laws of the land by broken trust, damaged the right to privacy. It has to go.

CAVUTO: You sound like a libertarian, Congressman.

KUCINICH: Well, I am. I am someone who believes in liberty and freedom and we cannot let this unholy marriage between big Internet corporations and big government cause our right to privacy to become polarized, and if we don't have a backlash from the American people who connect with the deeper principles of our Constitution, we're looking at losing not only the right to privacy, but losing a whole chain of freedoms that are connected with it.

CAVUTO: Congressman, do you think the president, then, lied, when he said there's not domestic surveillance going on in this country or he didn't know?

KUCINICH: Well, either scenario is pretty distressing. And one thing for sure: when we see that this agency, the NSA has unashamedly lied to the FISA court, repeatedly lied to Congress and either lied to the White House or is complicit with them, the agency has to go. There are plenty of intelligence agencies that can take up the slack, but the message has to be this: if you violate the Constitution, you violate American's right to privacy, you turn America to something that it's not, you're out of here.

CAVUTO: So, you don't buy the notion this is being done to keep us safe?

KUCINICH: We have to be protected from the NSA now. And this whole idea of -- they've created a protection record, it's the electronic protection record in the 21st century, analogous to the other kind of protection records that were run in the '30s, the '40s and '50s in this country, where people would go around and say, you've got a nice place, so you want to keep it that way. No, we've got to eliminate any kind of force within our government that is repeatedly violating the Constitution or otherwise we're going to lose our country, we're losing the sense of what it means to be an American now. If we get government, and we just -- we are -- government just turns rogue or an agency turns rogue, repeatedly violates the Constitution, annihilates or polarizes the right to privacy. You know, this whole idea of personhood, privacy is a spiritual space as well. Government has no right in that area, and yet we have seen the violations by the tens of thousands every year according to the FISA Court, by NSA. Neil, frankly, this cannot be tolerated and it needs to be the highest standards applied here. And I think the ultimate punishment, which is -- you are done.

CAVUTO: That is very well put, Congressman. Thank you very much/

KUCINICH: Thank you.

CAVUTO: Dennis Kucinich.

Is it time for the man with the pen to just walk into the sunset? Why something the speaker wants to do has some Tea Partiers ready to throw him overboard.

CAVUTO: Tonight's Clash -- time for Boehner to bolt? Growing anger now among a lot of conservative House members over John Boehner's push for a short-term budget bill to keep the government kind of limping along for another couple of months. It is the speaker's way of avoiding a government shutdown, but it's gotten some very angry House colleagues wondering whether the speaker should just step down. Should he?

Lizzy MacDonald says after so many punts, she is not surprised some of his members want to give their speaker the boot. Adam Lashinsky says calm down, the man is just trying to make everyone happy. Lizzy, you kind of say that that is a problem.

LIZ MACDONALD, FBN: Yes, I don't think they should compromise. Listen, they should not shut the government down, though. That is a really bad move. They will get blamed for it. They will basically not be able to fund the military, the FBI.

CAVUTO: This is what Boehner was saying, right?

MACDONALD: I don't think they shut the government down at all. They did it in '91 and '95. The GOP got blamed for it. By the way, they only have 45 votes in the Senate, so they can't get that done.

The thing that I'm talking about is hold their feet to the fire about the sequester. It worked. Even the government union is saying, yes, we found places to cut the fat (inaudible) through the government. We did not have to do the furloughs that they expected. It was successful.

CAVUTO: Do you think then the speaker should go or not?

MACDONALD: I don't know if he should go. I'm just saying he should just hold their feet to the fire and not be so ready to bend and compromise during this coming costume drama of the debt ceiling fight that is coming up.

CAVUTO: Adam, is he now running into the buzzsaw we already knew was there, and now he's going to pay dearly?

ADAM LASHINKY, FORTUNE MAGAZINE: Actually, I think not. Boehner is doing what passes for statesmanship right now in Washington. He's actually behaving responsibly.

CAVUTO: How is that statesmanship if we keep, you know, I understand what you're saying, but there is always a bump-along, temporary measure, temporary measure, temporary measure, just to keep us going.

LASHINSKY: It is far from ideal. But a temporary measure to avoid a shutdown, which would be bad for the country and bad for his own party, it is, you know, as I said, I hedge my language, Neil. It is the closest we can come to statesmanship right now. He is in a difficult negotiation with both the administration, and his own party, his own base in the House of Representatives. I see a man who's doing his best and I applaud him for doing his best. I'd much rather have him doing that than then elect a leader who would accede to their wishes and wreak havoc on the country in a completely irresponsible way.

CAVUTO: Well, whether you guys are right or wrong, he's gone, I think he's gone. I think (inaudible) enough--

MACDONALD: And by the way, the Democrats are about to wreak havoc on the country, wanting to raise taxes yet again. I mean, enough already. Do the right thing by the American people and stop hitting us in our wallets and take care of your own fiscal house first.

CAVUTO: Yes, leave us alone.

LASHINSKY: Neil, I am probably going to be wrong with what I say, because I've never see you be wrong on tactical political issues. I think he survives for the same reason that he has survived so far. Because he is trying to do this balancing act. And --

(CROSSTALK)

LASHINSKY: -- neither side in his own party wants to fire him.

CAVUTO: He could provide cover for them, I've heard that argument as well.

Our second clash, guys, is this. Would you still own bank stocks? If you knew the government was never, ever, ever going to rescue them again, ever? But Moody's is threatening to downgrade a bunch of them. Convinced the White House means what it says, when it says it will not bail them out if they ever get in trouble again. I think that could be the ratings agency's way of kind of stating the obvious. So for investors, take away the training wheels, would you still ride this bank bike? Lizzy, are bank stocks by definition a riskier investment if you take out the argument the government won't be there when everything hits the fan?

MACDONALD: Yes, they are. Just look at the big guys, I mean, look at Citigroup. They are still struggling. They still have a massive exposure to bad mortgage assets, and a lot of the bank balance sheets are improving because the Fed has been helping them out with the housing recovery by keeping rates down.

I mean, I will tell you something, this whole thing about bailing out banks is so bad. We should not have started on this process. It worked for a very long time by merging healthy banks with sick banks. The problem is when you have bailouts, and why have this massive regulatory scheme. It sort of undoes that whole rule-making agenda if you're going to bail them out anyway.

CAVUTO: So take the training wheels off, but without that guarantee, I know your views on rescues, you would not be looking at things.

MACDONALD: The reason why they do it is because the banks are the biggest buyers of government bonds.

CAVUTO: Exactly, no, no, exactly. So, Adam, that is essentially what Moody's -- I am way oversimplifying, and maybe too much so. But they are saying take that sort of factor out of the equation, you know, bank stocks lose a lot of their appeal. What do you make of that?

LASHINSKY: I think there is a ray of hope here. Yes, they lose their appeal, but that -- from an investor perspective, that is concerning. From a sort of national, from the stability of the financial perspective, this is really good news, because with Dodd-Frank, we are going to instead of bailing them out, we are going to wind them down. So if your bank that you invested in behaves badly, you will in fact--

CAVUTO: Do you really believe that, though, Adam? I always think with everything, when push comes to shove -- and I agree, that would be the logical approach, what you're advocating. But I think everyone gets scared, there is a meltdown coming, they fear it's going to be oh my God, Katie bar the door, and they scramble to the rescue.

LASHINSKY: I think we are making steps in the right direction. Lizzy glossed over this, but the leverage ratios are down, the balance sheets are better. This is partly for the reasons she said. Also because again, the regulators are forcing them to improve their balance sheets. This is all relatively good news. I'm not saying let's start doing cartwheels. They are de-risked so that Moody's can make this observation that they won't necessarily be safe.

MACDONALD: I'm not glossing over that. Listen, when you are trading- -

CAVUTO: I knew that was going to start fire.

MACDONALD: When you are trading at only one times book value, that means you are really--

CAVUTO: Don't even get me going on book value.

MACDONALD: Don't even get me going on book value. But I'll tell you something, they are so inefficient, so huge and dangerous and not transparent, these big guys, the way they are running their balance sheets. I'm not liking this too big to fail regime.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: You just had your ATM (inaudible) disconnected. Guys, thank you really, both, very, very much. Have a great weekend.

Meanwhile, you think ESPN is unbeatable on the cable sports front? I think they used to say that same thing about CNN 17 years ago on the cable news front. Fox News, of course, had a guy named Roger. Fox Sports has an equally cunning star. And his name is Regis!

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REGIS PHILBIN: Google my name, you get 7 million results. Walk Hollywood Boulevard and look down, there's Regis again! You want an Emmy? Take one of mine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Well, the professional football season hasn't even started. And we are getting word that ads for next year's Super Bowl are almost completely sold out. What the Fox? Well, it must be Fox, right? Which would be broadcasting the big game, of course, and it must be a very good omen for my next guest, because Fox's big time in the cable sports game. That's right, ESPN, start getting rattled, because Regis is rumbling. Regis Philbin, the star of Fox Sports One and a very friendly face behind Rupert Murdoch's latest plan to take over the universe. Regis, very good to have you.

PHILBIN: Thank you. That's about it, too.

CAVUTO: Yes, that is it. You are on a mission from God.

PHILBIN: That's right.

CAVUTO: What made you do this? You've done everything else.

PHILBIN: Well, I was out for a year and a half, and a friend of mine had an idea about a once a week show that we used to do years ago in LA. And so he took it to Eric Shanks (ph), one of your top guys, and the more they talked about it, the more Shanks became interested. They both flew to New York, we spent some time, and Shanks was more interested in the sports network that was starting here on Fox.

CAVUTO: But you, you say you are not a sports guy, although you're quite good at this. But what made you do it? It's certainly different.

PHILBIN: It is different. Yes. I've always loved sports. And there were times when, in my career over the year, I had a little sports show here and there.

CAVUTO: Oh, you did stuff before Fox Sports One?

PHILBIN: Yes, yes. And enjoyed it very much. And then would always talk about sports on my talk show with my co-host, who she wouldn't -- either one of them would never listen to me.

(LAUGHTER)

PHILBIN: -- would say what--

(LAUGHTER)

PHILBIN: Is he talking about sports? What?

CAVUTO: But I am wondering, you know, you joked about it yourself, an 81-year-old guy, reaching to the 18-to-49 demo. What do you think of that?

PHILBIN: I think it can be done. I'm hoping it can be done. I am going to do things like you know, instead of just athletes, we've got to have some entertainers in there as well. We got a guy coming up next Wednesday on the show, Bill Cosby, who played defensive back for Temple University. In the last couple of years I'm looking at Temple University and they are growing into a pretty good football machine. So all of a sudden on my Notre Dame schedule this year, it's Temple. The first game we played. So Cosby knew about it too. I said you got to get Bill Cosby on the show. He flew down to Philadelphia give the Temple team a pep talk.

CAVUTO: You have a pretty impressive role. So does it bother you? You just move on?

PHILBIN: No, I haven't heard that yet. I mean, people are interested in seeing how we will approach it. And what we are going to offer. That is what we are doing all week.

CAVUTO: There a lot of connections already. But I notice that it's bigger on your personality. Was that by design? Is going to be different? Sports and events that define it, is this about the personality?

PHILBIN: I must tell you. I really didn't expect to be working with five other people. But they have some interesting people in there. They have a great big football player from the Baltimore Ravens and the Denver Broncos, 14 years in the NFL, two Super Bowls, just a terrific guy, Trevor Price, big defensive --

CAVUTO: Anyone you hate, you think it's going to problem?

PHILBIN: No. There's a guy who wants to be a comedian. He is a former tennis pro. There's Jason Gay from the "Wall Street Journal." They flew in a gal named Georgie Thompson from England who is into soccer. Do you know much about soccer?

CAVUTO: It's a sport where you kick the ball.

PHILBIN: It's going to be the biggest deal in the world the way it looks.

CAVUTO: It's interesting in this country it's big with our kids when they are young and then it falls away.

PHILBIN: You're absolutely right. They are in the schoolyard. They are playing soccer. And you got around New York City. They are playing soccer. We talk about soccer every day.

CAVUTO: You are a nice guy. Usually people who survive just have an evil quality to them. You just love what you do.

PHILBIN: Thank you very much. I just love television. They checked me out very carefully, but it worked out really well. But I just never thought a million years when I was at Notre Dame that I would be offered any broadcaster radio. Then I was in the service and I would look at television and I would say, gosh, that looks like fun.

But what can I do? I don't have a broadcasting voice come I don't have any talent. Two tough guys, they went in as private because they were honored when on the battlefields. But anyway, the guy said to me, what you want to do in your life, now that you are leaving.

And I look at these people on TV and it is like, don't you know that you can have anything you want in this life. You've only got one chance. Now do you want it and I said, I just -- I don't know and he said, I said do you want to? And I said, yes, sir. It's the first time I said that.

One of my producers for Mike Douglas went out and had a job that they had, Little Roger.

CAVUTO: Everyone is getting ready with musical chairs.

PHILBIN: I just don't know. You know, I'm surprised that NBC is letting Jay Leno go. I guess they are looking for the young audience. I can't answer that question. I followed you for years. I want to know Neil Cavuto. How is Apple going to do next six months?

CAVUTO: We will talk after the show. I don't give this stuff out for free.

PHILBIN: You are hilarious. I watched you for years talked about this. I need help. Anyway, what else you got?

CAVUTO: I look at the landscape. He seemed to be always up front, everyone going on around you. But what do you like to watch?

PHILBIN: I'm watching sports, to tell you the truth, because it's really important.

CAVUTO: I could be wrong. It could be an inner passion of yours.

PHILBIN: I mean, to see those guys battle it out. They're trying to bring boxing back and we have him on as well. We have those who are bringing the boxing writer, bringing the right spots. People love to see it, you know?

CAVUTO: You guys are hooking your wagon to this.

PHILBIN: Please don't forget soccer.

CAVUTO: Is that enough? You need to do stuff like more college football? You know, to get this other kind of stuff that won't give up?

PHILBIN: I think that they are slowly moving into that area. Fox has looked at that. Fox did get the chance to play at Stanford.

CAVUTO: He came out with a bang. It is not too shabby.

PHILBIN: I think that's just great.

CAVUTO: And income at the time they were rich when they were CEOs. Do you pay much attention to politics?

PHILBIN: I really don't get into that very much.

CAVUTO: In the old days it was every bit as heated.

PHILBIN: I think that they were more genteel with the people. I started in San Diego. Richard Nixon.

CAVUTO: You know what did you think of him?

PHILBIN: Well, I said to him that I had a piano the end I heard about you playing the piano. And I thought, let's go. He played the piano forums and he was pretty good. We had a lot of laughs. Somehow I got into him and so that he became a terrific guest. Years later I ran into a guy named Paul Keys. And you know, he said, wow, I love being with that guy. And I really felt good about it.

CAVUTO: It seems like it would be really important. Some may have a type that and it would break down things with you. But we were doing a lot of these specials, leading up to the dreaded fascination, and here is how different kinds of work. In the interview John Kennedy says can we review a couple of these questions, and they allowed it. They allowed it. It goes along in a few, but that was a different time. For the president said if we did it again, we were doing.

PHILBIN: I think it's going to be very honest. He's beginning out there and taking it for whatever it is. It's a tense interview? Who have now come another day? But he is quite a guy.

CAVUTO: When you look at just the TV message, that young people today, my daughter for example, I think everything is on that. Rupert Murdoch says that this is just how it is and transported and is it the same with I.T.?

PHILBIN: I don't have one of those devices. I really don't. So what is going on? Everyone is talking about little thing and it's kind of scary. What we have on the show is girl from Boston who was into the situation. Who is inside the internet? We go on and what is the latest on what is going on. We're covering ourselves. One of them is going to happen, I'm sure.

CAVUTO: What have you done with all of your dollars?

PHILBIN: Well, I have about six kids and I have about 13 more at Notre Dame. The scholarship thing is incredible. It really is. So that is what I am doing.

CAVUTO: A great accomplishment, a great fortune. They just want to have a blast and travel the world.

PHILBIN: I have a nice house in Connecticut.

CAVUTO: You just sold one in Connecticut, didn't you?

PHILBIN: Yes and I brought another one. I'm answering all your questions. Tell me about Apple, Apple up or down?

CAVUTO: Could you see yourself doing what the network talk show? I look at all these things come in the big names come and they are good. Not blowing smoke, I think and two of the best interviewers out there. I think people of all ages clearly love you. And I think a lot of these guys are across the board with al groups. Do you ever want that? Without getting in the mix with these guys?

PHILBIN: I don't think so. I think the age factor would stop.

CAVUTO: The older you got come in with young people accepted.

PHILBIN: Thank you very much, I agree with you. Why don't you how many? Let's call river right now you get him on the phone.

CAVUTO: You look at this as a long-term effort? My first contract went to eat. That was here at Fox. And we had the other entries here.

PHILBIN: When he left have to make that decision. Did you know it was going to be week to week?

CAVUTO: It was actually thought it was a full hearted mission. But it is tough when you go against the grain and everyone says oh, in your case, ESPN is the dominant player, good luck. Good luck with this news channel that you will dominate. It's amazing how much it can seem to be wrong.

PHILBIN: Well, I don't know. They seem to keep going. They have hit this and they're running forward. I think age has a lot to do with it. I don't know anyone my age, but is still having this. I think it's a great bottom line.

CAVUTO: Best of luck to you.

PHILBIN: Tell me about Apple.

CAVUTO: If you are going to talk about this comment might be like Carl Icahn. Regis, thank you, you are the best. In the meanwhile, I hope that this has nothing to do with the CEO of Microsoft announcing that he might be leaving in the year. I think we just put them up-to-date. It is kind been downhill.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROBERT GRAIFELD, NASDAQ CEO: We were deeply disappointed with what happened yesterday. We did become live quite successfully and finished the day in normal course of business.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: All right, someone find me a body language expert. I am not buying it. A whole bunch of traders aren't either. From professional folks to average folks who seemed to be saying to the Nasdaq folks after this latest snafu that it's getting kind of long. Which could mean trouble for all of those who have stocks residing on the Nasdaq. If their exchange looks rocky, who are you to say that stocks like Apple, Intel, Cisco and so many others don't look rocky as well? Maybe just not some, what do you think?

KEITH FITZ-GERALD, MONEY MAP PRESS: You know what his interview look like after this whole crash? I didn't do it. I mean, you know, body language that was it. I think this big tech companies are suspect because if the foundation is rocky then who is to say the pricing is actually accurate. You know, whether or not it is the exchange, data coming in, who knows.

But investor confidence was dead and buried a long time ago between the insider trading, the big banks, the bailouts you guys were talking about. It's easier to find someone that believes in the tooth fairy.

CAVUTO: Does it affect Nasdaq issues though especially some of those prominent technology names, Gary B., would add just another level, but another level of caution?

GARY B. SMITH: To the high-frequency trader, yes, absolutely. That three-hour glitch was like a canyon, but 99 percent of the people who are not involved, absolutely no effect. I asked my wife at the end of the day, do you know about the Nasdaq outage and it's like, what he talking about. That is what the average person is saying in the Ciscos of the world.

CAVUTO: Steve, I love showing folks whooping it up. I said that you are every bit as impressive with incoming freshmen. So maybe it is just coincidental. But I hear that you are getting all of these calls to team up and do motivational speaking. And I saw that you are already a billionaire. So Gary, I do know that once word got out, the stock was jumping.

SMITH: I think what you read into it, he's really every horrible. I look back in the last 15 years in the Microsoft stock has done zero. In that same time Apple has not 7000 percent. You know, I think that they need to start thinking differently. They need some of this in America.

CAVUTO: That could be you. You become what you think?

FITZ-GERALD: You know, a blogger said he looked like planet of the apes when he did that dance, the CEO got to do that? No, I have long advocated that it's a good thing that he's gone.

CAVUTO: All right, so you have this note. In the final blitz and speaking of Apple, offering a series of new phones before Apple's big announcement. It has a 40-hour per month preview. I guess no limit. Hitler said it is because the advertising buzz is just slowly filling in. You're not so convinced about that?

SMITH: I am not. I think it's just best to avoid these stocks. I never liked that. You have to keep paying every time. I think that's more stable way to go.

CAVUTO: Could I switch gears then and look at the other side of this, would you, Keith, Apple, I mean, it's getting attacked on all fronts. It's getting sort of wind up by what used to be considered effusions now going for the prints. Are the wounds piling up, damage done, what?

FITZ-GERALD: You know, I think they are. I think since Jobs' unfortunate demise or death, the company is oozing MBA's are no longer oozing innovation. I think bandwidth has gone to zero. There's certainly be changed to foreign factor with regard to its iPad and iPod. But you know, bandwidth is ubiquitous now and I think Pandora is making move. To me the thing is more interesting about this is the application feed that's going to develop as a result of it. I think Pandora is simply stepping out ahead. I think Apple is going to play me too. This reminds me of the Sony Betamax wars years ago.

CAVUTO: That's interesting. Guys, I want to thank you both. Have a great weekend. I look forward to Mark Cuban on Monday. This is a place where billionaires come home to roost.
