urn:contentItem:58VY-CR61-DXH2-6430-00000-00CAVUTO for July 10, 20132013-07-10T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:30ZLexisNexisCAVUTO8:00 PM ESTKevin Brady, Gina Loudon, Joe Lieberman, Gabriel Weinberg, John Fleming, Jared Levy, Todd Wilemon, Dennis Hastert, Gretchen Hamel, Christian Dorsey, Imogen Lloyd Webber, Michelle FieldsNEWSDomestic071001cb.223CAVUTO for July 10, 2013Neil Cavuto

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: Well, at least it's something. If the IRS is not going to cut any one over these targeted groups, how about we just cut the IRS's funds and target its budget. Welcome, everybody. I am Neil Cavuto. Well, GOP to IRS, how is this for tax thing? House Republicans looking to cut 3 million bucks from the IRS budget. 4 million less than what the White House wants. Clearly, it is punishment for an agency that won't so much as reprimand itself, and its administration, that just as clearly thinks, it really doesn't have to, because two months after the White House promised that it was going to get to the bottom of this IRS mess, not a single targeted conservative group has been questioned or so much as an initial finding had been reported. So, maybe the IRS's getting its budget cut it just deserves. After all, if you're going to whack groups for no reason, why not whack their finding? For what seems like very good reason. Now to the congressman leading that charge and eager to cut the cash. With me now Republican Kevin Brady in Texas. Congressman, it sounds like a sound idea to me. Does it have much popular support?

REP. KEVIN BRADY, (R-TX), HOUSE DEPUTY WHIP: You know, I think it does, and mainly because it's something you don't see around Washington much, which is accountability. This cut simply says, look, clean up your act, follow the recommendations of the inspector general, stop the frivolous funding on from bonuses to conferences, and by the way, stop covering up these patterns of abuse and open up the IRS, so we can get to the truth, and I think that is fair.

CAVUTO: All right, now, this would have an (inaudible) fight in the Senate, I imagine, even if it gets through the House. So, you're probably more truly sending a warning to the IRS, that you're on it, you expect accountability, expect reaction, you expect immediate action on some of these abuses and that has been shortcoming, has it?

BRADY: You know, it has not been happening at all. The new acting head of the IRS, I think, is trying to manage the problem, rather than create trust, open it up, help us get to the truth here. But just know this, Neil. These dollars that have been withheld are for specific actions. If the IRS follows the recommendations of the Inspector General in cleaning up their act and changing their behavior, you know, than finding follows, until they do that, they need to know that their behavior or lack of reforms have consequences.

CAVUTO: All right. Does this have any implication down the road, Congressman, IRS's role eventually in policing at least the financial part of healthcare? There are about 40 somewhat different areas that they will oversee when the healthcare law comes in to full fruition. Do you want to stop that as well because their budget is going to go up exponentially once that happens.

BRADY: You know, at this point I think the IRS has lost any credibility enforcing the Affordable Care Act. This is - they're using their dollars in their enforcement to pursue political agendas, based on political belief, we don't think they have the credibility to enforce the 23 taxes and all the mandates within Obamacare either. Nor is there confidence among American public they will protect our taxpayer information once we give it to them, so right now they're probably the least credible organization in the federal government. They've got some changing to do.

CAVUTO: All right. Congressman, we'll watch closely on Kevin Brady of the fine state of Texas, on what could be a way to get the IRS going or not, depending on your point of view.

But now to the Tea Party who says, why just cut around the corners when it didn't got to the core? And maybe cut the IRS itself out of existence. With me now Tea Party activist Gina Loudon. Gina, good to have you. You are not for just sort of doddering here, you're for walloping. Explain why.

(LAUGHTER)

GINA LOUDON, TEA PARTY ACTIVIST & RADIO HOST: Music to my years, Neil. You know, the IRS has become a weapon of mass destruction against the taxpayers. It is so corrupt, we know, that is unconstitutional, it was actually voted unconstitutional once upon a time. There are so many problems with this and not only that. It's so old school. There's such much more efficient ways we can tax the people in the United States that are much more fair. And I think would settle well with most of the American people. It's definitely time to make these reforms.

CAVUTO: All right, but you know, be careful what you ask for. You just might get it, and that the argument is to just abolishing the IRS. Well, a lot of people share that view. It is - that's impractical and you need an organization that polices whether people are paying the taxes. You pay your taxes, I pay my taxes, but there are a lot of people who tried to pull some fast ones, and you need an agency, whether it's IRS or something else to monitor that.

LOUDON: But it doesn't need to be the largest organization in the federal - largest federal bureaucracy, there is. It doesn't need to be an organization that has targeted minority groups. It doesn't need to be an organization that votes itself fat cat bonuses. If this were a private business, Neil, you and I both know, it would be long gone, because the government would have regulated it out of business. It is completely corrupt, it's unconstitutional and it needs to go away. And there are great answers out there. You know, the progressives are always saying, they love the word fair, right? So let's do something fair. Let's do something that does tax everybody straight across the board like a consumption tax. It can't be avoided by the black market work like ...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: No, you don't need a big agency.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I see, but you don't need a big agency to police that.

LOUDON: Yes, you don't.

CAVUTO: But back to these whole harassment of conservative groups, what you - I think you might have been one, but do you know anybody in your case or others, whether they were contacted by these group that's supposedly investigating what happened at the behest of the president?

LOUDON: I know so many different people that have been attacked by the IRS and one from another ...

CAVUTO: Yeah, but no one - no one has been - where (inaudible)

No one has been contacted, these groups that were targeted, had not been contacted by this White House investigator, that is looking into what happened, and that worries me.

LOUDON: That's right. That's right. And I'm still hearing continued stories of abuse that are new stories of abuse, so basically nothing is being done here, and this organization needs to go way. Having an organization like this is sort of tantamount to driving a covered wagon to a hospital. We need to come to the edge, this century, of automobiles and get this done in a much more efficient, transparent, technologically savvy way. It's time for the IRS to be abolished. Straight up. Get them gone.

CAVUTO: All right, but as you know, they're going to play a central role in health care and unless something changes and fairs the roll out for that, actually begins next year. And it's sort of ...

LOUDON: You're fine.

CAVUTO: Setting a stone, and you're saying, unset it.

LOUDON: You know, I am always looking for opportunities for politicians to be heroes. I thought W. (ph) in deep hole this week that said two-thirds of Americans are demanding that the IRS, go away. This is the chance for politicians - I thought you were on the Superman list this week. This is the chance for politicians to ingratiate themselves to the American population they're supposed to serve and say, hey, we are going to do what makes sense here, instead of continuing on because this is the way things have always been done. The American people have spoken, Neil, and it's time to make some changes.

CAVUTO: Gina, always great having you on. Thank you very much.

LOUDON: Always good to be here with you. Thank you.

CAVUTO: Gina Loudon. By the way, Congress isn't only busy cutting cash for the IRS. Now, it's looking abroad and seeing this as full and cutting the catch out there as well.

But you'll never guess where they want to start. It's enough to get Joe Lieberman here on the flash to say Congress, you are going too far.

CAVUTO: Well, Cairo is still a mess, and a government now toppled, to which we have already given billions, gets worse. No wonder why Republicans want to cut any more aid now. But guess where they are targeting their spending at right now? Not Egypt, Syria. As all the dough that we are forking over to Syrian rebels, they worry that it is going to the wrong guys, rebels who need us, but don't much like us, and because many are aligned to al Qaeda, it might actually turn around to kill us. To Joe Lieberman who says, they're jumping to conclusions and giving a thick pay to (inaudible), a big jump on continuing to crush its people. Senator, good to have you back.

FMR. SEN. JOE LIEBERMAN (I-CT): Neil, great to be back.

CAVUTO: I just wondered myself, this seemed out of the blue, I mean I would be looking that maybe if you had any reason to sort of curtail. Funny you can reassess Egyptian government and changes there, but the Syrian thing, I think, was just odd. What do you make of it?

LIEBERMAN: Yeah, no - I agree. Look, this has been going on in Syria now for more than two years. More than 100,000 people have died. I mean it is a humanitarian disaster and the cause of freedom is on the line. We should have been in there in the beginning. I went over earlier on met the opposition to Assad. Assad is an anti-American dictator. These were ...

CAVUTO: And how do you know, some of these other groups that have formed? Justice (inaudible)

LIEBERMAN: Well, now we've waited too long. And ...

CAVUTO: We don't know this.

LIEBERMAN: We know enough, we - listen, if our intelligence is not good enough, and I am sure it is good enough, to know who the good guys are over there and who the bad guys are, we've got a problem. And ...

CAVUTO: But it started out earlier what we did, like when guys like you were there and you knew who they were ....

LIEBERMAN: Yes.

CAVUTO: But now the fear is what Republicans are saying senators. Now, we are not quite so sure and do we want to make the same mistake we apparently made in Egypt?

LIEBERMAN: Yeah, I think we've got to take a risk. And the reason is not only to try to stop the humanitarian disaster of the killings, but what is happening in Syria is really a proxy war between Iran and Russia on one side, and our allies in the Arab world and us on the other side, but we're not very much on the field. We finally have begun to give some assistance to the opposition to Assad. If Assad goes down, it is the biggest defeat for Iran, his patron in the Middle East, in a long time and helps us to put pressure on them to stop their nuclear weapons program, which, I think is the biggest threat to the region and the world today.

CAVUTO: You know, Senator, I had Ron Paul here not too long ago, and he was saying, what have we got for all the money we've given? Now, of course, he's clearly libertarian, his point of view, it is not worth it, you know, stop it, and all that. Because in one country after another we've had a record of putting that on the wrong people and they come back and they bite us. And he sees things like U.S. flag burnings at some of these demonstrations. So, why add insult to injury?

LIEBERMAN: Yeah.

CAVUTO: What is that?

LIEBERMAN: So, looking a lot of places around the world over the last 25 or 30 years, this has really been and advance of democracy and freedom and pro-American allies. That is certainly true in Eastern and Central Europe, the former Soviet Union and it is also true in Asia.

CAVUTO: But what about this region? Maybe, I don't know - when there's a gentlemanly way to put it. You were the last gentleman in Washington. Maybe they are just nuts? And there is no way you can bet on any group, because they all seem crazy.

LIEBERMAN: Yeah, but they are not all crazy. I spent a lot of time over there. And what happened in Tunisia and Egypt, and then Libya, and it began to happen in Syria, was an uprising of what I would call moderate sort of modernizing young Arabs who were sick and tired of the dictators who are not only ...

CAVUTO: So, why did they turn on the very government that they put in power?

LIEBERMAN: This last time around?

CAVUTO: Yeah.

LIEBERMAN: Right. In Egypt because they concluded and I agree with them, that an election is only one element of really having a democracy. The rest of it is, that's just as important, more important, ultimately. It's freedom. It's human rights.

CAVUTO: But does it trouble you on some level, senator, that whatever merits you think - what you're saying is accurate, that it was a military that toppled the democratically elected government. Maybe for valid reasons ...

LIEBERMAN: Yes.

CAVUTO: That doesn't look good.

LIEBERMAN: It doesn't look good. But I will tell you, and it's the most unusual circumstance, and it's not - you know, you try to follow your ideals, but then sometimes you just have to be practical about this, and in this case, Morsy, the previous Muslim Brotherhood leader of Egypt was really becoming a dictator. The people had no alternative, but to go out in the streets and very unusually, the military basically got him out of power and now give the revolution that started against Mubarak a second chance to work, but they have got to learn to work with each other, and that is a real challenge.

CAVUTO: You know, this is - probably going to sound like a racist comment, but isn't it by design in nature that, you know, the Muslim-led government by design isn't going to reconcile with the secular interest of its people? Maybe that's that what happened in this government's case? And that is irreconcilable.

LIEBERMAN: So, in this government's case, in the case of Morsy and the Muslim Brotherhood, they won the election. Not by a lot, but they won it, and then he began to close off the opposition, people's freedom, putting ...

CAVUTO: Because it's given his background - given his ...

LIEBERMAN: Yeah.

CAVUTO: It wasn't in his DNA, to be a democratically elected leader.

LIEBERMAN: So, I by the way, I think it depends on the leader. It depends on the Muslim leader. In Tunisia, we've had an encouraging situation, which is an Islamist party, actually, got more votes than any of the other parties, but it needed to form a coalition ...

CAVUTO: Right.

LIEBERMAN: ....to get a majority to govern and it made the coalition with secular Muslim Arab parties and they pretty much held together.

CAVUTO: Do you think that could be (inaudible), because it looks tough.

LIEBERMAN: It's tough. But that is the (inaudible). It's very hard to go from where a lot of these countries going when you had central dictatorship, not only controlling their freedom, but basically, taking the wealth of the country. And the people got fed up with it. Most of them want what you and I want, which is a better life, the kids grow up better. And not to be governed by extremist whether they are secular dictators or Islamist extremist. That's the whole - it's not going to be easy to get there.

CAVUTO: Senator, really quickly on this healthcare thing. Many argue it is falling apart. It's losing a key source of funding. It's imploding. What do you say?

LIEBERMAN: I don't think it is imploding. I mean I think this step back on that funding requirement was probably smart to do to show some flexibility in the Obama administration, that they were responding, no problem. But there - they have not said they're going to repeal it. It's coming in a year when I think people are going to be better able to take it. No, I think it's going to be there. I will never forget when President Clinton came in to talk to a bunch of us, senators when we were reconsidering the House healthcare proposal, and he said, get it as good as you can and then adopt it, because trust me, you're going to be coming back for 25 years to fix it because you cannot get it right the first time. And that is the question. I mean it remains unpopular, I'm afraid that the administration has not done as good of a job as it should have done in convincing the American people that this was - to the ....

CAVUTO: Do you think they knew all these problems were there, and they just did not say?

LIEBERMAN: I don't know. I can't say.

CAVUTO: I think you do.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: No, I have no idea.

(LAUGHTER)

CAVUTO: Joe Lieberman, it's always a pleasure. Thank you very, very much.

LIEBERMAN: Great to be with you.

CAVUTO: Just classed up the city nonsense in letting here - anyway. You had it was Google handing over your stuff. Well, how about telling Google to just get stuff? The search engine that is making it awfully tempting and actually, awfully easy. After this.

CAVUTO: Well, if Ed Snowden is right, the government might snoop, but it sure has a whole lot of culprits helping it out. Among them scores of high-tech companies, that not only hand over the affirmation what the NSA asked, but according to Snowden, keep a back door open, just in case they want to come back and get some more. To the search engine that says Uncle Sam to just search on, because it won't be giving up a thing. And promises it uses no one is going to be tracking them. That engine is called DuckDuckGo. And the guy, creating all this quacking joins us now. CEO Gabriel Weinberg. Gabriel, how do you stick to that? How do you stick to that promise?

GABRIEL WEINBERG, DUCKDUCKGO CEO: So, when you search anything on the Internet or going any Web site, you are automatically sending over this information, the metadata that we keep talking about, right? What we do is literally throw that information away. We throw that metadata away, so that we just start completely anonymous searches. So, if someone were to come to us and ask us, you know, hand over data on E.U. We literally cannot do that, because we don't have it.

CAVUTO: I don't believe you. No, because I think you guys are so hi- tech and brilliant. You have ways - and you know.

WEINBERG: That is the beauty of it is. You literally throw it away and never write at a desk. Never store it. So, even if someone's stole out your servers, for instance, or hacked into your system, which has happened to big tech companies. There is still no way to expect the information.

CAVUTO: Well, how do you make money?

WEINBERG: That's the beauty of it. It is a myth that Web search engines need to track you to make money. We make money the same way they do, which is serve and ad based on the keyword, and not the person, so you type in like car, you will get the car ad. It's pretty simple.

CAVUTO: But are you keeping track of a number of times that I punched in the word "Car" ?

WEINBERG: No, no so all they have ....

CAVUTO: It might just be one time I did car and that's what's doing it, or ...

WEINBERG: Exactly.

CAVUTO: What's - you at least get to be the first time.

WEINBERG: So, it's all in real time. So, you're typing car, you get a car ad. The next day you come and type in mortgage, so you get mortgage ads.

CAVUTO: You don't have these big old size of Rhode Island servers that are keeping track of all this?

WEINBERG: No, no, data center in Utah.

CAVUTO: OK. So, let's say now the NSA, when it come to you and say, we need to collect all of your records. What do you say?

WEINBERG: We say the laws are structured that you cannot force a company to change its business practices.

CAVUTO: Understood, but that's under a judge's order.

WEINBERG: That's right. But still, the order says, only orders about turning over existing business records or they have preservation orders, which (inaudible) about enabling you to keep records for longer. So, if you start for 24 hours, you know, start for two weeks. And since we don't have any records, there is really nothing to compel us to turn over.

CAVUTO: But what is to stop me as an NSA agency saying, you know, this guy's is too clever for words. I bet he does have that stuff, I'm going to take over this, I'm going to get access to this, and I'm going to prove that he does have?

WEINBERG: Right. If they saw we had access, and we're trying to hack us, or came to us with a court order, you know, we would be compelled to turn over our data and that is why we don't store anything.

CAVUTO: Do you find the Google's and the Apples and the others - who have given information, they say for national security reasons, or they were told at the time.

Do so easily, do so almost too easily?

WEINBERG: You know, it's a little unclear from all of the statements falling around, but what is clear is that the presumption for big tech companies is to store as much data as possible and hope that, you know, they could use it later for something useful. And the reality ...

CAVUTO: Well, Google says he keeps this stuff so they could target ads ...

WEINBERG: Right.

CAVUTO: You know, whatever.

WEINBERG: Who knows, I think most of it is just kept and not used, but the reality is that there is about court order. Whenever that turns out to be a valid, whenever we decide this constitutional line. If it's still valid, they have to turn it with the data. And because the data exists, they are going to have to turn it over.

CAVUTO: So, what are you making when Ed Snowden tells at interview in Europe, I believe, he was talking about this, that a lot of it keeps this sort of back door open, which I think, and you know this far better than I, allows the government to come back in? And so to check the place out.

WEINBERG: Although there is a story out today that companies have been charging, you know, the government ...

CAVUTO: Right, right, right.

WEINBERG: For wiretapping an access. And what that says to me is that there are systems in place to deal with this request and the volume.

CAVUTO: I always think the government doesn't need those inconsistency, right? It's just sort of ...

WEINBERG: Well, it makes it easier for the company, right?

CAVUTO: Right.

WEINBERG: They are getting thousands and thousands of requests, you got to do something and hand it over easily. And that's the worry right? That's become too easy.

CAVUTO: Has your business grown since this whole Snowden thing (inaudible)

WEINBERG: Yes. I mean we always think people don't want to be tracked but really, they don't know what to do about it, and so, what this has really revealed is that there are private alternatives you can switch to, it's a little sacrifice. And so, we have seen, you know, our users spreading it to their friends and family and saying, hey, you know, I use this search engine that gets great results, but also, it does not track you. And so we've been up about 90 percent since this whole ...

CAVUTO: Wow.

WEINBERG: Yes, since this new cycle.

CAVUTO: Totally clear. It's just - the ballpark kind of question. Do you think Ed Snowden is a hero?

WEINBERG: You know, it's a little too early to tell. If you need - if you can whistleblower in this manner and stay in the U.S., I think that's ...

CAVUTO: You think the fact that he did not stay in the U.S. takes away the free speech he wrote (inaudible)

WEINBERG: You know, there was an editorial by Daniel Ellsberg the other day in "The Post."

CAVUTO: Yeah. Pentagon papers.

WEINBERG: Yeah, and it was - it was pretty compelling that you would have to leave the country. And so, I don't really know what to make of it, but I know that I like there is an open discussion about the constitutional lines of this stuff. And I think it's great to be public, and not private. I don't like at all being secret.

CAVUTO: Good for you. Thank you very much. DuckDuckGo the founder and CEO on fire right now.

Remember what (inaudible) on immigration reform was in the Senate? But don't look now, but it's falling apart in the House. The Republican Congress and - knows why after this.

CAVUTO: Well, the president might be touting its economic benefits, but as things stand out, immigration reform is looking kind of like that health care law on life support. Only healthcare is the law and immigration reform is a long way from becoming law, and that's because Republicans at the House think it - well, not only doesn't make money, Louisiana Republican Congressman John Fleming says, at this point it really doesn't make much sense. The congressman joins me on the phone. Congressman, you are still opposed to this thing, right?

REP. JOHN FLEMING (R ),LOUISIANA: Yeah, absolutely, Neil. And I just came from an extended conference with my fellow Republicans, and out of over, you know, well over 210 members, I don't think there was one single person in that room who would vote for this current Senate immigration amnesty bill.

CAVUTO: Wow. So that would effectively kill it in the House. There is all sorts to talk, but John Boehner is under enormous pressure to try to woo some of those reluctant colleagues of yours. Has he had any luck, if you're right? No.

FLEMING: Well, you know, it's interesting - there is a broad consensus we all want to solve the problem, we want to fix the immigration. We see it as broken. But we also have a broad consensus that it all begins with border security and the Senate bill is anything but border security.

CAVUTO: Well, I had Senator Marco Rubio here not too long ago, Congressman. He says that has been addressed and he doesn't know how to make it more forceful that the proviso was in there -- you know, saying under threat of military action. What do you want to see that presently you don't see in the Senate version?

FLEMING: Well, first of all, there is no end point. There is no verifiability. There is no certification process. We offer one in our homeland security bill that's passed of a committee. It authorizes a bunch of resources, but the president as he has done in many cases can redirect those any place that he wants and it does not appropriate money even borders resources.

CAVUTO: Do you worry that this will be a redoubt of what Ronald Reagan was (inaudible). In other words, a grant amnesty or what seemed to be at the time in 1986 amnesty, but without getting the promised reinforced border?

FLEMING: I think it doubles down in and takes the problem from bad to worse.

CAVUTO: Congressman, thank you very much.

FLEMING: Thank you, Neil.

CAVUTO: Well, here's how bad are things getting for Speaker Boehner and all of this? Harry Reid says he actually feels sorry for him and Republicans are keeping him from doing what is right on immigration reform and so Reid expects no immigration reform from now. Does he have a point? Dennis Hastert, what do you think?

DENNIS HASTERT, FORMER SPEAKER OF THE HOUSE: You know, I think Boehner's probably in a tough spot, but you know, you look at the issue. The issue isn't going to go away. The issue doesn't get better by not addressing it. That's what leaderships about. You have to convince folks that there is a way.

To just reject the Senate bill, you have to have something to beat something. So there should be something of the House. What the House really needs to do is come together and say, OK, we need more border security. Let's put up together a bill with more border security.

If we need to have a path -- a naturalization process that automatically happens with automatic citizenship at least there has to be a path to citizenship. Let them get the citizenship like everybody else does. You know, apply for it and wait and go to the process.

CAVUTO: Do you think the party is dragged by my conservative members say don't bend and telling John Boehner if you even blink, your toast?

HASTERT: Well, it's either the party is telling a leader or the leader is leading the party, but there has to be a happy medium here and there has to be a come together. You know, one of the things that -- we'd need to get reform done on immigration neither. So I'm just saying, I know what the pitfalls are. There has to be a team approach on this. You have to bring it together and you had to bring the ideas together --

CAVUTO: But I don't see the team and I'm wondering if behind the scenes either cooler heads are trying to prevail or say, look, guys, if this goes down, politically it doesn't look good because if you're concerned how poorly we did with the Latino vote in the last election, we're going to do worse. So you think that those kind of conversations are going on? Do you think they are legitimate fears that everything hinges on this?

HASTERT: I think there are legitimate fears in this situation. But there are a lot of people and I think that aren't convinced yet, but they have to be convinced. It is a common-sense approach to this and if we just let all of these, you know, hard feelings get melted out a little bit and take the common sense. I hope we get it done.

CAVUTO: Dennis Hastert, thank you. Good to see you again.

HASTERT: My pleasure.

CAVUTO: Meanwhile a federal judge ruining your party? Well, you know, there's an app for that. If only Apple could find a way out this.

CAVUTO: Apple not so happy birthday, not to expect an expansion and not a crystal clear forecast, so many blitzes, so many buts. Time to start getting this straight and here to do their blitzing, Jared Levy and Todd Wilemon.

First stop, Jared, Apple, who could blame the executives there if they cried at their birthday if they want to because on at store's five-year anniversary, a federal judge crashes the party that Apple colluded with five U.S. publishers to artificially drive up the e-book prices, if so, out of control? What do you say?

JARED LEVY, ZACKS.COM SENIOR EQUITIES STRATEGIST: You know, it is funny. I was so excited about my five free apps and five free songs today. I pretty much blew over the news and a lot of traders actually did the same. If you look at Apple's stock, it didn't really move down that much. And what that tells me is the market sort of spoken here.

Remember, this happened last year over in Europe. The European Commission, you know, ruled on the antitrust issues and Apple settled without admitting any wrongdoing. I think we need to look now is what is the next big thing? I think that's what traders are looking for.

In September when we see the new iPhone, is it really going to wow us? You know, if it doesn't, I think the stocks moved way lower, but for now, I think this is something press aside and look forward to the future of Apple, which I am still unsure about.

CAVUTO: All right, you know, you could make the argument that the stock has been punished enough and maybe that's it is not punishment enough what do you think about that?

TODD WILEMON, NYSE EURONEXT MANAGING DIRECTOR: I would agree with that. The stock is already down. It's already down big time from its high of over $700. Realize, you know, historically when big companies have tangled with the government on anti-trust or anti-competitive issues, going forward after the company gets finished -- after the government gets finished with that company, the company doesn't do that well.

Two cases of point AT&T during the '70s and `80s and then you have Microsoft. There is a real worry that this is going to take the focus on Apple away from what they do best and that's competing and coming out with great products that people like to buy. So going forward, I would be worried about Apple. They lost Steve Jobs. Now they've lost this antitrust. Let's hope that iPhone is good.

CAVUTO: And let's hope my memory is even better. Todd, I apologize. In the meantime, issue two, Yelp on the roll or should I say roll out because this web site known mainly for compiling local business reviews is teaming up with smaller companies to offer a food delivery service and soon even a medical appointment service.

So, Jared, I think that means you can review a local company online while you're ordering a sandwich online and if you get food poisoning while eating the sandwich, click an appointment with your doctor to have him check you out. Is that far out?

LEVY: All in one. No, it's (inaudible) -- right. I mean, you know, Yelp has done it right. Out of all the social media companies out there that came public, I think Yelp has the most promise. What you got to remember first of all is Yelp is still losing money, right. And to do this right on national scale, they are only doing it in New York and San Francisco.

It will take a lot of mechanics. They are partnering up with a couple of different companies like you said. I think Yelp has a little bit of legwork here. I think the stocks a little bit over bought, probably going to come down. I think it is a real smart idea. I like the reservations type thing because listen, people believe Yelp.

In fact, a buddy of mine, a company he hears that Yelpers, you know, they complain about specific employees. Companies are firing them left and right because they've got faith in Yelp. As horrible as that sounds, it is good for the company. And I think long term Yelp is good, but I look for a full back in the stock here in the near term.

CAVUTO: Jared, that's another reason to admire you. You have a friend who runs a valet company. Todd, what do you make of that?

WILEMON: We need his number. I think Jared hits it right on the nail. But it is great about Yelp because the internet is the great disrupter. Yelp has a lot of people that go on there and critique things, which they love to do because people love to point out where people are failing. And they are trying to monetize the eyeballs. If it is successful, all those critiques are going to be perfect for Yelp.

CAVUTO: All right, issue three, gentlemen. Big Ben, big confusion, investors buying initially as they hear that Ben Bernanke may not pull the plug on stimulus anytime soon and will pull back so if the tapering is still on, Jared, any clues here?

LEVY: You know, all right, so the minutes showed us that about half of the members were fully on board with bringing tapering back in September late year and we saw the market has sort move lower then Bernanke spoke in Cambridge after the markets it is probably better than Ambien for putting you to sleep, but he did let us know a couple of things.

What he portrayed to us was a little bit more of a dubbish stance. In other words, you know, the fed will not tighten as aggressively as possible and on that futures are higher. So here's what I think. I think for now this trajectory remains the same. I think markets are excited.

But we are looking forward to a post QE world and we're looking positively forward and I think Bernanke lead us to believe we can be positive and for now we continue to drink the Kool-Aid and the markets, well, they are going to move a little bit higher until the next piece of news comes out.

CAVUTO: You know, whatever they do before hand. I don't think once the act happens, you know, Todd and they actually do start tapering or cutting down from the 85 or so billion a month that they've been, you know, throwing cash at these markets. It will not be a big deal ahead of the fact? What do you think?

WILEMON: I totally agree. It is the news not the rumor because right now markets moving on the rumor. When the news comes out, it's not going to be that big of a deal. I'm reading through the notes, all that kept going through my mind was Ricky Ricardo going Lucy.

CAVUTO: Guys, thank you both very much. Guys, thanks again. In the meantime, a country even fatter than we Americanos. Wait until you hear who just knocks us off the world's most obese list.

CAVUTO: Here is the bad news. We're still fat in this country. Here's the good news. We're no longer the fastest country. Mexico went ahead of us. Enchiladas are fattening? I digress. Maybe now the food police can cease and desist here and move south. Michelle Fields hope so. Imogen Lloyd Webber sure hopes not. Imogen, what do you make of this.

IMOGEN LLOYD WEBBER, AUTHOR AND COLUMNIST: Obesity. The only reason I'm here is to say the word obesity. Michelle is here to say this. Obesity is a public health care catastrophe. It threatens to shorten U.S. life expectancy for the first time since -- not only that it cost America output of $147 billion in related health care cost. Obesity is actually long way compared to your health care problems here.

CAVUTO: OK, what do you think of that, Michelle?

MICHELLE FIELDS, NEXTGENERATION TV CORRESPONDENT: Look, I think that the government should stop trying to tell people what they can and cannot eat because it is obviously not working. If they want to do anything, why not stop a lot of the subsidies that we provide for additives -- makes junk food cheaper. I don't think that this is a collective problem. This is a individual problem what happens to personal responsibility?

The only reason we look at this as a collective problem is because we have big government in health care. So whether you have high cholesterol or high blood pressure that ends up being everyone's because everyone have to pay for your medical bills, and whether you go to the doctor or not. At the end of the day government should not be in health care, but we should mind their own businesses.

CAVUTO: We have a good shot at dropping at number three because New Zealand looks like it's pretty hefty on the chabua front --

WEBBER: We are at number seven.

CAVUTO: What do you guys to do that we're not doing?

WEBBER: There is seriously, obviously a link between poverty and obesity and the scary thing is a lot of obese people are actually malnourished. So it does come down to I'm afraid that there's need to be some government help, some comprehensive help. From labelling, Oklahoma State University proved early on this in a study that labelling helps to educate people who need educating in all of this --

CAVUTO: In this city they publish menus with the calorie count you don't know the double whopper has a lot of calories?

WEBBER: It is about accessible and affordable food so again looking at farming methods and so forth. There is a point. We need a public way to tackle its. This is a public health care catastrophe. Therefore, you need a public way of looking at it to tackle it.

CAVUTO: Well, it's an obesity catastrophe.

WEBBER: It's an obesity catastrophe.

CAVUTO: We have to get dragged ourselves away from that? Maybe we should give birth wouldn't it be great if that little tight grew up to be a fat so?

WEBBER: No Henry the Eight. Not yet.

CAVUTO: You know, Michelle, when you look at these parents are not policing their kids right. We are eating all the wrong stuff. We have to do something because it is out of control?

FIELDS: Well, I think it has a lot to do with the economy. Look, it's cheaper to go to McDonalds and buy your whole family food than to go and buy tons of fruits and vegetables. I think improving the economy will make it so that people can go out and afford to buy good food.

CAVUTO: Yes, but we've been getting it good and bad the economy alike.

FIELDS: Certainly and I think that a lot of times it is education. Like she said we need to educate people, but I don't think having these programs for our children where you limit the amount of calories they can have for school lunch is not appropriate. It's not working.

CAVUTO: Did you hear the school system where they were forcing the kids' (inaudible) --

WEBBER: The scary thing is the World Health Organization -- is now saying that obesity eating too much is a bigger than starvation. This is an issue. We all need to be together tackling this.

CAVUTO: So you take no solace in Mexico moving to the top.

WEBBER: Certainly not, no.

CAVUTO: Duly noted. Good luck with the baby. Hope it is not fat kid. Say it one more time.

WEBBER: Obesity.

CAVUTO: Remember when Republicans said that the president couldn't delay the employer mandate because it's law, well, count me confused because now Republicans want to delay the individual mandate because they say unfair.

CAVUTO: What you do for my boss you better do for me. I think that pretty much sums up what Republicans are saying about the administration delaying employers having to provide health care for their workers. Their workers are entitled to the same delay providing it for themselves. Gretchen, what is at stake here?

GRETCHEN HAMEL, PUBLIC NOTICE EXECUTIVE DIRECTOR: Individuals having to undergo and have a big burden of Obamacare be resting on them this next year. Here we are. We have small businesses and businesses being delayed on the employer mandate, but individuals are still going to have to be signing up for these plans next year because this whole plan hinges upon young people to shoulder the burden of the older generations to be paying more in premiums for the next year to fund Obamacare in the future.

CAVUTO: What I don't understand is some inconsistency among Republicans because yesterday they were talking, no, Mr. President, you cannot change that because it's the law. A law that they were against, but today they are saying if you do for the boss you have to do it for dominion which I can understand, but it's either all in or all-out. I just don't understand that Republican position.

CHRISTIAN DORSEY, ECONOMIC POLICY INSTITUTE: Yes, I mean, this is about, you know, the Republicans have tried 38 times to repeal Obamacare in the House. It is just another attempt at trying to do what they've been unsuccessful in doing for four years. Everyone knows that the individual mandate is a key to making this work affordably and efficiently.

CAVUTO: Then why doesn't the White House ease the angst its getting now by just pushing it back for everybody?

DORSEY: Well, the White House has handled this whole thing poorly. I will freely admit that, but you know, the individual mandate has been in play in Massachusetts for over five years and it is proven to reduce cost in the individual insurance market to make the whole thing work. So that's why you don't want to delay it because if you delay that particular piece, Neil, then the whole thing just ought to be delayed and there's no reason to do that.

CAVUTO: Well, here's what I worry about. Right now, it's falling apart because all the financial, all the ways that it makes money are drying up, fewer young people signing up, low wage workers, they aren't able to afford signing up. Even the uninsured to be interested to sign up and now the companies that were going to be the butlers for this delayed in having the fork out. So they're running out of financing options, what do they do?

LENORE HAWKINS, MERITAS ADVISORS PRINCIPAL: Absolutely and this also showing that there is no respect for the rule of law. Here's we've got where the government is attempting to take over about 15 percent of the economy. With four years' notice, they still can't get it together to distract information. Now they say Congress is going to pass a series of laws, just what the administration wanted, but now chivvying treasury discretion? Where does that and? When does Congress ever pass something and then give another part of the government. Discretion is to whether or not they are going to actually implement.

CAVUTO: Well, some of our biggest laws in entitlements whether you're for against it or not there is a history to how bumpy they start out. Medicare is a good example in terms of little things, but be that as it may with from some of FDR's new deal program -- JFK came up with domestic initiatives, rocky starts, many returns to the well to fix things so how is this any different? Gretchen, what do you say?

HAMEL: Well, it's not really any different. You could make the argument that the things have not been fixed with Medicare, which has $50 billion worth of fraud every year. You look at the IRS and what the IRS has been doing and receiving bonuses, misusing taxpayer funds. You can look across the government and see the incompetence that the government has -- has executed over the course of the past few years and now they are going to be dealing with our health care.

Our personal choices with our health care, our premiums have gone up. Our plans are changing and there's going to be doctor shortages. Of course, there are bumps along the way, it does not show no matter how much glitz or glamour it will cover up that will have flawed executions.

CAVUTO: But it is unpopular law right now and one of 10 Americans like it. They may live up to those expectations, but it is a tough sell because doctors don't like it, specialists don't like it. I am wondering if Nancy Pelosi did indeed read it and know what was in it and just didn't want to say it?

DORSEY: You know, Neil, we have to stop pretending that the affordable care act is some novel construct -- wait a minute. The major tenants of how this will work nationally have been in place in Massachusetts for over five years. We know how it will work if anybody cares to actually read the bill and study what has happened. We have to stop pretending.

CAVUTO: This is not happening. Something went wrong.

DORSEY: Because there's been a full frontal assault against it from the day the ink dried on the legislation. That we can all agree on --

CAVUTO: Doctors are seeing costs go up as a result of it. Health care premiums are rising because of it. That is not imaginary stuff, the responsibility of Republicans blasting it. That is the reality.

(CROSSTALK)

DORSEY: Are you telling me with health care premiums?

CAVUTO: I have no idea. That was not supposed to happen, but it is happening.

DORSEY: But to promise at premiums to will go up and we have seen all three. Those promises were made and they have been broken.

HAWKINS: It cannot be saved. All it did very simply was increase the demand for medical services while at the same time suppressing the supply because it is not in their best interests. Make it more difficult to apply medical services while increasing demanding at the same time. It teaches prices are going to go up.

CAVUTO: We'll see. It's still early. We will give it time is a bumpy road. But folks, good to have you. Thank you very, very much. We will follow all of these as some changes they are proposing to pay at a possible tax hike to cover the gap. We will see you then.

urn:contentItem:590B-YK81-JB20-G4SD-00000-00CAVUTO for July 26, 20132013-07-26T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCAVUTO8:00 PM ESTCarl Paladino, Chris Stirewalt, Ron Paul, Howard Schmidt, Dee Dee Benkie, Rick Ungar, Craig Huey, Jonathan Hoenig, Dr. Leigh VinocurNEWSDomestic072601cb.223CAVUTO for July 26, 2013Charles Payne, Melissa Francis, Liz MacDonald, Dennis Kneale

CHARLES PAYNE, FBN ANCHOR: Is this tour less about an economic reboot and more about putting a boots to Republicans?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Sincerely, they have a fundamentally different vision for America, one that says inequality is both inevitable and just. One that says an unfettered free market without any restraints inevitably produces the best outcomes regardless of the pain and uncertainty it holds on ordinary families. I say to these members of Congress, I am laying out my ideas, so now it is time for you to lay out your ideas.

(APPLAUSE)

OBAMA: You can't just be against something. You've got to be for something.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

PAYNE: Welcome everybody. I'm Charles Payne in for Neil Cavuto. And all week we have been hearing the president talk about the economy. But instead of saying he wants to work with Republicans, he has been blaming and attacking Republicans saying they are the ones holding a middle-class down. To Melissa Frances, Carl Paladino and Chris Stirewalt on if the president is looking for the economy to pick up or is he just looking to pick a fight. Melissa.

MELISSA FRANCIS, "MONEY WITH MELISSA FRANCIS" HOST: You know, he says you cannot be against something, you've got to be for something. How about being for the Keystone XL pipeline. I mean he talks about the economy and politicians fighting on each other -- fighting with each other. Why don't we get behind some projects that could actually create jobs? Keystone could create 20,000 jobs out of the gate construction jobs. That is conservative. Some people think it is 40,000.

PAYNE: Unions have a bigger number than that, I think.

FRANCIS: Absolutely. Half a million barrels of oil a day would wipe out our need to bring in Venezuela and South American oil. This is something that could create jobs and lower prices for American. Get behind that.

They reinventing themselves and I know Dennis is well versed in this, into essentially a technology company with hardware, with dominance in the Cloud. So yes, Amazon isn't making a lot of money now, doesn't planting the third quarter, but the investments they are making are going to pay off. I think why you are seeing the stock continue to do so well.

PAYNE: But what about the consumer? Where do you think the consumer risk is? We get mix signals almost every day these earnings come in.

DENNIS KNEALE, FOX BUSINESS: I think it is really important to look at these big retailers as a pulse point, but I think Wal-Mart is the vastly better predictor of what consumer is and where it's going than Amazon. Amazon is a very select mix and they are very different from the typical retailer simply buying stuff from someone and sell it. They are making their Kindle and selling stuff they use that Amazon kindle to shop on Amazon there is so many directions. I'm not sure that Amazon -- also their sales growth is really strong and that is consumer demand. It's their earnings.

PAYNE: To your point, this dollar stores, I mean, stocks have been hot. The family dollar had a huge number of week or so ago, is that a red flag?

KNEALE: Because the thought being that they are hot because people are thinking that the consumer is going to trade down?

PAYNE: That is not a great sign of confidence.

KNEALE: It is time to stop worrying and start spending.

HOENIG: They are, Charles, I mean, Target has been strong. Wal-Mart has been strong. A lot of the (inaudible) retailers have been strong and I tell you consumer confidence tends to follow the stock market. So the market at an all-time, it's not surprising to see this consumer feeling a little bit better moving forward.

PAYNE: Yes, I think we're in a period, guys, where people are just spending money. They are not necessarily borrowing, but whenever they had in that check, they'll spend it. I don't know if it's good or bad with respect to the future.

Let's shift gears a little bit. To the attack on fracking, bad enough the EPA is looking to regulate fracking. Now the Justice Department is going after companies like Halliburton. Jonathan, will this war on oil ever stop?

HOENIG: Well, the war on fossil fuels in general, Charles, and it's terrible because whether it's oil or natural gas, which of course, fracking use to produce. I mean, it is a tremendous benefit to the consumers at large. Fracking is safe. It's been practiced for decades in this country and just in the last two years the innovations in fracking have helped bring natural gas prices down 70 percent. That is a huge benefit for the economy and for everyday consumers just trying to go out and make some money, feed their families and live the American dream.

KNEALE: Yet, why is a Justice Department investigating frackers right now? They are looking into antitrust. Now since when do plunging prices of gas, plunging prices of frack services end up leading to an antitrust investigation?

Charles, here's what really bothers me about this, in the wake of the IRS targeting scandal going after opponents that President Obama maligned. I don't trust other arms of the Obama administration not to seek opponent base on the political agenda. We know this administration hates fracking and is against it. Now your Justice Department is investigating antitrust in a market where prices fall?

PAYNE: Well, here's the thing, Jonathan. They better be very careful because fracking, to your point, has been the economic godsend. If they mess around with that the only reason this country is not in a recession right now. If you take away the fracking miracle, we would be in a deep recession.

HOENIG: Indeed. I mean, Charles, it is fracking and its energy production in general. I mean, there are so much energy resources available to help power this country's economy forward. Unfortunately, it is not the earth that we seemed to battle so often. It's the regulators themselves, they don't want that what to make that process as difficult as possible.

PAYNE: I tell you what there will be no manufacturing renaissance without cheap fuel. By the way, if you control fossil fuel, you control the world. Finally, guys, this is a fun one. (Inaudible) because Wolverine is expected to hit the snap the summer slump streak. I know he's my man. Dennis, all right, these big budget movies have been dead. What about this?

KNEALE: Well, you know, we have had some huge successes, but we also have some huge flops in Hollywood feels like "Wolverine" to the rescue. It could bring in $80 million this weekend. It cost $120 million to make, but understand we've had four flops in a row, "Long Ranger, White House Down, Pacific Rim and RIPD," those four films combined cost almost $700 million to make and their U.S. gross so far is well under $300 million and the studios keep only half of that 300.

PAYNE: OK, but you would put your money on Hugh Jackman, right?

KNEALE: Yes.

PAYNE: This is the only action figure you still see. What do you think, Jonathan?

HOENIG: Well, I mean, I thought trading stocks was dangerous and risky, Charles. I mean, the movie businesses, to Dennis' point is far more risky $120 million put in this film? I had to say though I think it will do well. "Wolverine" like all these Avengers characters has this broad appeal. It's the old folks remember from their childhood and it's a lot of new consumers. So despite the fact there's a lot of competition out there for movie dollars I think "Wolverine" soars and has a great opening weekend.

PAYNE: A lot of people say the blockbuster model is dead.

KNEALE: We always think the way of doing business is going to be invented.

PAYNE: But at the end of the day don't they want to make profits in Hollywood?

KNEALE: There words, "Iron Man Three" $1.2 billion and you can't shake a stick of that.

PAYNE: You guys are fantastic. Really appreciate it. Health care is looking so bad, government workers who are going to work on the law are actually trying to avoid being covered by that same law. We'll figure.

PAYNE: Family doctors are selling and that's driving prices up. More hospitals are buying private practices and a new study says this could drive up cost by as much as 20 percent.

Dr. Leigh Vinocur says that is the latest bad news courtesy of the health care law. Doctor, thanks for joining the show. You know, I've been hearing about this and I am shocked at some of the numbers. I mean, this is big time thing a lot of hospitals, a lot of private physicians are just selling out.

DR. LEIGH VINOCUR, EMERGENCY ROOM PHYSICIAN: Yes. Well, it is predicted that two-thirds of the 1 million doctors in 2014 will be salaried and working for some health care system or some hospital because it's frankly getting to the point where doctors cannot afford to be in solo practice that's a thing of the past. The structure from the affordable care act is changing for repayment. So these accountable care organizations are starting up and doctors are having to join them.

PAYNE: Of course, that means -- the idea that you are going to stick with your doctor will probably change dramatically. The idea that will give lower prices changes dramatically because economics 101, the last competition that there is, the higher prices typically go.

VINOCUR: Well, theoretically that is true. But health care sort of never kind of fit really neatly in that supply-side economics. You know, it is going to be precarious. I am anxious to see what is going to happen because there is going to be penalties if the quality goes down and with these accountable care organizations, there's going to be one pot. It's going to be like a decapitated payment. So they get one pie for the patient and if they use it up because the costs have gotten higher. Then that is the end of it. So, you know, they could be shooting themselves in the foot by doing this, but we will see how it works out.

PAYNE: It is interesting because that is the risk they're apparently willing to take because the alternative they know already would be a lot worse.

VINOCUR: Well, there is not going to be a lot of fee-for-service anymore. It is kind of changing the way reimbursement is and you know, solo practitioners just start making it any more, I mean, their reimbursement fees are going down. There's cut, more and more cuts are going to be into Medicare and then they cannot afford the malpractice and running the office.

So that's what doctors are saying and these accountable care organizations are what this affordable care act is promoting. So you have to be a part of it to get reimbursed.

PAYNE: So Dr. Vinocur, this is the thing I think a lot of people are concerned about, there is a big difference between health care insurance and quality -- access to real quality health care. It sounds like what was already a numbers problem bringing 30 million more people into the system, it is going to even be worse than probably even imagined.

VINOCUR: Well, I mean, that is a very good point. I've been saying that for a long time. Just because you have health insurance doesn't mean that you have access to care. What we saw in Massachusetts is once everybody got coverage, there weren't enough primary-care doctors and that is the problem that the affordable care act doesn't address.

There is a predicted shortage of almost a hundred thousand doctors coming up by 2020 and unless we get more primary-care doctors involved and have better access for people to go, it doesn't matter if you have insurance if you cannot find a doctor to take care of you.

PAYNE: Absolutely. You know, of course, some changes have already been made. The president just made a change with the employer mandate. Do you think at the very least, forgetting about political ideology, at the very least though this is something that probably should be pushed back the entire thing and rethought a little bit?

VINOCUR: Well, you know what? It is already starting to go in motion. Insurance companies are already planning these products. People that are getting insurance today are being told. So I think it is probably too late to turn back. And the biggest issue is there was a pool of patients that didn't get insurance, that had too many illnesses and they couldn't get insured.

But for it to work you need this pool of healthy, young individuals that are going to buy insurance and you know, if you're only paying a $95 penalty and if January 1st there's a law that says it doesn't matter if you have a pre-existing condition. It doesn't make sense. I can't see a young person paying $300 and $400 a month just in case they need it. They might as well just pay the $95 penalty once and wait until they need it so I'm not sure how it's going to work because of that.

PAYNE: You know, I mean, that is pure logic and we know it's going to happen and to your point, we don't know how bad it's going to be, but this thing is going to have some real ugly moments without a doubt. Thank you for lending us your expertise and we appreciated.

VINOCUR: My pleasure.

PAYNE: You know, Senator Harry Reid, he strikes again. This time telling Republicans that there will be no tax reform until he gets this, $1 trillion in tax hikes. Democrats holding tax reform for ransom that's next.

PAYNE: What do tax hikes have to do with tax reform? For Senator Harry Reid, everything, the Democratic majority leader says he wants nearly $1 trillion in new revenue as a starting point, this on a day where the pope is scolding the rich pay up as well, telling a crowd in Brazil that they have to bridge the gap on incomes of haves and have-nots.

Dee Dee Benkie, Rick Ungar and Liz MacDonald back on the war on the rich. Lizzie.

LIZ MACDONALD, FOX BUSINESS: I think Harry Reid should resign. I love how Americans are treated like tax cheats because they are not paying their fair share when the government has blown over $1 trillion and not selling their real estate, empty building that should have at the top of the market.

I'm telling you they have been hitting the middle class really hard this administration. They are the worst administration overseeing economic -- worse economic growth since the great depression. I mean, we've got job growth that is basically service sector jobs at minimum wage.

To think that you could take $1 trillion more out of the American people's pocket and that is going to create middle class job, that's not the way to go.

PAYNE: Rick, what do you make of the pope, who's now, his nickname is the slum pope. The guy walks to the worst neighborhoods of Brazil. He's applauded and he's been pretty adamant about wealth or the wealthy doing more. What do you make about that message?

RICK UNGAR, PROGRESSIVE COLUMNIST: Listen, I am not a Catholic, but this pope is so cool. I've actually giving it some thought. I love this guy.

DEE DEE BENKIE, FORMER BUSH 43 WHITE HOUSE AIDE: May I interrupt? Since you're rich and I'm poor, give me $50 right now.

UNGAR: What was I saying? I love this guy, but what's going to be fascinating though is people -- Catholic businesspeople who made the big fuss based on their religion about contraception and Obamacare, how will they deal with this issue in terms of how they pay their own workers in light of what the pope says?

PAYNE: I don't know. I just think the idea that you just answered it yourself. The fact that I am a business owner and providing jobs and opportunity for someone should put me in a positive light with the pope. The pope is talking about the super wealthy doing more that is his position, but the fact of the matter and I'm glad we're talking about this because this was debate all year last year, what is rich, what's not rich. The fact of the matter is in capitalism, people who create opportunities for themselves typically have duty.

BENKIE: I don't think anyone -- you are rich and I am for so give the many. That is not right. That is not the way that it should be they create the jobs and businesses that it is how they do not just hand over money that doesn't help anybody.

MACDONALD: As a practicing Catholic, I want to tell the pope listen American taxpayers are paying between 60 or 70 percent of the federal tax revenues in this country. We have the most aggressive income tax system this is not about spending wealth, but creating wealth you do not do that by taxing.

PAYNE: We have a crisis of selfishness and individualism's year and have to be wealthy to be selfish. I think someone who is sitting at home sucking up government benefits all day long that is another forum.

UNGAR: I don't disagree for one second. But selfishness is when you look at people working in the same company who earn 500 percent or 600 percent more than the lowest person on the rank and feel no trouble with the fact that person cannot supply a his family with food and have to go on Medicaid. That is what he is talking about.

BENKIE: Those people should be paid well.

UNGAR: They let people work in this business?

BENKIE: That is capitalism.

MACDONALD: He is trying to unite. This president and this White House and congressman like Senator Harry Reid are the most divisive politicians even Reagan and Clinton reached across the aisle and try to get bipartisan agreement. It is striking that this president who is a Nobel Peace Prize winner is one of the most divisive president in recent history.

PAYNE: I think both the president and the pope are in the same position where they have to recruit more followers. In Brazil, 90 percent of the people used to be Catholic. It's down to 57 so you need a hard message, but in America what is the president trying to accomplish? It feels like he is ripping us apart.

UNGAR: I have to say apparently the president was able to recruit enough followers to still be president. You want to throw that out the window for some reason.

PAYNE: He talks about Washington as if it is separate from him. What are you talking about?

UNGAR: Talking about those guys sitting in the House of Representatives who will not let him do a thing. Anything he sends --

MACDONALD: Every second term president has to deal with an opposition party and one legislative party.

PAYNE: Audience, thank you for your support. It's been fun two weeks. A lot of people called and e-mailed. By the way, your man, the main man, Neil, he'll be back on Monday.

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX HOST: Thirty-six days out and time some Democrats are already teeing a lot more spending up. Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. And never mind, we haven't even gotten to the first debate.

Some Democrats are already laying out their spending plans for a second Obama term's first day. Vermont Democratic Congressman Peter Welch wants to get back to an energy policy that acknowledges the climate change is real. For now, he is leaving out the price tag to address it, which Republicans predict will be unreal. California Democrat Mike Honda wants to refocus on health care to expand on increasingly cost days and state days insurance exchanges.

Arizona's Raul Grijalva favors a conservative push on immigration reform. Still, others interpret any Obama win as a referendum for more stimulus out of the middle-class, good or bad, depending on your political point of view. More taxes are on the rich to help pay for regardless of your point of view.

So get ready for it. They are already licking their financial chops planning for it. Never mind, you haven't even cast your vote.

It seems a lot of politicians are already grabbing for your wallet. Not much talk about getting this debt under control -- lots of talk, though, about, as we say, getting the very spending that helped get it out of debt and into debt out of control, an issue now that worries two former titans of the Senate, Democrat Sam Nunn and Republican Bob Bennett, thereby partisan red (ph) is coming up first to some worry post-election watchers right now.

Fox News Digital Political Editor, Chris Stirewalt and townhall.com's Katie Pavlich.

Chris, what are we to make about sort of these plans for a second Obama administration -- might not come to pass, but they're getting their spending priorities in order.

CHRIS STIREWALT, DIGITAL POLITICAL EDITOR, FOX NEWS: Well, look, Neil, the -- the thing that the president is very clearly doing in this reelection campaign is being very vague. And while Democrats accuse Mitt Romney of being vague, the president has intentionally talked only in general about the need for infrastructure and other stimulus kind of spending and the need for what he says will be a tax increase on top earners to pay for it.

But when you get down to specifics, you don't need -- you don't hear very much about what it would be. Part of the reason for that is that the president knows that there are a lot of people with their hands out.

There are a lot of people with ideas for how that money ought to be spent. And one concern that he has aside from frightening moderate voters with more spending is creating this line up at the trough for lawmakers from his own Party that would be looking for the second term to be even more lavish than the first.

CAVUTO: So you think that will be the case, Katie?

KATIE PAVLICH, TOWNHALL.COM: I think it could be. But based on, you know, what these Democrats have already lined up in terms of what they want for a second Obama term, it does seem a little bit out of touch because as we know, more spending when you're spending outside of your means -- we have $16 trillion in debt -- just means the expansion of government.

And poll after poll shows that the American people and American voters are concerned about how big the federal government has been getting. And I hear a lot of repeats in what they're asking for.

President Obama may not be, you know, implementing an environmental policy that's directly geared toward climate change, but you look at the EPA's policies under President Obama. And they're geared towards addressing climate change in terms of regulations on coal mines.

And in terms of immigration reform, we've seen President Obama work on the dream act. And we just saw his executive order that was very similar to that piece of legislation.

So it's kind of a repeat of what we've already seen and I would say a little bit out of touch with what people are concerned about right now.

CAVUTO: I wonder, Chris, if it's part of this -- the perceived victor's already claiming these polls. I suppose if Mitt Romney were the runaway favorite right now and you're in the defense establishment, you are seizing on keeping open those facilities and military contracts or jobs that could be imperiled as a result of even automatic sequestration.

So are we just seeing something we always see, just more obvious now or what?

STIREWALT: Well, I certainly think there is truth in that. And on the Republican side, Neil, what you'd expect right now would be a lot of calls for Romney to move right and position himself so that there would be cuts and that there would be things like that.

You might hear social issues crop up. But I think for the president, what this is -- we saw a poll today that was conducted for the Hill that said that 87 percent of Democrats are confident that the president's going to win.

And certainly, it is not helpful to the president's chances of winning for Democrats to be talking about new spending now at a time when people are very concerned about debt and deficit. But as these folks continue to believe that their man is going to carry the day on November 6, they probably want to get in line first.

CAVUTO: I'm just wondering, if there's always the risk when word lot (ph) of this leaks out, that they look like they're, you know, decorating the office before they're guaranteed they're going to have it, Katie. Now, if you're Barack Obama, you already have it.

So what's to stop you from saying, I might look at that new rug or what have you. But you know what I mean. There does seem to be a sense that -- that, you know, that they are planning for a victory that might not happen.

And if this gets out, then it could strike a lot of voters as, at the very least, arrogant.

PAVLICH: Well, I think, too, that they're forgetting that President Obama isn't the only piece of the puzzle. You still have a Republican House which Republicans look like they're going to hold onto the House.

And if Mitt Romney loses, well, let Paul Ryan is still going to be the budget chairman. And so Democrats can line up all these big spending initiatives if they want to.

But the fact is that the House is still going to be majority Republicans. If Republicans don't take back the Senate, it's going to be the same situation that we've had for the past two years.

And I would say, if they're going to go as far as trying to, as you say, decorate the office before they have it, well, we might see another turnaround election in the year 2014, like we did in 2010, if they continue to push this big spending, big government ideas going forward.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Wait a minute, you're not giving up on -- you're not giving up on 2012. It almost sounded like you were there.

PAVLICH: Well, I'm just simply saying, if they're going to go decorating the office, see (ph).

CAVUTO: OK. Guys, thank you both very, very much.

PAVLICH: Thank you.

STIREWALT: You got it.

CAVUTO: And well, don't look now, but he is back. Remember Ross and his charts 20 years later, back with a vengeance, and now, a new warning -- so deep in debt. Ross Perot fears we're easy baked (ph) to be taken down.

A former Clinton Press Secretary, Debate Commission Co-Chair, Mike McCurry on those warnings from a guy who two decades ago almost up-ended the presidential race.

Michael, very good to have you.

MICHAEL MCCURRY, FMR. CLINTON PRESS SECRETARY: Good to be with you.

CAVUTO: I remember Mikey and his charts -- I remember Bill Clinton responding to that, addressing that. And many will argue, it was your boss who did address some of those same debt issues that Perot claimed fame for.

But Perot is back saying, both Parties have let him down. I think he goes on to say that he doesn't like other guy and that both Parties have essentially risked throwing the country down the drain. Is that resonating?

MCCURRY: Well, I think that's classically Ross Perot. And I think, you know, that would be an attitude you expect him to have. But look, there is an opportunity with these debates on Wednesday night to get to some of the specifics that, you know, some of your commentators say are missing.

We're hoping that the format we have for these debates will get back beyond some of these slogans and the traditional talking points we're hearing from some of the candidates and get into a more substantive discussion. We're designing it that way.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Are they allowed charts, Mike? They can't bring charts like Ross Perot, right? So they have to tell it.

MCCURRY: It's a good question. The two campaigns have been in discussions with each other. The commission kinds of take a hands-off view...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I see.

MCCURRY: ...of that. I don't know if they've got an agreement on that. But we've seen both Governor Romney and President Obama use charts from time to time.

CAVUTO: Sure.

MCCURRY: So we'll tune in and we'll see what happens.

CAVUTO: You know, one of the things that I remember about the debates in '92 with Bill Clinton and others who have sort of mastered this as trying to get a complicated stuff across easily, particularly (ph), Ronald Reagan had this knack as well on the Republican side, to take complicated material and synthesize it for the people.

I mean, in this case, it would be a lot more money going out than is coming in. So I think to your old boss's credit, he would say, we have to address both Republicans, he'd been saying, now just to address all that money that's going out, address spending.

But how do you encapsulate that in a one-minute or 90-second rebuttal response to a point on spending?

MCCURRY: Well, that's the point. You really can't. So that's why we have redesigned the format of these debates so that there will be 15-minute chunks. And the candidates have to address the topic.

Now, Jim Lehrer, who will be moderating...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...the debate on Wednesday night has already said, the first three subjects will be the economy, the economy, the economy. And then the fourth subject will be health care -- obviously, Medicare, financing, and health care financing, a big issue. And then to what your panelists were just talking about, the fifth topic will be the role of government.

And I think this goes, if you want to, you know, think about how to simplify the debate a little bit, one of my other old bosses, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said, look, the quintessential question for the American people is how much government do we really want?

And how much are we really willing to pay for? That's a pretty simple set of questions. And that's really the heart of the debate they're going to have.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But I think you're right. I think that's what every election -- if you think about, it comes down -- unless you're in the middle of a crisis, but to that point, Mike, when you say, the 15 minutes, you address these in chunks, they are still timed on answers to each question.

So can -- can they go at each other, you know, unencumbered by a moderator or, you know, something that gets in the way of them getting at each other?

MCCURRY: Absolutely. I mean, the only ground rule is that there will be a question posed in each -- at the beginning of each segment to each candidate. And they get about two minutes to go, you know, to lay out what they have to say on an issue like the deficit, like infrastructure...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...like the economy. And then -- then they really are going to be asked by the moderator, I'm sure, to sort of let's flush this out a little bit. Let's talk about it.

There is some -- we need some more specifics here. And we'll see how both candidates respond.

Now, I have to make clear, it's not up to our commission to decide how that conversation...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...is structured. It'll really be up to the moderator, Jim Lehrer. But you know, knowing...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But would the moderator going to have to say you didn't answer that question or you didn't give me a specific answer or after one or two tries, does he say, well, this is going nowhere fast. I'm onto...

MCCURRY: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...the next thing.

MCCURRY: I'll say this. If you just -- if you only walk into that debate with a lot of zingers or one-liners or sound bytes, you're not going to be able to fill up the, you know, the chunk of time that's going to be around that -- that debate. So I think it'll be -- I'm hoping it'll be an opportunity for both Governor Romney and President Obama to really have a textured conversation about this.

And then more importantly, to get to those philosophical differences that clearly they have on what the role of government should be.

CAVUTO: I'm looking forward to it. Mike, thank you very much. Good seeing you.

MCCURRY: Nice seeing you. Good to be with you.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, by the way, we will be out live, 8:00 p.m until midnight this Wednesday for that Denver opening debate. And we'll be covering back (ph) all the debates right here on Fox Business.

Meanwhile, get ready for the October surprise, only it might be a number, not a blunder. I'm going to explain. There is a difference. But it could be China that turns the election around by taking our economy down. And it would take only a few guys to do it. and the old-timer says Washington is running out of time. Former Senators Bob Bennett and Sam Nunn are having none of it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: It's October 1st. Do you know where your election surprise is? To hear political pundits tell it, you can count on it -- the gap or crisis that will tip the selection one way or the other.

But what if it's not a misstep that does it but just a boring old economic number that ultimately decides it? Todd Schoenberger and Sandra Smith on the data that could pull a doozy at the polls.

Todd, it could be any host of data, right?

TODD SCHOENBERGER, MANAGING DIRECTOR, LANDCOLT TRADING: That's right. I mean, we've just had the GDP -- the report card on the U.S. economy, came in very low. We have the upcoming jobs report.
