NEIL CAVUTO, FOX HOST: Thirty-six days out and time some Democrats are already teeing a lot more spending up. Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. And never mind, we haven't even gotten to the first debate.

Some Democrats are already laying out their spending plans for a second Obama term's first day. Vermont Democratic Congressman Peter Welch wants to get back to an energy policy that acknowledges the climate change is real. For now, he is leaving out the price tag to address it, which Republicans predict will be unreal. California Democrat Mike Honda wants to refocus on health care to expand on increasingly cost days and state days insurance exchanges.

Arizona's Raul Grijalva favors a conservative push on immigration reform. Still, others interpret any Obama win as a referendum for more stimulus out of the middle-class, good or bad, depending on your political point of view. More taxes are on the rich to help pay for regardless of your point of view.

So get ready for it. They are already licking their financial chops planning for it. Never mind, you haven't even cast your vote.

It seems a lot of politicians are already grabbing for your wallet. Not much talk about getting this debt under control -- lots of talk, though, about, as we say, getting the very spending that helped get it out of debt and into debt out of control, an issue now that worries two former titans of the Senate, Democrat Sam Nunn and Republican Bob Bennett, thereby partisan red (ph) is coming up first to some worry post-election watchers right now.

Fox News Digital Political Editor, Chris Stirewalt and townhall.com's Katie Pavlich.

Chris, what are we to make about sort of these plans for a second Obama administration -- might not come to pass, but they're getting their spending priorities in order.

CHRIS STIREWALT, DIGITAL POLITICAL EDITOR, FOX NEWS: Well, look, Neil, the -- the thing that the president is very clearly doing in this reelection campaign is being very vague. And while Democrats accuse Mitt Romney of being vague, the president has intentionally talked only in general about the need for infrastructure and other stimulus kind of spending and the need for what he says will be a tax increase on top earners to pay for it.

But when you get down to specifics, you don't need -- you don't hear very much about what it would be. Part of the reason for that is that the president knows that there are a lot of people with their hands out.

There are a lot of people with ideas for how that money ought to be spent. And one concern that he has aside from frightening moderate voters with more spending is creating this line up at the trough for lawmakers from his own Party that would be looking for the second term to be even more lavish than the first.

CAVUTO: So you think that will be the case, Katie?

KATIE PAVLICH, TOWNHALL.COM: I think it could be. But based on, you know, what these Democrats have already lined up in terms of what they want for a second Obama term, it does seem a little bit out of touch because as we know, more spending when you're spending outside of your means -- we have $16 trillion in debt -- just means the expansion of government.

And poll after poll shows that the American people and American voters are concerned about how big the federal government has been getting. And I hear a lot of repeats in what they're asking for.

President Obama may not be, you know, implementing an environmental policy that's directly geared toward climate change, but you look at the EPA's policies under President Obama. And they're geared towards addressing climate change in terms of regulations on coal mines.

And in terms of immigration reform, we've seen President Obama work on the dream act. And we just saw his executive order that was very similar to that piece of legislation.

So it's kind of a repeat of what we've already seen and I would say a little bit out of touch with what people are concerned about right now.

CAVUTO: I wonder, Chris, if it's part of this -- the perceived victor's already claiming these polls. I suppose if Mitt Romney were the runaway favorite right now and you're in the defense establishment, you are seizing on keeping open those facilities and military contracts or jobs that could be imperiled as a result of even automatic sequestration.

So are we just seeing something we always see, just more obvious now or what?

STIREWALT: Well, I certainly think there is truth in that. And on the Republican side, Neil, what you'd expect right now would be a lot of calls for Romney to move right and position himself so that there would be cuts and that there would be things like that.

You might hear social issues crop up. But I think for the president, what this is -- we saw a poll today that was conducted for the Hill that said that 87 percent of Democrats are confident that the president's going to win.

And certainly, it is not helpful to the president's chances of winning for Democrats to be talking about new spending now at a time when people are very concerned about debt and deficit. But as these folks continue to believe that their man is going to carry the day on November 6, they probably want to get in line first.

CAVUTO: I'm just wondering, if there's always the risk when word lot (ph) of this leaks out, that they look like they're, you know, decorating the office before they're guaranteed they're going to have it, Katie. Now, if you're Barack Obama, you already have it.

So what's to stop you from saying, I might look at that new rug or what have you. But you know what I mean. There does seem to be a sense that -- that, you know, that they are planning for a victory that might not happen.

And if this gets out, then it could strike a lot of voters as, at the very least, arrogant.

PAVLICH: Well, I think, too, that they're forgetting that President Obama isn't the only piece of the puzzle. You still have a Republican House which Republicans look like they're going to hold onto the House.

And if Mitt Romney loses, well, let Paul Ryan is still going to be the budget chairman. And so Democrats can line up all these big spending initiatives if they want to.

But the fact is that the House is still going to be majority Republicans. If Republicans don't take back the Senate, it's going to be the same situation that we've had for the past two years.

And I would say, if they're going to go as far as trying to, as you say, decorate the office before they have it, well, we might see another turnaround election in the year 2014, like we did in 2010, if they continue to push this big spending, big government ideas going forward.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Wait a minute, you're not giving up on -- you're not giving up on 2012. It almost sounded like you were there.

PAVLICH: Well, I'm just simply saying, if they're going to go decorating the office, see (ph).

CAVUTO: OK. Guys, thank you both very, very much.

PAVLICH: Thank you.

STIREWALT: You got it.

CAVUTO: And well, don't look now, but he is back. Remember Ross and his charts 20 years later, back with a vengeance, and now, a new warning -- so deep in debt. Ross Perot fears we're easy baked (ph) to be taken down.

A former Clinton Press Secretary, Debate Commission Co-Chair, Mike McCurry on those warnings from a guy who two decades ago almost up-ended the presidential race.

Michael, very good to have you.

MICHAEL MCCURRY, FMR. CLINTON PRESS SECRETARY: Good to be with you.

CAVUTO: I remember Mikey and his charts -- I remember Bill Clinton responding to that, addressing that. And many will argue, it was your boss who did address some of those same debt issues that Perot claimed fame for.

But Perot is back saying, both Parties have let him down. I think he goes on to say that he doesn't like other guy and that both Parties have essentially risked throwing the country down the drain. Is that resonating?

MCCURRY: Well, I think that's classically Ross Perot. And I think, you know, that would be an attitude you expect him to have. But look, there is an opportunity with these debates on Wednesday night to get to some of the specifics that, you know, some of your commentators say are missing.

We're hoping that the format we have for these debates will get back beyond some of these slogans and the traditional talking points we're hearing from some of the candidates and get into a more substantive discussion. We're designing it that way.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Are they allowed charts, Mike? They can't bring charts like Ross Perot, right? So they have to tell it.

MCCURRY: It's a good question. The two campaigns have been in discussions with each other. The commission kinds of take a hands-off view...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I see.

MCCURRY: ...of that. I don't know if they've got an agreement on that. But we've seen both Governor Romney and President Obama use charts from time to time.

CAVUTO: Sure.

MCCURRY: So we'll tune in and we'll see what happens.

CAVUTO: You know, one of the things that I remember about the debates in '92 with Bill Clinton and others who have sort of mastered this as trying to get a complicated stuff across easily, particularly (ph), Ronald Reagan had this knack as well on the Republican side, to take complicated material and synthesize it for the people.

I mean, in this case, it would be a lot more money going out than is coming in. So I think to your old boss's credit, he would say, we have to address both Republicans, he'd been saying, now just to address all that money that's going out, address spending.

But how do you encapsulate that in a one-minute or 90-second rebuttal response to a point on spending?

MCCURRY: Well, that's the point. You really can't. So that's why we have redesigned the format of these debates so that there will be 15-minute chunks. And the candidates have to address the topic.

Now, Jim Lehrer, who will be moderating...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...the debate on Wednesday night has already said, the first three subjects will be the economy, the economy, the economy. And then the fourth subject will be health care -- obviously, Medicare, financing, and health care financing, a big issue. And then to what your panelists were just talking about, the fifth topic will be the role of government.

And I think this goes, if you want to, you know, think about how to simplify the debate a little bit, one of my other old bosses, Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said, look, the quintessential question for the American people is how much government do we really want?

And how much are we really willing to pay for? That's a pretty simple set of questions. And that's really the heart of the debate they're going to have.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But I think you're right. I think that's what every election -- if you think about, it comes down -- unless you're in the middle of a crisis, but to that point, Mike, when you say, the 15 minutes, you address these in chunks, they are still timed on answers to each question.

So can -- can they go at each other, you know, unencumbered by a moderator or, you know, something that gets in the way of them getting at each other?

MCCURRY: Absolutely. I mean, the only ground rule is that there will be a question posed in each -- at the beginning of each segment to each candidate. And they get about two minutes to go, you know, to lay out what they have to say on an issue like the deficit, like infrastructure...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...like the economy. And then -- then they really are going to be asked by the moderator, I'm sure, to sort of let's flush this out a little bit. Let's talk about it.

There is some -- we need some more specifics here. And we'll see how both candidates respond.

Now, I have to make clear, it's not up to our commission to decide how that conversation...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...is structured. It'll really be up to the moderator, Jim Lehrer. But you know, knowing...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But would the moderator going to have to say you didn't answer that question or you didn't give me a specific answer or after one or two tries, does he say, well, this is going nowhere fast. I'm onto...

MCCURRY: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...the next thing.

MCCURRY: I'll say this. If you just -- if you only walk into that debate with a lot of zingers or one-liners or sound bytes, you're not going to be able to fill up the, you know, the chunk of time that's going to be around that -- that debate. So I think it'll be -- I'm hoping it'll be an opportunity for both Governor Romney and President Obama to really have a textured conversation about this.

And then more importantly, to get to those philosophical differences that clearly they have on what the role of government should be.

CAVUTO: I'm looking forward to it. Mike, thank you very much. Good seeing you.

MCCURRY: Nice seeing you. Good to be with you.

CAVUTO: All right. Well, by the way, we will be out live, 8:00 p.m until midnight this Wednesday for that Denver opening debate. And we'll be covering back (ph) all the debates right here on Fox Business.

Meanwhile, get ready for the October surprise, only it might be a number, not a blunder. I'm going to explain. There is a difference. But it could be China that turns the election around by taking our economy down. And it would take only a few guys to do it. and the old-timer says Washington is running out of time. Former Senators Bob Bennett and Sam Nunn are having none of it.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: It's October 1st. Do you know where your election surprise is? To hear political pundits tell it, you can count on it -- the gap or crisis that will tip the selection one way or the other.

But what if it's not a misstep that does it but just a boring old economic number that ultimately decides it? Todd Schoenberger and Sandra Smith on the data that could pull a doozy at the polls.

Todd, it could be any host of data, right?

TODD SCHOENBERGER, MANAGING DIRECTOR, LANDCOLT TRADING: That's right. I mean, we've just had the GDP -- the report card on the U.S. economy, came in very low. We have the upcoming jobs report.

There are a couple of, clearly some time bombs there, that -- that can actually sway. It could be a game changer for the election. I personally think it's going to be higher oil prices.

I think this Middle East uprising is going to boil over. And if that's the case, you're going to see higher prices at the pump.

And as you know, Neil, voters vote with what's in their wallets. So if you take some cash out of those wallets, it could sway the election.

CAVUTO: Sandra, I always tend to think that things are kind of baked (ph) to do a cake when it comes to the economic numbers, that unless they're so awful or even so great that their way out of what was expected, it's -- it's not going to move the needle much.

SANDRA SMITH, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hey, but...

CAVUTO: What is the expectation for -- for something approaching that?

SMITH: Well, the two big jobs reports that we have from -- between now and the election, I mean, we saw last month a dismal jobs growth of 96,000 jobs. And Neil, we have another jobs report on Friday.

If we see anything above eight percent unemployment, which we're still there now, we've been hovering around that level -- if we see a jump in that unemployment, if we see another dismal jobs growth number, these markets are going to react.

And let me tell you something, Neil, when you look at the stock market and people go home and look at their 401ks here as we enter into this...

CAVUTO: Yes, yes.

SMITH: ...last quarter of the year, Neil, if we see a 10, 15 percent drop in the stock market, yet voters will react. And traders on the floor are warning that investors have become so complacent. The VIX is down 63 percent over the past year.

The stock market's up 15 percent this year. Between now and election day, we could see a significant sell-off in this market.

Voters will indeed react to that.

CAVUTO: But Todd, to Sandra's point, for now, a lot of them are looking at those statements and seeing that double-digit run-up depending on statement, depending on the 401(k), and they like what they see. And they might like what anecdotally they're getting out of sights at zillow.com and the rest that children (ph) at their homes are no longer at least imploding.

They're not exactly soaring. But they stopped, you know, tumbling. And is that enough in this environment where we tend to expect so little to help the president?

SCHOENBERGER: Well, let me tell you something, that's absolutely correct. Sandra's absolutely right. The next 30 to 45 days are absolutely critical. You had the average 401(k) balance in this country.

It's about a hundred and 7,000. Yes, but S&P -- it's up 14 percent plus year-to-date. If you see those gains evaporate, if they -- they go away because of poor macro headlines, higher oil prices, anything that's going to cut down on earnings, that would actually be the game-changer for voters because what they don't want to see is a brokerage statement and see these -- these numbers just start melting away.

And if that's the case, they probably will start to change, using their wallets, come election day.

CAVUTO: Do you know, Sandra, when you look at the data and the markets, and if the market's, our forward-looking mechanism and the markets, you know, it could be all over the map and the gyrations read (ph) today is notwithstanding, it is still the president's trend and friend.

Would an October surprise or like a -- cause pause, in other words, that they would just say, well, wait a minute, but barring that -- that the President dodges a financial bullet?

SMITH: But one could simply argue that the stock market is -- has been artificially propped up by the Fed's money printing measures...

CAVUTO: Right.

SMITH: ...and when the market looks forward, Neil, they look at earnings. And we're about to get the latest report on quarterly earnings.

And UBS just put out a very dramatic note, saying that they believe that we are going to enter earnings recession, meaning two straight quarters of negative earnings growth. Those are the fundamentals that should be driving the stock market.

We're still sort of in this euphoria period after quantitative easing...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: You're right.

SMITH: ...three by the Fed, to stimulate the market. What happens when we get those negative earnings report so for the next month or so?

CAVUTO: You know, real quickly, Todd, and then go over here a little bit, but I remember, 1980, there was a sounding (ph) point during that weekend before, when a lot of people just said, to hell with it. They had seen Ronald Reagan in the debate with Jimmy Carter, liked the idea that they could switch horses at that stage.

Even though they weren't sure then, he seemed to comfort himself well. They were ready to do it. They just tired of everything and needed a reason to just say, we're done. This guy's out.

Are we approaching anything like that now where -- where whatever...

SCHOENBERGER: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...we're seeing it boil (ph) now, could reverse dramatically?

SCHOENBERGER: Yes, because if you remember that time, American pride was even -- was down the tubes. I mean, the misery index was super high, as it is now, Neil. You know, we -- we actually get accustomed to seeing some of the -- you know, the new products from, say, in Apple.

And we start thinking, oh, everything's great. And then you hear from the politicians and you hear everything's in recovery mode. But it's simply not the case.

Main Street does not buy it. And if sentiment if poor, the jobs picture continues to be weak, then yes, then leading up to this election, you have 30-plus days left, Neil.

If people are not feeling well going into the election poll, going into the polls, that Tuesday, it's going to be pretty for -- for the incumbent.

CAVUTO: We shall see. Guys, thank you very, very much.

SMITH: Yes.

CAVUTO: Meanwhile, how is this for an October surprise -- a hack attack that could be a huge setback for the entire economy -- the guy who says that he's closer than you think?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: A red alert at the White House. We are learning that Chinese hackers breached a computer at the White House's military office. Now, the White House is saying no -- no harm was done.

But this is just the latest hack attack -- cyber crooks just hitting several major U.S. banks. So Homeland Security Adviser, Michael who says this is a bigger economic threat than the military one it would obviously pose. Explain what you mean by that?

MICHAEL BALBONI, FMR. HOMELAND SECURITY ADVISER: We, in a society, we do everything now digitally. And when you think about the -- the past, I mean, even companies like eHarmony, with those breaches, more and more what the attacks have been about is not only taking information but distorting it as well.

And the recent attacks against the banks just point out that this is the evolution. You know, Congress has been wrestling with this for the last couple of years.

And they cannot get out of their own way to say, how do we set a standard, how do we get information shared about these attacks? And how do we make American businesses and society more resilient and less vulnerable to these types of attacks?

CAVUTO: But they keep happening, right? I figure, you know, it happens that, you know, a mid-sized company -- even one of these large companies, it worries whether it happens to a big tech company because then I'd say, well, you're tech if you can't figure it out then for god's sake, how can anyone else?

BALBONI: Right. Very true, yes, absolutely. They can have the budgets from the I.T.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But now, what happens to a government computer, I mean, and it goes all the way to the White House and they say, well, you know, technically, this is just like a phishing expedition quite literally where they plant a virus-plagued mail and it disrupts the computer. Well, they planted a virus mail and it disrupted a computer. End of story.

BALBONI: Well, the problem with any of the governmental structures that -- the I.T. structures is that it all relies on one component -- the same component. And that is a human element.

And oftentimes, what happens, even though we assume that everybody from the folks in the White House on down to the Department of Defense, to any other of the governmental agencies, everybody knows what they're doing when it comes to e-mail and how to deal with the computer systems.

What we're really finding out is they don't know as much as they should. And so every opportunity that the hackers can have to find somebody that they can infiltrate and get them to open up one of these e-mails and download a malicious payload is all you need to -- to prevent and to start an attack. And preventing it is really difficult.

CAVUTO: But Michael, why are the Chinese so blatant about it? I mean, they're -- in a thousand U.S. corporation instances, to say nothing of repeated government attacks, it's as if they set up shop at a Starbucks and are doing it in broad daylight. And they're not even denying it.

They say, oh, what do we do about that?

BALBONI: Well, look, the Chinese government has been very open about the fact that they hire young students. They train them to do hacking. They train them to go into the computer systems and decide how the United States and the rest of the world does their cyber business, go in and get that information and take it for their own use...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Well, where do you see this going, Michael? How far does this go? What do you see happening?

BALBONI: And actually -- and actually, the information I've received about some of the bank attacks -- the recent bank attacks is that there's a more disturbing evolution here. And that is that it's not just the attack where you go after a Web site, and you try to take down the Web site through a denial service attack.

You basically wall it off, or you try to insert some malicious code there. But they're actually going after the domain names, in other words, the infrastructure of cyber security world.

And what's so disturbing about that is that now, you can take the information. And yes, you could stop it. But you could also distort it.

And that now, when you have a consumer-based cyber security or cyber network, where you do all your cyber business, what do you do if you say, you get onto your bank account and now, everything's gone. What happens if we lose confidence in our cyber system in this nation? That's an economic ruin.

CAVUTO: Well, well-pointed out, Michael. Thank you very much.

Meanwhile, ignore all the polls. Focus instead on how many might be going to the polls.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Halftime, are Democrats the ones who are going to get throttled? Now, you don't see that certainly in most polls. But you do see it in the number of Democrats who, so far, aren't planning to go to those polls, because compared to this time in 2008, not a whole lot of jazzed Democrats in 2012, at least not nearly as many, in Ohio, 490,000 -- fewer folks registered compared to four years ago.

And 44 percent of them in Cleveland and surrounding Cuyahoga County where Democrats are a two to one advantage over Republicans. Another survey -- this one by a left-leaning think tank, Third Way, shows similar Democrat voter registration declines in Florida, Iowa and New Hampshire.

And that is not to say, the president still doesn't lead in polls in these states and might win big of these states -- just the Democrats' tepid get- out the vote campaign might not translate into victories in these states, not if their own troops don't even bother showing up.

And if passion is a factor, is the president a possible loser in swing states where he, right now, looks like a winner? Hard to say, this much is not. If the key to victory is jazzing your base, the president is not.

And that's not to say that Mitt Romney has. But by comparison, the number of Republican registered voters is about the same, if not slightly hire than in 2008.

Who knows what any of this means? And who knows whether all these registered voters surveys failed to appreciate the influence of just plain old independents who presently align themselves with neither Party.

Let's just say, for the president and for Democrats, a sign they should hold off on that Party. So our question tonight is this -- if so many Democrats aren't coming back, who says Mitt Romney really is that far back?

GOP Strategist, Cheri -- Cheri, I think I know what you're going to say. But what do you say?

CHERI JACOBUS, PRESIDENT, CAPITOL STRATEGIES: Well, I do think there are some problems with the polling. A lot of people are looking at the 2008 models, Neil. And that's not the way to go. Obama voters and Democrats were very energized in 2008. And they're not now. So a lot of people talk about registered voters, as if they're all going to the poll. And you have to look at likely voters.

And even then, I think we have some problems. In 2010, pollsters were way off. They really could not have predicted that Republicans would have picked up a net of 63 House seats and six in the Senate. It was kind of a surprise. And we even saw this in '94. I don't think Newt Gingrich really expected to be speaker in '94. It was...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: No, no, no, there is historic precedent to divide (ph) kind of getting it wrong. I don't know -- well, it's a Machiavelli in plan, I doubt that. But I will say this -- that in some states, and it's still early, as you remind me, it is beyond the margin for sampling error. By that, I mean...

JACOBUS: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...if -- if Barack Obama is up eight to 10 points, even allowing for whatever statistical bias you see, Mitt Romney should be worried, right?

JACOBUS: Well, he should be worried. But again, it doesn't make sense. Nationally, you've got this race statistically tied, Romney just a couple of points down.

And you see that in poll after poll. And now, you're looking at these battleground states where we're hearing, you know, Obama is so far ahead. It doesn't make sense, Neil, because those battleground states are probably about 25 or 20 percent of the entire votes.

So there's something off right there. And I think that you have to look at maybe the 2010 models.

CAVUTO: Right.

JACOBUS: Again, it was an unexpected victory...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: And if you did that, Cheri, if you did that -- by the way, the counter to that argument would be in core states that are safe, Republican states, Texas comes to mind, some southern state Mitt Romney enjoys significant leads.

Is this typically the case where core states to each -- each candidate go their way? But having said that, do you think that there is room for a wide swing within those swing states? And if so, how significant would it be? Normally, the closer we get to the election, the less likely that is, although in 1980, it happened. But what do you see happening?

JACOBUS: Yes, well, look, you've got a president who's only got a 47 percent approval rating. If you are under 50 percent, and you're the incumbent and it's October, you've got big, big problems. So the case has been made for this -- for that why this president should be hired. The problem now is Romney has to make the case why he should be hired. But he has picked up in the past week or so with independence. So that's very good news for the Romney campaign.

So I think when you see these battleground states with the number so far -- with the margins so -- the distance between the two candidates so large, I -- I think that it's unlikely that it can be that stark in those states. So the numbers have to be off. It was seen that even in battleground states, even if there's some urban areas that tend to favor the Democrat, you have to look at likely voters -- the voters who are going to turn out.

CAVUTO: Yes.

JACOBUS: And again, Neil, if I'm a campaign -- seems to be relying just on getting voters angry, almost to the point of hatred. And you've got to keep them riled until election day and still get them out on election day - - very different from 2008 when it was very positive -- all hope, all change are very uplifting.

So that's a real challenge for the Democrats, for the Obama campaign to get those voters riled up again where they were almost euphoric in 2008. And now, they have to be so angry. That's -- that's a tough job.

CAVUTO: Yes. You want them registered at least. You want them out there set to vote. Cheri, thank you very much. Cheri Jacobus...

JACOBUS: Thank you.

CAVUTO: ...in Washington.

Well, Bill may sell the man. I want you to meet the Republican and the Democrat, who actually do the math.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

CLINTON: Now, people ask me all the time, how we got four surplus budgets in a row. What new ideas did we bring to Washington? I always give a one- word answer -- arithmetic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, we interrupt this political shouting for something that's exploding -- our debt. Ross Perot wasn't the only one coming back in a page one set in USA today, in fact, to say it's going to crush us. Two season of Washington veterans, Democrat and a Republican say, this keeps up.

Ross is actually understating it. We all go down. Here to spell it out, and the options we still have before time is up, former Georgia Democratic Senator Sam Nunn, and former Utah Republican Senator, Bob Bennett.

Welcome, gentleman, and an honor having both of you.

Senator Nunn, do you first, of course, long ago, you were reminding people of the dangers of this accumulating debt. But it's still accumulating. And I'm wondering if in this election year, it's an issue they're even bothering to address. If you had your druthers in this upcoming debate, what would your words be to both candidates?

SAM NUNN, FMR. SENATOR, (D) GEORGIA: Well, I would like for them to use common sense and honest arithmetic. And I'd like to see the candidates explain to the American people that we really do have a serious problem.

And all parts of the budget have to come under scrutiny. We have to play with a whole deck of cards.

But we particularly have to discuss, frankly, with the American people, that the entitlement programs simply cannot maintain the same trajectory. We're not going to cut people's Social Security or cut people's Medicare.

But we have to bend the coastline downward. Otherwise, we will simply not be able to sustain the programs that we have, and our country, with a fragile economic recovery, and a global environment that's very fragile, will be in deep difficulty.

No one can predict how long the bond markets will support American debt. But we're borrowing 40 cents, approximately out of every dollar that we spend today.

CAVUTO: Well, it will keep doing so as long as Ben Bernanke keeps this thing going again.

But Senator Bennett, I always think, and I know we've chatted about this before, sir, that -- that we live in an environment, where each party is captive to the extreme elements that don't want to budge and not even these varied -- either those extreme elements.

Well, on the Democratic side, to Senator Nunn's point, that if you're trying to rein in the growth of entitlements, you're overthrowing grandma off the cliff on your side.

And you experienced this first-hand, Senator, if you're trying to address, you know, closing loopholes and credits and allowances that allow some, to not pay the taxes at all, you're raising taxes so tea partiers hate you. So you can't move the ball forward, when that's how we're playing the game, can you?

BOB BENNETT, FMR. SENATOR, (R) UTAH: Well, there needs to be some honesty here. And Sam Nunn has got it exactly right. The challenge with entitlements, frankly, is not because of anything that Republicans have done, not because of anything the Democrats have done.

It's because of changing demographics in the country. And demographic trends are the most difficult trends to change. And they've been coming at us for years. And we've known this is coming for years. And we keep putting it off, saying, well, I'll just demagogue the issue in this election.

And then, we'll deal with it later on. Well, you can't do that. The baby boomer started retiring, started swelling the ranks, demographically of the people drawing entitlements in just a year -- 2008. So just as we have the problem that hit with us with the financial collapse that occurred in September of 2008, we saw the increases demands going up simply because...

CAVUTO: Yes.

BENNETT: ...we are an aging nation. Now...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: But you know, you explain that very clearly. I mean, you could be left or right and understand that that's an escapable truth. We're getting older, a lot more of a big crush of people, such at the same time, getting older, too. The -- the dynamics don't support what we've got right now.

But Senator Nunn, I'll address this in a Democratic perspective than a Republican perspective, the idea is you even try to slow that momentum in spending, and address that growth in population. You -- you are torpedoing benefits that are sacrosanct.

How do you get people around the notion you're trying to save those benefits or they're gone?

NUNN: Well, I don't think a torpedo should apply when you're treading a line that continues to grow up. You're just not making the trajectory as sharp.

We have to tell younger people, frankly, you're going to have to save more money because by the time you retire, the age of retirement may go up somewhat. That happens over a long period of time. And we may have to say on cost to living type adjustments over a long period of time...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Easy solutions, never offered -- never ever offered...

NUNN: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...never accepted by enough to get that ball moving forward.

NUNN: Well, they've been offered -- they've been offered on the floor of the Senate, even when I was there, several times a week...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Well, you're actually right about that.

NUNN: We never had a majority vote for them. You're right about that.

CAVUTO: Senators...

BENNETT: I wrote -- I wrote a bill...

NUNN: People never understood the problem. People have to understand it. When they do, the American people, I'm confident, will support...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Oh, no, I think you're right. I think you're right. But Senator Bennett, it's getting past that hurdle, right, to get the word out to them.

BENNETT: Yes, well, I -- I wrote a bill that was -- that did exactly the things that Senator Nunn is talking about. And it was scored by the administrators, the board of trustees, if that's the proper term of the Social Security administration, as a 100 percent fix of Social Security that would -- would make Social Security safe in perpetuity.

And I took it to the Republican leader and said, this is what we ought to be doing. And he said, Bob, that'll be the Republican position. And we'll get behind it as soon as you get your first Democratic cosponsor. And so I walked across the aisle and sat down with some of my Democratic friends and laid it out. And they said, you know, this is great. This is -- this will solve the problem.

And we'll get behind it. We'll join you right after the election.

CAVUTO: OK.

BENNETT: Well, you know, there we were. One point I really want to make, that Washington's the only place I know where, when you give somebody more this year than you gave them last year, that's called a cut.

CAVUTO: That's a very good point. And it's a point I want to pick up on.

(CROSSTALK)

BENNETT: Because you're giving them less than they were promised.

CAVUTO: Less than what they were expecting. I'm going to swirl (ph) it a little bit because that is something that we get wrong in the media, this idea of cuts, when you're actually talking about slowing the growth of something, to Senator Nunn's point, about making sure that line doesn't go up as much as it presently is.

The debate over -- the very words we use in this debate after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Fair and balanced -- we've got former Senator Bob Bennett, former Senator Sam Nunn, debating what we do now on -- on the debt. And you're quite right, gentlemen. Normally, this stuff comes up in detail in bravery (ph) after an election.

But Senator Nunn, do you -- if Barack Obama is reelected, the argument is, right now, we're hearing a lot of Democrats -- not all are already planning spending initiatives of their own. In other words, to keep the spigots spigotting, nothing changes.

Republicans, conversely if Mitt Romney were to win, are planning a lot of more military and the like spending. How do we disavow each side of its knee-jerk inclination to spend on industry's favored to its Party?

Senator Nunn, to you first.

NUNN: Well, I thought, hope that the debate will produce some more honest dialogue. And then right after the election, whoever is elected, whether it's President Obama or Mitt Romney, we face the fiscal cliff in January. And almost all economists left or right or center, say that that would cause a high-risk of another recession, a deep recession.

So what I would like to see instead of the fiscal cliff that we face, and instead of kicking that can down the road six months, why don't we change cans? Why don't we use Simpson-Bowles, Domenici-Rivlin or some legislative combination of those, substitute it for the cliff and say, OK, you've got six months.

You can overturn it. You may not like it. But it's a lot better than what we face right now. So why not substitute a logical and sane default position for what we have facing us now.

CAVUTO: Senator Bennett, what in your gut, do you think, they will do? I mean, regardless who wins in November, the prevailing wisdom is they either delay these cuts, try to screw around with sequestration so that the cuts are put off a little bit or all the Bush rates don't expire immediately -- a glorified way of kicking the can down the road. What do you think will happen?

BENNETT: Well, I think the suggestion that Senator Nunn has just made is exactly the right thing we ought to do -- we ought to see them do. I do not see sequestration, a fiscal cliff.

I see Congress blinking very big time and saying, well, let's delay this.

CAVUTO: We've got a lame duck session that decides that?

BENNETT: No, no, I think...

CAVUTO: Really?

BENNETT: ...maybe they'll do it in the lame duck. They come back on the third of January, do it quickly well or just put it off a little while while we talk about it because no one wants to be responsible for their consequences that would come if they did nothing.

So the instinct is well, let's just put it off a little while, while we talk about it.

CAVUTO: Yes, well, we've done that forever.

BENNETT: Let's not...

CAVUTO: But Senator Nunn, to that point...

(CROSSTALK)

BENNETT: ...that's not a solution. That's not a solution.

CAVUTO: I agree with you.

BENNETT: That's not a solution.

CAVUTO: But Senator Nunn, to that point, if we end up doing something like that, are we reinforcing the credit ratings agencies' desire to downgrade us, that that's the stuff of Banana Republic's and that (ph) now, there's going to be hell to pay for doing it.

NUNN: Well, I think Bob is basically correct. Yes, it's - it's an issue of rating agency. But the fundamental issue is a moral issue and a generational issue. And beyond the numbers, we can deal with the numbers - - all sorts of people on both sides that can work this thing out.

But the real signal to the markets and to the world and our own country is that this government cannot function. That's a more dangerous signal than even the numbers.

CAVUTO: Do you think, Senator Bennett, that if we don't make a move and soon, the message to the markets will be, sell-off like crazy?

BENNETT: The one thing that disturbs markets more than anything else is uncertainty. And Sam has just described the biggest uncertainty of all, which is will the U.S. government be able to function? There are...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Well, let me keep -- we're going to go a little longer if we...

BENNETT: Yes.

CAVUTO: ... I want to hear what you're saying, that if we -- if we don't act immediately, what you're saying, Senator Bennett, is that you can't keep pulling this stunt, that -- that this time, there would be hell to pay for that?

BENNETT: Well, I think, GDP growth would continue to be sluggish, if indeed, not tip over into another recession, just because, as has been pointed out in previous versions of this, there are trillions of dollars waiting on the sidelines for some sense of certainty...

CAVUTO: Right.

BENNETT: ...to come into the economy and investment. And if the federal government can't get its act together...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: If they get -- if they get their act together and respond...

BENNETT: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...that...

BENNETT: That money won't come in.

CAVUTO: I'm sorry. Senator Nunn, sorry, pressed for time here. I just want to make be clear on something. And do you think then that there would be a collapse or would these sequestration cuts just cuts off the growth of spending in the military and all these others, over 10 years no less. Are they really that draconian, that there would be that kind of a hell to pay?

NUNN: Well, to change all our previous habits but it's not draconian. We make modest changes now or everyday or month or a year. We wait. The changes have to be more dramatic.

CAVUTO: No, I understand. But these sequestration cuts that everyone all but calls doomsday -- are they really that doomsday?

NUNN: Well, it's a huge increase in taxes. And it's a very large cut of expenditures. All at once, it's not...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: All at once, yes.

NUNN: All at once. This is sudden and it's in a fragile economy. So no one knows precisely what's going to happen. But you know, I think we're right in the middle of Winston Churchill's prophecy where he said that America will always do the right thing after its tried every other alternative.

We don't know how long we're going to have to get through with the alternatives and do the right thing. No one can predict that.

The markets are comfortable until they're not comfortable. And it happens as we've seen in Europe very rapidly.

CAVUTO: A very good point. The markets are comfortable until they're not comfortable. That is a very good point.

Gentlemen, thank you both very, very much.

NUNN: Thank you, Neil. Thank you, Bob.

BENNETT: You bet.

CAVUTO: Progress is possible, folks. More after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, now, it is going to get busy -- very, very busy. The first big debate in Denver, coming up on Wednesday night. We're there. A little more than a week after that, the vice presidential debate, then we've got yet another presidential debate wrapping things up with the final Obama- Romney clash.

We're on each and every single one because it's your money. It's your life. And we mean it when we say it. We like to travel and we like to look out for you. Watch us.

END

NEIL CAVUTO, FOX HOST: Thirty-six days out and time some Democrats are already teeing a lot more spending up. Welcome, everybody. I'm Neil Cavuto. And never mind, we haven't even gotten to the first debate.

Some Democrats are already laying out their spending plans for a second Obama term's first day. Vermont Democratic Congressman Peter Welch wants to get back to an energy policy that acknowledges the climate change is real. For now, he is leaving out the price tag to address it, which Republicans predict will be unreal. California Democrat Mike Honda wants to refocus on health care to expand on increasingly cost days and state days insurance exchanges.

Arizona's Raul Grijalva favors a conservative push on immigration reform. Still, others interpret any Obama win as a referendum for more stimulus out of the middle-class, good or bad, depending on your political point of view. More taxes are on the rich to help pay for regardless of your point of view.

So get ready for it. They are already licking their financial chops planning for it. Never mind, you haven't even cast your vote.

It seems a lot of politicians are already grabbing for your wallet. Not much talk about getting this debt under control -- lots of talk, though, about, as we say, getting the very spending that helped get it out of debt and into debt out of control, an issue now that worries two former titans of the Senate, Democrat Sam Nunn and Republican Bob Bennett, thereby partisan red (ph) is coming up first to some worry post-election watchers right now.

Fox News Digital Political Editor, Chris Stirewalt and townhall.com's Katie Pavlich.

Chris, what are we to make about sort of these plans for a second Obama administration -- might not come to pass, but they're getting their spending priorities in order.

CHRIS STIREWALT, DIGITAL POLITICAL EDITOR, FOX NEWS: Well, look, Neil, the -- the thing that the president is very clearly doing in this reelection campaign is being very vague. And while Democrats accuse Mitt Romney of being vague, the president has intentionally talked only in general about the need for infrastructure and other stimulus kind of spending and the need for what he says will be a tax increase on top earners to pay for it.

But when you get down to specifics, you don't need -- you don't hear very much about what it would be. Part of the reason for that is that the president knows that there are a lot of people with their hands out.

There are a lot of people with ideas for how that money ought to be spent. And one concern that he has aside from frightening moderate voters with more spending is creating this line up at the trough for lawmakers from his own Party that would be looking for the second term to be even more lavish than the first.

CAVUTO: So you think that will be the case, Katie?

KATIE PAVLICH, TOWNHALL.COM: I think it could be. But based on, you know, what these Democrats have already lined up in terms of what they want for a second Obama term, it does seem a little bit out of touch because as we know, more spending when you're spending outside of your means -- we have $16 trillion in debt -- just means the expansion of government.

And poll after poll shows that the American people and American voters are concerned about how big the federal government has been getting. And I hear a lot of repeats in what they're asking for.

President Obama may not be, you know, implementing an environmental policy that's directly geared toward climate change, but you look at the EPA's policies under President Obama. And they're geared towards addressing climate change in terms of regulations on coal mines.

And in terms of immigration reform, we've seen President Obama work on the dream act. And we just saw his executive order that was very similar to that piece of legislation.

So it's kind of a repeat of what we've already seen and I would say a little bit out of touch with what people are concerned about right now.

CAVUTO: I wonder, Chris, if it's part of this -- the perceived victor's already claiming these polls. I suppose if Mitt Romney were the runaway favorite right now and you're in the defense establishment, you are seizing on keeping open those facilities and military contracts or jobs that could be imperiled as a result of even automatic sequestration.

So are we just seeing something we always see, just more obvious now or what?

STIREWALT: Well, I certainly think there is truth in that. And on the Republican side, Neil, what you'd expect right now would be a lot of calls for Romney to move right and position himself so that there would be cuts and that there would be things like that.

You might hear social issues crop up. But I think for the president, what this is -- we saw a poll today that was conducted for the Hill that said that 87 percent of Democrats are confident that the president's going to win.

And certainly, it is not helpful to the president's chances of winning for Democrats to be talking about new spending now at a time when people are very concerned about debt and deficit. But as these folks continue to believe that their man is going to carry the day on November 6, they probably want to get in line first.

CAVUTO: I'm just wondering, if there's always the risk when word lot (ph) of this leaks out, that they look like they're, you know, decorating the office before they're guaranteed they're going to have it, Katie. Now, if you're Barack Obama, you already have it.

So what's to stop you from saying, I might look at that new rug or what have you. But you know what I mean. There does seem to be a sense that -- that, you know, that they are planning for a victory that might not happen.

And if this gets out, then it could strike a lot of voters as, at the very least, arrogant.

PAVLICH: Well, I think, too, that they're forgetting that President Obama isn't the only piece of the puzzle. You still have a Republican House which Republicans look like they're going to hold onto the House.

And if Mitt Romney loses, well, let Paul Ryan is still going to be the budget chairman. And so Democrats can line up all these big spending initiatives if they want to.

But the fact is that the House is still going to be majority Republicans. If Republicans don't take back the Senate, it's going to be the same situation that we've had for the past two years.

And I would say, if they're going to go as far as trying to, as you say, decorate the office before they have it, well, we might see another turnaround election in the year 2014, like we did in 2010, if they continue to push this big spending, big government ideas going forward.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Wait a minute, you're not giving up on -- you're not giving up on 2012. It almost sounded like you were there.

PAVLICH: Well, I'm just simply saying, if they're going to go decorating the office, see (ph).

CAVUTO: OK. Guys, thank you both very, very much.

PAVLICH: Thank you.

STIREWALT: You got it.

CAVUTO: And well, don't look now, but he is back. Remember Ross and his charts 20 years later, back with a vengeance, and now, a new warning -- so deep in debt. Ross Perot fears we're easy baked (ph) to be taken down.

A former Clinton Press Secretary, Debate Commission Co-Chair, Mike McCurry on those warnings from a guy who two decades ago almost up-ended the presidential race.

Michael, very good to have you.

MICHAEL MCCURRY, FMR. CLINTON PRESS SECRETARY: Good to be with you.

CAVUTO: I remember Mikey and his charts -- I remember Bill Clinton responding to that, addressing that. And many will argue, it was your boss who did address some of those same debt issues that Perot claimed fame for.

But Perot is back saying, both Parties have let him down. I think he goes on to say that he doesn't like other guy and that both Parties have essentially risked throwing the country down the drain. Is that resonating?

MCCURRY: Well, I think that's classically Ross Perot. And I think, you know, that would be an attitude you expect him to have. But look, there is an opportunity with these debates on Wednesday night to get to some of the specifics that, you know, some of your commentators say are missing.

We're hoping that the format we have for these debates will get back beyond some of these slogans and the traditional talking points we're hearing from some of the candidates and get into a more substantive discussion. We're designing it that way.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Are they allowed charts, Mike? They can't bring charts like Ross Perot, right? So they have to tell it.

MCCURRY: It's a good question. The two campaigns have been in discussions with each other. The commission kinds of take a hands-off view...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I see.

MCCURRY: ...of that. I don't know if they've got an agreement on that. But we've seen both Governor Romney and President Obama use charts from time to time.

CAVUTO: Sure.

MCCURRY: So we'll tune in and we'll see what happens.

CAVUTO: You know, one of the things that I remember about the debates in '92 with Bill Clinton and others who have sort of mastered this as trying to get a complicated stuff across easily, particularly (ph), Ronald Reagan had this knack as well on the Republican side, to take complicated material and synthesize it for the people.

I mean, in this case, it would be a lot more money going out than is coming in. So I think to your old boss's credit, he would say, we have to address both Republicans, he'd been saying, now just to address all that money that's going out, address spending.

But how do you encapsulate that in a one-minute or 90-second rebuttal response to a point on spending?

MCCURRY: Well, that's the point. You really can't. So that's why we have redesigned the format of these debates so that there will be 15-minute chunks. And the candidates have to address the topic.

Now, Jim Lehrer, who will be moderating...

CAVUTO: Right.

MCCURRY: ...the debate on Wednesday night has already said, the first three subjects will be the economy, the economy, the economy. And then the fourth subject will be health care -- obviously, Medicare, financing, and health care financing, a big issue. And then to what your panelists were just talking about, the fifth topic will be the role of government.

CAVUTO: ... I want to hear what you're saying, that if we -- if we don't act immediately, what you're saying, Senator Bennett, is that you can't keep pulling this stunt, that -- that this time, there would be hell to pay for that?

BENNETT: Well, I think, GDP growth would continue to be sluggish, if indeed, not tip over into another recession, just because, as has been pointed out in previous versions of this, there are trillions of dollars waiting on the sidelines for some sense of certainty...

CAVUTO: Right.

BENNETT: ...to come into the economy and investment. And if the federal government can't get its act together...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: If they get -- if they get their act together and respond...

BENNETT: Yes.

CAVUTO: ...that...

BENNETT: That money won't come in.

CAVUTO: I'm sorry. Senator Nunn, sorry, pressed for time here. I just want to make be clear on something. And do you think then that there would be a collapse or would these sequestration cuts just cuts off the growth of spending in the military and all these others, over 10 years no less. Are they really that draconian, that there would be that kind of a hell to pay?

NUNN: Well, to change all our previous habits but it's not draconian. We make modest changes now or everyday or month or a year. We wait. The changes have to be more dramatic.

CAVUTO: No, I understand. But these sequestration cuts that everyone all but calls doomsday -- are they really that doomsday?

NUNN: Well, it's a huge increase in taxes. And it's a very large cut of expenditures. All at once, it's not...

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: All at once, yes.

NUNN: All at once. This is sudden and it's in a fragile economy. So no one knows precisely what's going to happen. But you know, I think we're right in the middle of Winston Churchill's prophecy where he said that America will always do the right thing after its tried every other alternative.

We don't know how long we're going to have to get through with the alternatives and do the right thing. No one can predict that.

The markets are comfortable until they're not comfortable. And it happens as we've seen in Europe very rapidly.

CAVUTO: A very good point. The markets are comfortable until they're not comfortable. That is a very good point.

Gentlemen, thank you both very, very much.

NUNN: Thank you, Neil. Thank you, Bob.

BENNETT: You bet.

CAVUTO: Progress is possible, folks. More after this.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, now, it is going to get busy -- very, very busy. The first big debate in Denver, coming up on Wednesday night. We're there. A little more than a week after that, the vice presidential debate, then we've got yet another presidential debate wrapping things up with the final Obama- Romney clash.

We're on each and every single one because it's your money. It's your life. And we mean it when we say it. We like to travel and we like to look out for you. Watch us.

END
