Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:598Y-67D1-F190-V06P-00000-00CAVUTO for September 3, 20132013-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCAVUTO for September 3, 2013

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: Forget if we ever launched missiles at Syria, focus on the issues that are stacking up like planes at LaGuardia. Welcome, everybody. I am Neil Cavuto. And add a possible war with Syria to Congress to do less. When it gets back from vacation, as if a budget deadline and a debt limit deadline and defund Obamacare or don't defund Obamacare deadline, and than immigration reform deadline, and so many other deadlines. As if all of these deadlines were not enough, now this.

That's why I do not - I want to move beyond this fixation with Syria. Do you really think this is just about Syria and do you really think this is about a president who suddenly cares about not going over the head of Congress after years of pushing through executive orders and regulations that (inaudible) that routinely defied Congress. And just as telling last week, when the president was saying when it came to Syria, he really did not need the approval of the Congress.

Now, this is about confusing Congress, maybe even embarrassing Congress and all of the nine days it will be in session this month, once again, ridiculing Congress and getting Americans to focus, maybe not so much on the president punting, but on Congress, once again, not governing. Now, he could come out smelling like a rose, even though he has given Congress nothing but thorns. But on whom he will pile, probably, all the blame. And is at this point, that the president steps back and says, well, I tried their way. Now the president isn't saying that yet, but it's pretty clear, his confidant informer campaign manager David Axelrod is thinking that right now tweeting that Congress suddenly is the dog that caught the car. I guess that means that Congress was chasing down to Syria in (inaudible) car? And now that it's caught, it has no idea what the hell to do with it or about it?

Well, me - I have had enough of it, because the only thing I liken to a dog and all of its pile on his, you know, pile of you know what, it's leading in its way, spending bills that never get done, budget reform that never gets touched, a tax makeover that never gets started. You smell what I smell? You don't have to be a Republican or a Democrat to smell it. It's the same smell. One we both smell before, long before Syria and I suspect, long after Syria. And even if Congress does want to make things right, Washington watcher Chris Stirewalt says they better boogie (ph) fast, because they don't have time to do much. If anything at all.

Chris, realistically, nine days, this month what can they do?

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS DIGITAL POLITICS EDITOR: Well, they can fight, they can posture, they can shove, they can yell, I think in the end they will have to be here more than those nine days. As you enumerated, aside from the odors that you talked about, there is work to be done. As you said, the continuing resolution funding the government expires at the end of September. You also have, as you said, the rollout of the free stuff (inaudible), the president's help while people can sign up for Obamacare on the first of October. You've got that. And then you have Jack Lew dropped the flag on the debt Derby, that ceiling has to go up in the middle of October - by the middle of October, he says. So, it's all running. Something has got to happen. Syria is related in this way, too. We have sequestration, spending levels that are in place. For the military and non-defense spending across the federal government. Democrats want to get non-defense spending up, if we're dropping billions of dollars worth of bombs on Syria. That's going to make it tougher, and - I suspect you'll hear hawkish Republicans like John McCain and others, saying well, if we're bombing Syria, we need to get rid of these caps on increased spending. We call it sequestration.

CAVUTO: We're going to be talking to a member who is advocating just that. You get my vote to just stop this military sequestration cuts. But having said that, that would be great harm, where there not, if we are going to go to war to be dealing with these annoying pesky financial issues that could bring the government down or shut it down or get it into a debt limit crisis? Wouldn't that play to the president's favor just to have this backdrop and not drop any of these other surprises?

STIREWALT: Well, I would say that David Axelrod is whistling past the graveyard a little bit on this. If the president of the United States is rebuffed by Congress on the fall to attack another country that is a pretty stinging defeat, and they can slap chop, they can divide (inaudible) however they want. But it will not be good if the president cannot get his way. And we should remember, he was forced to go to Congress. He wanted to do what he did with the attack on Libya, which was to say that it had been approved by an international buddy, in that case, the United Nations and the Arab League, unable to obtain - or not the United Nations, NATO, unable to obtain the cooperation of Great Britain, and without the initial help of the Arab League, the president had no choice, but to do what American presidents hate to do, which is go to Congress.

CAVUTO: Yeah, flying in the face of what he had said. Really, just 48 hours earlier.

STIREWALT: Yes.

CAVUTO: Chris, thank you, my friend. Good having you again.

STIREWALT: You bet.

CAVUTO: Well, forget about all these issues piling up. Retired Army General Robert Scales has focused on the real damage of the president throwing his hands up, particularly on Syria, where he all but announced the terror threat around the world - or keep terrorizing the world. General, what do you think of this?

GEN. ROBERT SCALES, U.S. ARMY (RET.): Well, you know, Neil, anytime we have these conversations I invoke the wisdom of First Sergeant Braun (ph). I know in Vietnam when I had my dithering moments, Sergeant Braun would say captain, always remember rule 13. Rule 13? Yeah, rule 13 says when in charge, take charge. And rule 13 applies whether you are a captain in the Army or the commander-in-chief. Look, whether we shoot missiles or we don't shoot missiles. When this is all over, the rest of the world and the American people are going to look at this, and scratch their heads over the process, the witness, the dithering, the inner articulation of Wednesday (ph). This since of a loss of will. You know, there is an old - there's an old strategic concept that says military power is equal to capabilities times will. No one doubts our capabilities, but people throughout the world and inside this country, are beginning to question our will. Neil.

CAVUTO: Now, you also mentioned, you know, this view that some people ask. That we're not consistent, to put it mildly. And I was always telling people, what do you for, or against or getting involved in Syria, whatever it is, whatever you decided or whatever you want to do, telegraph it immediately and don't sort of dither about it, whether you are not going to be involved, Mr. President, make that very clear. You see, the reason and the story certainly don't draw a red line. You do draw a redline, act on that redline pronto, because any dithering, any waiting just to me kind of emboldens our enemies. But what is your sense of it?

SCALES: I absolutely agree. You know, there's an old (inaudible), that whenever a nation takes an e (ph), whenever a nation goes - or pauses in an operation, the advantage of the initiative and time shifts to the enemy. And if anybody thinks that Assad isn't going to take advantage of these nine days, or these 13 days to reposition his forces, to gain allegiances in the region, to strengthen his own power, and also to pound his own people with missiles and artillery is wrong. Nine days of inaction shifts the advantage to the enemy, and so we get involved what - two weeks from now? And we wind up basically bouncing sand.

CAVUTO: Amazing. General, thank you.

SCALES: Thanks, Neil.

CAVUTO: You know, media magnate Mort Zuckerman says it could be even worse than that. Forget about how the president is seen in the eyes of the bad guys, the way he's indecisive, this is playing out on the global media, is not exactly proving a ringing endorsement from - for the rest of the world. Guys. What is going on?

MORT ZUCKERMAN, BILLIONAIRE INVESTOR: Well, what is going on is really an interesting question, because it is almost incomprehensible to witness what is going on. And to try and understand that given, a, the nature of the political system of the United States and B, what the president himself has said, so I'd like to read some of the things that he has said, so I get it right. When he first came into office, and we're now dealing with the much more serious issue, not just Syria but Iran and they're both connected because the credibility that we would have had, if we had done something in Syria, might have had a bigger effect on Iran. Now, the lack of credibility or the collapse of credibility will completely change that whole theater of the world.

So, Barack Obama shortly after his first election said to use all elements of American power, and I quote, "to thwart Iran's nuclear ambitions" and he said last year that a nuclear Iran would threaten the elimination of Israel, the security of Gulf nations and the stability of the global economy as well as risk triggering a nuclear arms race in the region and the unraveling of the non-proliferation treaty.

Now, what has happened in Syria have so undermined the international credibility of his entire policy, that the recent failure to respond to the chemical attacks by Syria will affect the credibility and viability of everything we have done so far, which is the core of America's programs and attitudes and credibility vis-.-vis Iran. Now, there is a suggestion we state to hear that the Arab Leagues did not support that. I'm going to read you from the resolutions of the Arab League. OK? Number one is the call upon the United Nations, this just came out - the call upon the United Nations and the international community to shoulder its responsibilities by taking firm and dissuasive means - measures against the perpetrators of this crime, for which the Syrian regime was responsible and to put an end to such violations and crimes of genocide that the Syrian regime has been committing for more than two years.

CAVUTO: Is that the whole Arab League saying that, or is it just some of them?

ZUCKERMAN: No, no, it's all the Arab League. No, no, no, it's virtually all, except two - and let me just - I can go on about this, OK? They strongly condemned and denounced this atrocious crime, this is virtually all of them, with the exception of two countries. To strongly condemn and denounce this atrocious crime, in which internationally prohibited chemical weapons were used in flagrant denial of ethical and humanitarian values as well as international laws and usages. I could go on about that, but ..

CAVUTO: But even they are saying that, now post this decision or non- decision ...

ZUCKERMAN: No, this meeting was just held in the last - yes, right after the ...

CAVUTO: So, could they be saying, they though attack would have been imminent, now that it's looking like it might not be imminent, they are getting worried?

ZUCKERMAN: Oh, no, they are very worried that he United States has basically abdicated the long-standing leadership role that we have played in the Middle East, and we have a lot of allies in that part of the world who are critical to us.

CAVUTO: What does Israel say?

ZUCKERMAN: Well, Israel of course is the one who's now faced with a huge problem of trying to deal, A, not only with Syria, but with Iran. Iran is a country that has been threatening Israel, and Israel of course on one level, it's going to do whatever it takes to defend themselves. They have a simply theory of life, because everybody knows that Iran is literally several months away at the very most of having a deliverable nuclear weapon.

CAVUTO: So they are interpreting that our lack of strong, immediate response in Syria telegraphs we will have the same posture with Iran?

ZUCKERMAN: Without question, that whole part of the world.

CAVUTO: Do you agree with it?

ZUCKERMAN: What else can you think about, when you have the president who comes out and says what he says and then does what he does? How can you believe what he says?

CAVUTO: So it's vacillating more than any specific position is what has rattled folks, right?

ZUCKERMAN: Of course, nobody -- the president of the United States has to be believed, he has to maintain his credibility. A lot of what we say, we hope, is going to prevent doing things that we don't want to do. We don't want to go to war. That is not what the United States is about. What we want to do is to protect the interests of ourselves and our allies, and there are a number of Arab countries who are our allies, and now they have lost faith in the United States, because they see that whatever he says is not necessarily what he does.

CAVUTO: Do you think, then, Mort, that the president regrets the famous red line remark, that it boxed him into a corner and he is scrambling to get out?

ZUCKERMAN: I don't know how to measure what he says or what he feels or what he believes at the time he says it, how he changes his mind. That is his job. But his job is also to make sure there is a consistency to what he says, because you cannot just say X on one day, and then say excuse me, I did not mean X, I mean Y. And then say, well, I didn't really mean Y. The president has to have that credibility and consistency, and if he does not have it, he cannot perform on behalf of the United States with our foreign policy and with the credibility it needs. We don't want to go to war every day to prove we are credible. You have to have somebody who, when he says something, everybody knows he means it.

The only time the Iranians held back on their nuclear weapons program was when the prime minister of Israel said if they got to a certain kind of a level of nuclear capability, the Israelis would act, so even though they could have crossed that line to date, the Iranians have held back, they understand who is to be believed. And now they will not come to the conclusion that this president is to be believed or to be feared.

CAVUTO: Mort, powerful stuff. Thank you, my friend, Mort Zuckerman.

Even Charlie is wrangling with the president on this one, because this decorated Korean War hero has a bone to pick with Barack Obama he says is not exactly acting heroic. Charlie unplugged, here and only here. But before we get back to Syria, Charlie later in the show, a look at the other drama that is being overshadowed by this Syria (inaudible). Remember those NSA spies? Lots more of them than you thought. Guess what? They are not working at the NSA. A whole bunch of them are just a point and click away. You use them every day even now.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Here is what feeds conspiracy theories on Syria. It is all but overshadowing serious spying abuses right here in the U.S. of A. And even now, in fact, more than even right now, the latest reports that Facebook and Twitter and Google have snoops that put those NSA snoops to shame, not just invading our privacy, to hear Katrina Pierson tell it, trampling on it. What is really going on here, Katrina?

KATRINA PIERSON: Here we are again finding out more and more things about who is reading our emails and who aren't. There was an independent research study that came out that showed that not only are some of these big tech giants reading our emails, but they are also clicking on specific links, which means your attachments are probably also being opened. But then I guess they figure if our government is doing it, it must be legal.

CAVUTO: Katrina, are they doing it at the government's behest or on their own? And if so, why?

PIERSON: That is the thing. Initially, they said, well, the government tells us we have to release this information, but this particular study said absolutely not. They sent out emails, personal emails with protected particular links, and they found that six out of the 50 they sent this through, through the networks, actually clicked on the link, including Google and Facebook. So really, what is the responsibility going on, and where is accountability in Congress on our privacy being violated? We need to start up and get out there and let Congress know they have got to get these companies under control.

CAVUTO: It is one thing for them to do something at the strong behest if not court order of the NSA or another government agency, it is quite another to take that power into their own, and it's already come up with issues about how they market things, how they share information, but this goes deeper than that, doesn't it?

PIERSON: That's the thing. We have to wonder why Congress is allowing this to happen. We already know that big business and government have a sinister marriage going on, and when we look at Google and Facebook and the political donors that come out of these companies to these politicians, it makes you wonder why there is no political will to do anything about it.

CAVUTO: So now where is all of this going? We know the NSA sort of cracked down, has sort of cracked up in the middle of this focus on Syria. I am sure the guys at the NSA love it. I'm sure the president likes that distraction. Many cynics argue it is the reason why Syria has been dumped in Congress' lap. So where do you think it's going??

PIERSON: I am not sure, and I do think it is a distraction. You mentioned earlier about some of the other issues Congress is going to have to take on, for example funding Obamacare, immigration and all these other things. So I think there are a lot of shiny objects being dropped into the room to divert attention to things really pressing American citizens today.

CAVUTO: Katrina, thank you very much, Katrina Pierson. While this is going on as we speak, despite all the huffing and puffing.

Well this Syria thing is apparently like the deflecting gift that keeps giving. Not only getting our eye off the spying still going on here ball, but you would not believe this latest doozy on health care ball. Guess what will happen very soon? While all these guys are knee deep in Syria debating. I will give you a clue. It has something to do with unions. I want to give you another clue -- it has something to do with them getting a big present too.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, under the cover of war there, a kamikaze attack by unions right here? Because mark my words, I told you this, while we're all focused on this do we or don't we get involved in Syria thing, general Richard Trumka will pull off one of the greatest stealth victories in the sordid history, short as it is, of this health care law thing. Without anyone knowing, he will have secured the exemption for unions on some of the law's most costly provisions, including the higher fees for Cadillac plans that dominate many unions plans, and ways around employer switching to too many part-time workers that could kill union workers. Only you won't know much about it, because I suspect no one will really cover because the world is too busy focusing on Damascus than unions pulling a fast one in DC. Julie Roginsky I am sure agrees with that point of view, but we'll get to her in a second. Jedediah Bila, to you first on whether that is a real possibility?

JEDEDIAH BILA: I think they're going to cave to the unions, and I think it's because for Barack Obama to say we don't need union support in the midterm elections would be ridiculous. The unions came out in support of Obamacare, and I think there were a lot of backroom deals and a lot of meetings that went on where the unions acknowledged that there were some things about this law that they did not necessarily like from the start, but they let Barack Obama know, we are allies here, and if we come out and we say we don't like this, you're going to need to mend those things. You're going to need to really account, be accountable to us, because we are the ones who helped you get elected twice, and we are the ones who are going to help your friends get elected over and over. So I think there will be a lot of caving, particularly with respect to the Cadillac tax and with respect to the concern about this influx of full-time workers going to part-time and what that does to a 40-hour workweek for union members.

CAVUTO: I don't think they are that sinister. I think they are stupid. But I will say this with all respect to Jedediah, a lot of them if they had just read the bill, they would have realized it added up and we are screwed. But they did not do that. But now they, like any group that feels it's offended and gotten a delay or extension or exemption, they want in, too.

JULIE ROGINSKY: Yes, I will say something that will offend my friends in the union movement, but that is what collective bargaining is for. Don't send me hate mail, I get it. But you know--

CAVUTO: It's nice your hate mail is bipartisan.

[LAUGHTER]

(CROSSTALK)

BILA: -- civil "Cavuto Clash."

CAVUTO: I could see under the darkness of all of this other stuff going on in Syria, some waivers that would be vague (ph), a new line in the bill that this applies to everyone but public union workers, it would not even be that blatant but it would be understood that they have gotten a pass.

ROGINSKY: It could happen. But as I said, it shouldn't.

CAVUTO: It will.

ROGINSKY: I don't know if it will happen. We will see.

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: Want to place one dollar on this?

CAVUTO: No.

(CROSSTALK)

BILA: I have $1, that's all about all I have, but I'll put a dollar on it.

ROGINSKY: I don't know if it will happen, but I sympathize with the unions, I get where they're coming from, but this is something to deal with the collective bargaining.

CAVUTO: (inaudible), who will be paying for it.

ROGINSKY: Well, as we've discussed--

CAVUTO: You and me.

ROGINSKY: Not you and I, because your health insurance is not going to change. I don't think they are going to get rid of health care insurance here at News Corp.

CAVUTO: You don't think my premiums have not gone up? Your premiums have not gone up?

ROGINSKY: My premiums went up well before Barack Obama came to office.

CAVUTO: You don't think it's accelerated? You don't think it will continue to accelerate?

ROGINSKY: Not once Obamacare kicks in.

BILA: Young people are going to help pay for it, who don't need insurance.

ROGINSKY: Sure they do.

BILA: But have been mandated--

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: We don't know what is coming, but I do want to address at another time here--

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Who says Secretary of State John Kerry is not every bit as good as his boss at it? One moment he is turning up the heat on Syria at the State Department, and the next he is talking about the heat via a video address to a climate conference in the Marshall Islands.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KERRY: Climate change is a global crisis, and it will require a global solution, one that includes shared resources, shared responsibility, and a shared sense of urgency above all.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAVUTO: Don't get me wrong, I am all for worrying about sweating, but shouldn't our secretary of state right now be sweating more about Syria? That's just me, Jedediah.

BILA: He wants to talk about everything but the real, legitimate, scary, frightening problem at hand.

CAVUTO: He is talking about--

(CROSSTALK)

BILA: I love all this talk about climate change. We all agree climate change exists. That's not the argument, John Kerry. The argument is how much of it is man-made. And how much government involvement should we have? Should we have pro free market approaches to address this problem or should we expand big government via stimulus or however you want to argue it in order to address the problem? So stop painting folks on the right as those who don't care about climate change in order to make a political point right now. You want to talk politics? Right now talk Syria. That's what you need to be talking about.

CAVUTO: Julie.

ROGINSKY: First of all, a Princeton University study came out a couple of days ago or weeks ago that actually said that climate change is linked to crisis, and that climate change is linked to more violence, so I think John Kerry is right to worry about this, because apparently according to the study, if global--

CAVUTO: It's making (inaudible).

ROGINSKY: Well--

CAVUTO: It makes despots more despot-like?

ROGINSKY: No, but it does make people more desperate when they have to fight over resources, and when they don't have resources to fight, when they have less, fewer resources to have, they are going to fight over that.

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: The point he is making is it is a global threat. It is a global threat to security, and if you look at the study, and I think the study is very telling, what it says essentially is that by 2050, if temperatures go up by 2 degrees Fahrenheit, which apparently they might, they will have a chance of doubling--

CAVUTO: And that is man-made? And (inaudible) needs us to pay for it?

ROGINSKY: First of all, you wanted a free market approach? How about the fact that we had a free market approach, cap and trade, something that the Republicans originally--

BILA: That's not a free market approach.

ROGINSKY: That is something the Republicans originally talked about--

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: -- walk, talk and chew gum at the same time?

(CROSSTALK)

BILA: Right now is not the time. You turn on the news right now, you see massive coverage of Syria, everyone in this country, no matter where you stand on the issue, is focused on this. John Kerry should not be pivoting right now to talk about climate change.

CAVUTO: But by the same token, many on the right will argue as I argued in the outset, do not use Syria as an excuse not to do anything else, not to address budget, not to--

(CROSSTALK)

BILA: -- a great time to expand government influence over the issue of climate change as the entire country is focused on our potential catastrophic involvement in Syria? He thinks this is the key time right now, today, to talk about climate change?

ROGINSKY: Is there ever a good time? There is always something going on. If we don't address this right now.

BILA: There is not always Syria going on.

ROGINSKY: First, there was Libya, then there was Egypt. Now there is a Syria.

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: We had Iraq for 10 years.

CAVUTO: But there is always time for golf.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: Days after his announcement that he's given to Congress, just hours after, he is golfing.

ROGINSKY: Are we really going to start comparing presidential vacations?

CAVUTO: Not at all. I just find it interesting.

BILA: The optics are not good. No matter how you slice it, the optics of him talking about climate change -- you could argue climate change is an important issue, just politically speaking the optics are not good for this right now.

ROGINSKY: Except for the fact that the majority of Americans agree that something needs to be done about climate change.

BILA: I agree, but I still think optically there is a problem.

ROGINSKY: There is always something going on. If we don't tackle this today, if we don't do this today, people are going to die tomorrow, and that is something we have to acknowledge, and that's something people, climate change deniers don't want to believe it, but it is happening. It is already happening if you look at the studies and it will continue to exacerbate.

CAVUTO: I could talk about global cycle patterns of weather and generational shifts and you could attach a very expensive solution to what you call a man-made problem, we can differ until the cows come home, but I find the timing odd.

ROGINSKY: (inaudible) timing is odd, I think you guys will never think there's good timing to do that.

BILA: I think there's good timing, plenty of good timing, and I think it is an important debate to have over government involvement versus how we address this, and it is a global challenge.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: -- don't use it as a (inaudible) distraction on the things we don't like. And conversely, liberals have to (inaudible) that we can't just force companies to pay for every environmental ill you attach to man.

(CROSSTALK)

ROGINSKY: We could spend more time repealing Obamacare for the 41st time. Or we could focus on things we actually might--

CAVUTO: I would like to repeal you.

(CROSSTALK)

CAVUTO: I don't mean it.

ROGINSKY: You just told me you're my last friend, now you dumped me. You dumped me too.

BILA: At least you have me.

ROGINSKY: Thank you, Jedediah.

CAVUTO: Between you and Colmes.

All right, when we come back, the president asked for when he put the Syria in Congress' hand. Congress demands the president dropped all those military secrets cuts or using getting his vote.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: The talk to Republicans in the House say they will now support the president on Syria so John Boehner and Eric Cantor are in. As for the rest of the troops on the right, let's not say all in and my guest says drop the military sequester cuts, Mr. President, or you can drop my support for those Syria strikes.

That Republican congressman is Michael Turner's offer on Damascus. Congressman, have you gotten any response from the White House?

REP. MICHAEL TURNER (R), OHIO: No, and just as we have not seen any leadership from the president with respect to his sequestration, his proposed sequestration, which I have opposed that is having devastating effects on our military. Now he wants to draw us into an additional conflict with Syria without addressing the issue that's affecting our men and women in uniform and certainly affecting the performance of our military.

CAVUTO: I'm sure you don't want to negotiate deals, is but if possible salvo back from the Democrats, all right, let's drop all sequestration cuts including the ones for defense, what do you say then?

TURNER: Well, in order to set the sequestration cuts aside, there have to be meaningful cuts elsewhere. The president embraced that himself when he proposed it and he put together the "Super Committee" that was supposed to propose those cut. With his withdrawal their failure resulted in the White House having the responsibility to come forward with those proposals.

The House passed two bills that would have set aside the sequestration by finding those cuts responsibly elsewhere. The Senate has passed none and the president still today has no response. Meanwhile, our military, we're hearing from the secretary is continuing to pay the price.

CAVUTO: You know, Speaker John Boehner has said he is confident that Republicans will share his view about the urgency of this. That you will go along and support fugitive strikes against Syria. It sounds to me that unless you get this you won't.

TURNER: Well, it depends. The president has not really made that case not to the American public or to the international community and certainly not to Congress. He does not appear to have any strategy here. We certainly don't know who we are for and also he has an unexplainable policy of this imaginary red line where the administration --

CAVUTO: I am not sure what that means. But the case that he has stated and you're right, it has been all over the map, but he has said he is not interested in regime change. So in other words, Assad stays in power, but he would very crippled, very weak and thereby I guess, getting the White House's argument setting the stage for him to be overthrown is not good enough for you?

TURNER: Well, I think certainly the president has indicated that he would like regime change in Syria, but the issue is that he declared this imaginary red line for the use of chemical weapons then redefined it to large-scale use of chemical weapons and now acknowledging that they were used previously. He clearly has not made the case internationally or to the American public or to Congress as to what our national interest? What are the risks and really who are we for?

The president had months, while hundreds of thousands of people had died in Syria, to address this issue and now at this crisis point trying to draw us into this crisis and a conflict with Syria without addressing what is happening currently in the Department of Defense as a result of his sequestration.

CAVUTO: But he has drawn in the House speaker. He has drawn in John McCain. He has drawn in a number of prominent Republican leaders maybe not you -- your speaker was not. So I guess what I'm asking you if your speaker came to you and said, Congressman, I really need you on this to support this. It sounds to me at this point, you would tell him no?

TURNER: Absolutely. At this point, the president is going to have to make the case that he has not made. He doesn't have a strategy. He has unexplainable policy and unless he does his homework done. I mean, the president has the responsibility to do his homework to get the international community together, to get Congress and the American public behind it. He has not done this. He has managed this as a crisis mode and I do not think that is a manner in which we should be heading into a conflict.

CAVUTO: All right, Congressman Turner, thank you very much.

TURNER: Thank you.

CAVUTO: Well, switching gears a little bit, are you ready for Samsung's smart watch? You know, it is beating Apple to the punch, but could I ask you something, do you really give a damn?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, now I know why Rolex sales have not been hurting. Apparently all this talk of a super cool smart watch from Samsung no one is biting or for that matter even buzzing. Tomorrow we'll know for sure when Samsung details its latest Dick Tracy wanna-be. But the company's only claim to fame here may be that it beat Apple to the punch offering this.

Tech analyst Lee Munson says what sounds cool, is it necessarily cool especially in a world where a lot of people express their status in life by the pricey stuff they put on their wrist. So if isn't Swiss, is the smart watch a miss, what do you think?

LEE MUNSON, PORTFOLIO LLC CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER: Well, I mean, here's the thing. If you are going to look for tomorrow's big announcement from Samsung that they are going to say we have the best new, the iPad, the smartphone of the future and the solution to Syria and the affordable care act, you're not going to get it. And that is what investors want tomorrow.

They want to know that some company has the new great driver of earnings to pummel Apple or be a big competitor, you're not. What you do have is something very much like back in 1996 when the first Palm Pilot came out. This smartphone you're going to see tomorrow, it's going to have a limited appeal for a limited market.

There is nothing wrong with that, but again if you have the wrong context or the attachment to what you think is going to happen tomorrow, you are going to be very disappointed and I think that is what going to happen to a lot of investors and viewers out there unless we set them straight today.

CAVUTO: All right, so for a smart watch, Dick Tracy watch, it's been talked about for decades, right? I mean, is it really that much demand for it. Now I'm hardly any -- but to me this sounds stupid. I think if you look at the watch, you look at the time or the date, but for the other stuff what becomes of all the other devices that you do depend on?

MUNSON: You know, I don't think it is clear what people are really going to use it for. For instance, all the leaks that we are getting and all the blogs is that what we're going to see tomorrow really is about people like myself who were into going to the gym all the time. So they are talking about, you know, it takes pictures of the food you eat and maybe the sophisticated heart rate monitor.

CAVUTO: But they have those types of devices. They have those types of devices. Now maybe they combine some of those features to give you the time and the day and the temperature and what they're eating in Bolivia but, come on, right?

MUNSON: Listen, I am not disagreeing with you, but I think that we do have to have -- there is a context. You are going to be disappointed as anybody who thinks this is going to be more than a cool little toy. I grant you. I do think that if you what status, you are going to buy an actual wrist watch that will never goes on or off line.

I mean, that's just cool to have something that you don't have to turn off when you're on an airplane, but I think the more important thing is investors, your viewers. Don't get confused tomorrow with whatever people like us end up saying about it because Samsung is a massive vertically integrated conglomerate. What that means is they have tons of products and billions in sales.

CAVUTO: I know that, but if they beat Apple to the punch on this and let's say we don't really need this then for Apple wouldn't be better to be never than late?

MUNSON: Well, I don't think so. You know, the thing is that we don't know -- we didn't know in 1996 what a Palm Pilot was going to be used for. My wife got one shortly after. I didn't know what to use it for, for years and years because it had a very small segment. There are going to be people tomorrow. They are going to want to buy this because it's shiny and new electronic.

Sales figures I am with you. I don't think it's going to be a mindblower, but I also think that the iPod was not the first MP3 player. What they did is they perfected the MP3 player. Samsung do the R&D and let the Apple do the real R&D, which I like to refer to as rip-off and duplicate only better so I think time will tell.

I think Apple has to have some sort of risk product, but I think they are going to let everybody else spend the money to figure out the market and Apple usually comes in there and perfects it.

CAVUTO: All right, that was the old Apple. I don't know about the new Apple. Lee Munson, thank you very much.

MUNSON: Thank you.

CAVUTO: In the meantime, it sounds like the president wrangled GOP leaders John Boehner and Eric Cantor, but it is a top Democrat Charlie Rangel out? When Democrats defect on Syria, is the situation for the White House getting serious?

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Well, one thing about this Syria crisis is it's turning everything upside down. Republicans, you would think would automatically say no to the president are now increasingly saying yes and Democratic supporters like Charlie Rangel are sounding very doubtful as if he will ever say yes.

The New York congressman is on the phone with us now. Another thing you might not know about the congressman, he is a Korean war hero so he is no daisy in this race. But I want to talk to you about that part of your experience, Congressman.

The argument the White House has made that this is important to avoid wider conflicts down the road and that we have to do this to send a message. But in delaying the message and leading it in Congress, isn't he compounding that?

REP. CHARLES RANGEL (D), NEW YORK (via telephone): First of all, we are talking about war. Whatever lines the president has drawn. Whatever commitment he may have made to international people, this is putting people in harm's way. They talk about limited war. There is no such thing as a limited war. Iraq was limited war.

We lost 6,500 American lives over the so-called limited war for a 10-year period. This is an international problem that demands an international solution, but to go into this alone with the idea to bypass the Security Council, and the United Nations, and the Arab League, the European Union, Great Britain, they tell us these people are on the line.

But this whole idea that every evil person requires such as the president of United States, that requires our troops in there, it does not make sense.

CAVUTO: Do you think though that throwing this in Congress is cover for the president because let's say Congress votes against this. I don't know what the read in the House. You may have a better idea than I do then the president could say I tried?

RANGEL: It's not throwing it in Congress' lap. The fact that the president has drawn a red line it does not constitute them right of the need to say we will go to war you have to come to Congress.

CAVUTO: He did it with NATO during the Bosnia situation --

RANGEL: So did Roosevelt and it's wrong. It is unconstitutional and the Congress goes along with it and you know why because they don't have their constituents for the most part that are making the sacrifice, the people from rural areas and in the cities to volunteer.

But if they go for one minute every time we went to war was in Kosovo or Panama or Iraq then the Congress will take this. We'll let the president to this. Sullivan told this morning it was about bombing and how could rethink of the loss of American lives or we have to do it because what people will think about us? We're not playing some war games. We're talking about people's lives.

CAVUTO: It sounds to me, Congressman, like you are saying that you would be against this as its defense now with the very least to lack of foreign support. So you would vote no on that basis alone?

RANGEL: You got that right. But this is international. There is no military solution to this problem. Anyone plays the case with every thread to society we have to put our military up that does not make any sense at all.

CAVUTO: Charlie Rangel, thank you very much.

RANGEL: Thank you, buddy.

CAVUTO: All right, the faded drums of war or much louder drums of deal? Something is perking Wall Street's interest and I suspect it's not missiles more like mergers.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Big deals, big risks and big dreams, Scott Martin and Kimberly blitz to see if you buy. First up, folks, those big deals are back with a vengeance whether it's Microsoft in more than a $7 billion transaction or Verizon paying Vodafone a staggering $130 billion to go away. Signs of mergers and acquisitions are just getting going this day? Would that be a good sign, Kimberly?

KIMBERLY FOSS, EMPYRION WEALTH MANAGEMENT PRESIDENT: Yes, I think this is a great opportunity for the telecom industry for rise in $130 million. It's the third biggest corporate fill in history. It's going to take, Vodafone giving to Verizon. You have the 6.4 percent dividend on Vodafone and 4 percent dividend on Verizon. It's going to propel this thing to no end. It is a big buy for me.

CAVUTO: You know, Scott, obviously the temptation for Verizon was the possible interest rates were as low as they were so if this thinking you get $130 million monkey of its back in the name of Vodafone, you can argue the price, maybe other companies are seizing on the same rate position right now to do something like it?

SCOTT MARTIN, ACCENT ASSET MANAGEMENT CEO: Well, they better hurry, Neil, because we all rates are going up at a pretty alarming rate here. It's kind of interesting though, I don't know if I totally agree with Kim though because I don't really like the space, Neil. It's becoming more competitive and margins are coming in. Meaning profits are dropping.

So that to me is not a great business to be in and plus these companies especially the tech companies are using cash that's parked overseas because they don't want to repatriate it and pay U.S. taxes. So that money is limited in some degree because instead of it going back to the United States, they are buying other countries. So yes, it's great if you're the acquirer like Nokia, but I am not sure if that helps the companies like Microsoft.

CAVUTO: All right, guys, I want to switch gears here to address this second issue, three words that don't register with me, retro hunting gear. I am told it is the rage and retailer H&M is all in. Who knew camouflage meant so much cash? Nothing attracts men like military fatigue. So it must be a bulletproof fashion statement? Scott, what do you think?

MARTIN: Well, I am pretty cool, Neil. So I was ahead of this one and I've already got some orders in on this stuff. I think it's interesting. It's definitely a risk, but I think they are calculated one for H&M because look at what's happened in retail, Neil. Even over the last couple of years, not just this summer where a lot of the retailers have been smashed because it is the same old same old. So I like the fact that this company is going out there and doing something different making a push perhaps into a different section just to roll some heads and see if it actually works.

CAVUTO: What do you think, Kim?

FOSS: Yes, I agree. I mean, no consumer should be denied and should be ignored especially the male consumer. I got to tell you they're doing the great job with the underwear and let me just tell you who knows? Maybe boxers is the next rage? I wouldn't mind if I came home and saw my husband in some chemo gear.

CAVUTO: This is a family show that maybe I am out of touch and you guys are clearly in touch. Now we know why Jeff Basos flanked down $250 million for the "Washington Post." He was high as the kite or drank out of his mind or both. What else could explain his reason for going big time on "Washington Post" reading? Apparently, he was to usher in a new golden age for newspapers lickety-split.

But Scott, is Jeff on to something because the golden age for newspapers and I love them dearly, but I read them online, the conventional product is gone.

MARTIN: Me as well, Neil, also that was decades ago. I think regarding whenever he resigned he was lucky he came off and bought it today not four years ago because I guess they're going to get four or five times what it did today, which goes to show you, again, it's kind of like the telecom business. You know, it's not a great business to be in. Yes people go there for their news, but it is online. It's digital. So unless he has some amazing revamping that he's planned here, Neil. I don't think it is a great deal for them as far as the Amazon or other newspapers possibly up for sale.

CAVUTO: He is good at marketing stuff and if you were to do something for prime readership customers that could be the start of something. So we have the makings of making this work, but he is up again strong ties?

FOSS: I think the digital era is here to have something very innovative for a certain segment of the market, but those that don't have the physical paper. Unfortunately, they are aging and they are not buying that paper as much anymore even read online when they magnify it. So I agree with Scott. I think this is not a win-win for Jeff or for the consumer. It is going to be a hard road, but maybe we'll wait and see what happens. He is pretty innovative guy.

CAVUTO: Indeed, if he can convince people to pay for that online product then maybe it would work. He would seem to have the best shot of doing that, but it is a very tough battle. Scott and Kim, thank you both very much. That will do it. We will continue monitor the debate with Syria and how it falls out.

END

urn:contentItem:598Y-67D1-F190-V05T-00000-00CAVUTO for September 3, 20132013-09-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:31ZLexisNexisCAVUTO for September 3, 2013

NEIL CAVUTO, FBN ANCHOR: Forget if we ever launched missiles at Syria, focus on the issues that are stacking up like planes at LaGuardia. Welcome, everybody. I am Neil Cavuto. And add a possible war with Syria to Congress to do less. When it gets back from vacation, as if a budget deadline and a debt limit deadline and defund Obamacare or don't defund Obamacare deadline, and than immigration reform deadline, and so many other deadlines. As if all of these deadlines were not enough, now this.

That's why I do not - I want to move beyond this fixation with Syria. Do you really think this is just about Syria and do you really think this is about a president who suddenly cares about not going over the head of Congress after years of pushing through executive orders and regulations that (inaudible) that routinely defied Congress. And just as telling last week, when the president was saying when it came to Syria, he really did not need the approval of the Congress.

Now, this is about confusing Congress, maybe even embarrassing Congress and all of the nine days it will be in session this month, once again, ridiculing Congress and getting Americans to focus, maybe not so much on the president punting, but on Congress, once again, not governing. Now, he could come out smelling like a rose, even though he has given Congress nothing but thorns. But on whom he will pile, probably, all the blame. And is at this point, that the president steps back and says, well, I tried their way. Now the president isn't saying that yet, but it's pretty clear, his confidant informer campaign manager David Axelrod is thinking that right now tweeting that Congress suddenly is the dog that caught the car. I guess that means that Congress was chasing down to Syria in (inaudible) car? And now that it's caught, it has no idea what the hell to do with it or about it?

Well, me - I have had enough of it, because the only thing I liken to a dog and all of its pile on his, you know, pile of you know what, it's leading in its way, spending bills that never get done, budget reform that never gets touched, a tax makeover that never gets started. You smell what I smell? You don't have to be a Republican or a Democrat to smell it. It's the same smell. One we both smell before, long before Syria and I suspect, long after Syria. And even if Congress does want to make things right, Washington watcher Chris Stirewalt says they better boogie (ph) fast, because they don't have time to do much. If anything at all.

Chris, realistically, nine days, this month what can they do?

CHRIS STIREWALT, FOX NEWS DIGITAL POLITICS EDITOR: Well, they can fight, they can posture, they can shove, they can yell, I think in the end they will have to be here more than those nine days. As you enumerated, aside from the odors that you talked about, there is work to be done. As you said, the continuing resolution funding the government expires at the end of September. You also have, as you said, the rollout of the free stuff (inaudible), the president's help while people can sign up for Obamacare on the first of October. You've got that. And then you have Jack Lew dropped the flag on the debt Derby, that ceiling has to go up in the middle of October - by the middle of October, he says. So, it's all running. Something has got to happen. Syria is related in this way, too. We have sequestration, spending levels that are in place. For the military and non-defense spending across the federal government. Democrats want to get non-defense spending up, if we're dropping billions of dollars worth of bombs on Syria. That's going to make it tougher, and - I suspect you'll hear hawkish Republicans like John McCain and others, saying well, if we're bombing Syria, we need to get rid of these caps on increased spending. We call it sequestration.

CAVUTO: We're going to be talking to a member who is advocating just that. You get my vote to just stop this military sequestration cuts. But having said that, that would be great harm, where there not, if we are going to go to war to be dealing with these annoying pesky financial issues that could bring the government down or shut it down or get it into a debt limit crisis? Wouldn't that play to the president's favor just to have this backdrop and not drop any of these other surprises?

STIREWALT: Well, I would say that David Axelrod is whistling past the graveyard a little bit on this. If the president of the United States is rebuffed by Congress on the fall to attack another country that is a pretty stinging defeat, and they can slap chop, they can divide (inaudible) however they want. But it will not be good if the president cannot get his way. And we should remember, he was forced to go to Congress. He wanted to do what he did with the attack on Libya, which was to say that it had been approved by an international buddy, in that case, the United Nations and the Arab League, unable to obtain - or not the United Nations, NATO, unable to obtain the cooperation of Great Britain, and without the initial help of the Arab League, the president had no choice, but to do what American presidents hate to do, which is go to Congress.

CAVUTO: Yeah, flying in the face of what he had said. Really, just 48 hours earlier.

STIREWALT: Yes.

CAVUTO: Chris, thank you, my friend. Good having you again.

STIREWALT: You bet.

CAVUTO: Well, forget about all these issues piling up. Retired Army General Robert Scales has focused on the real damage of the president throwing his hands up, particularly on Syria, where he all but announced the terror threat around the world - or keep terrorizing the world. General, what do you think of this?

CAVUTO: Well, one thing about this Syria crisis is it's turning everything upside down. Republicans, you would think would automatically say no to the president are now increasingly saying yes and Democratic supporters like Charlie Rangel are sounding very doubtful as if he will ever say yes.

The New York congressman is on the phone with us now. Another thing you might not know about the congressman, he is a Korean war hero so he is no daisy in this race. But I want to talk to you about that part of your experience, Congressman.

The argument the White House has made that this is important to avoid wider conflicts down the road and that we have to do this to send a message. But in delaying the message and leading it in Congress, isn't he compounding that?

REP. CHARLES RANGEL (D), NEW YORK (via telephone): First of all, we are talking about war. Whatever lines the president has drawn. Whatever commitment he may have made to international people, this is putting people in harm's way. They talk about limited war. There is no such thing as a limited war. Iraq was limited war.

We lost 6,500 American lives over the so-called limited war for a 10-year period. This is an international problem that demands an international solution, but to go into this alone with the idea to bypass the Security Council, and the United Nations, and the Arab League, the European Union, Great Britain, they tell us these people are on the line.

But this whole idea that every evil person requires such as the president of United States, that requires our troops in there, it does not make sense.

CAVUTO: Do you think though that throwing this in Congress is cover for the president because let's say Congress votes against this. I don't know what the read in the House. You may have a better idea than I do then the president could say I tried?

RANGEL: It's not throwing it in Congress' lap. The fact that the president has drawn a red line it does not constitute them right of the need to say we will go to war you have to come to Congress.

CAVUTO: He did it with NATO during the Bosnia situation --

RANGEL: So did Roosevelt and it's wrong. It is unconstitutional and the Congress goes along with it and you know why because they don't have their constituents for the most part that are making the sacrifice, the people from rural areas and in the cities to volunteer.

But if they go for one minute every time we went to war was in Kosovo or Panama or Iraq then the Congress will take this. We'll let the president to this. Sullivan told this morning it was about bombing and how could rethink of the loss of American lives or we have to do it because what people will think about us? We're not playing some war games. We're talking about people's lives.

CAVUTO: It sounds to me, Congressman, like you are saying that you would be against this as its defense now with the very least to lack of foreign support. So you would vote no on that basis alone?

RANGEL: You got that right. But this is international. There is no military solution to this problem. Anyone plays the case with every thread to society we have to put our military up that does not make any sense at all.

CAVUTO: Charlie Rangel, thank you very much.

RANGEL: Thank you, buddy.

CAVUTO: All right, the faded drums of war or much louder drums of deal? Something is perking Wall Street's interest and I suspect it's not missiles more like mergers.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

CAVUTO: Big deals, big risks and big dreams, Scott Martin and Kimberly blitz to see if you buy. First up, folks, those big deals are back with a vengeance whether it's Microsoft in more than a $7 billion transaction or Verizon paying Vodafone a staggering $130 billion to go away. Signs of mergers and acquisitions are just getting going this day? Would that be a good sign, Kimberly?

KIMBERLY FOSS, EMPYRION WEALTH MANAGEMENT PRESIDENT: Yes, I think this is a great opportunity for the telecom industry for rise in $130 million. It's the third biggest corporate fill in history. It's going to take, Vodafone giving to Verizon. You have the 6.4 percent dividend on Vodafone and 4 percent dividend on Verizon. It's going to propel this thing to no end. It is a big buy for me.

CAVUTO: You know, Scott, obviously the temptation for Verizon was the possible interest rates were as low as they were so if this thinking you get $130 million monkey of its back in the name of Vodafone, you can argue the price, maybe other companies are seizing on the same rate position right now to do something like it?

SCOTT MARTIN, ACCENT ASSET MANAGEMENT CEO: Well, they better hurry, Neil, because we all rates are going up at a pretty alarming rate here. It's kind of interesting though, I don't know if I totally agree with Kim though because I don't really like the space, Neil. It's becoming more competitive and margins are coming in. Meaning profits are dropping.

So that to me is not a great business to be in and plus these companies especially the tech companies are using cash that's parked overseas because they don't want to repatriate it and pay U.S. taxes. So that money is limited in some degree because instead of it going back to the United States, they are buying other countries. So yes, it's great if you're the acquirer like Nokia, but I am not sure if that helps the companies like Microsoft.

CAVUTO: All right, guys, I want to switch gears here to address this second issue, three words that don't register with me, retro hunting gear. I am told it is the rage and retailer H&M is all in. Who knew camouflage meant so much cash? Nothing attracts men like military fatigue. So it must be a bulletproof fashion statement? Scott, what do you think?

MARTIN: Well, I am pretty cool, Neil. So I was ahead of this one and I've already got some orders in on this stuff. I think it's interesting. It's definitely a risk, but I think they are calculated one for H&M because look at what's happened in retail, Neil. Even over the last couple of years, not just this summer where a lot of the retailers have been smashed because it is the same old same old. So I like the fact that this company is going out there and doing something different making a push perhaps into a different section just to roll some heads and see if it actually works.

CAVUTO: What do you think, Kim?

FOSS: Yes, I agree. I mean, no consumer should be denied and should be ignored especially the male consumer. I got to tell you they're doing the great job with the underwear and let me just tell you who knows? Maybe boxers is the next rage? I wouldn't mind if I came home and saw my husband in some chemo gear.

CAVUTO: This is a family show that maybe I am out of touch and you guys are clearly in touch. Now we know why Jeff Basos flanked down $250 million for the "Washington Post." He was high as the kite or drank out of his mind or both. What else could explain his reason for going big time on "Washington Post" reading? Apparently, he was to usher in a new golden age for newspapers lickety-split.

But Scott, is Jeff on to something because the golden age for newspapers and I love them dearly, but I read them online, the conventional product is gone.

MARTIN: Me as well, Neil, also that was decades ago. I think regarding whenever he resigned he was lucky he came off and bought it today not four years ago because I guess they're going to get four or five times what it did today, which goes to show you, again, it's kind of like the telecom business. You know, it's not a great business to be in. Yes people go there for their news, but it is online. It's digital. So unless he has some amazing revamping that he's planned here, Neil. I don't think it is a great deal for them as far as the Amazon or other newspapers possibly up for sale.

CAVUTO: He is good at marketing stuff and if you were to do something for prime readership customers that could be the start of something. So we have the makings of making this work, but he is up again strong ties?

FOSS: I think the digital era is here to have something very innovative for a certain segment of the market, but those that don't have the physical paper. Unfortunately, they are aging and they are not buying that paper as much anymore even read online when they magnify it. So I agree with Scott. I think this is not a win-win for Jeff or for the consumer. It is going to be a hard road, but maybe we'll wait and see what happens. He is pretty innovative guy.

CAVUTO: Indeed, if he can convince people to pay for that online product then maybe it would work. He would seem to have the best shot of doing that, but it is a very tough battle. Scott and Kim, thank you both very much. That will do it. We will continue monitor the debate with Syria and how it falls out.

END
